(A Particle Field Theorist's) Lectures on (Supersymmetric, Non-Abelian) Fluid Mechanics (and d-Branes)

R. Jackiw
Center for Theoretical Physics
Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Cambridge, MA 02139-4307

Text transcribed by M.-A. Lewis, typeset in ATEX\mathrm{AT}_{\mathrm{E}} \mathrm{X}ATE​X by M. Stock MIT-CTP#3000

Abstract

This monograph is derived from a series of six lectures I gave at the Centre de Recherches Mathématiques in Montréal, in March and June 2000, while titulary of the Aisenstadt Chair.

Contents

Précis ..... 5 1 Introduction ..... 8 2 Classical Equations ..... 9 2.1 Equations of motion ..... 9 2.2 A word on canonical formulations ..... 11 2.3 The irrotational case ..... 13 2.4 Nonvanishing vorticity and the Clebsch parameterization ..... 16 2.5 Some further remarks on the Clebsch parameterization ..... 18 3 Specific Models ..... 24 3.1 Galileo-invariant nonrelativistic model ..... 24 3.2 Lorentz-invariant relativistic model ..... 30 3.3 Some remarks on relativistic fluid mechanics ..... 33 4 Common Ancestry: The Nambu-Goto Action ..... 36 4.1 Light-cone parameterization ..... 36 4.2 Cartesian parameterization ..... 36 4.3 Hodographic transformation ..... 37 4.4 Interrelations ..... 39 5 Supersymmetric Generalization ..... 41 5.1 Chaplygin gas with Grassmann variables ..... 41 5.2 Supersymmetry ..... 44 5.3 Supermembrane Connection ..... 45 5.4 Hodographic transformation ..... 46 5.5 Light-cone parameterization ..... 47 5.6 Further consequences of the supermembrane connection ..... 48 6 One-dimensional Case ..... 49 6.1 Specific solutions for the Chaplygin gas on a line ..... 50 6.2 Aside on the integrability of the cubic potential in one dimension ..... 51 6.3 General solution for the Chaplygin gas on a line ..... 51 6.4 Born-Infeld model on a line ..... 53 6.5 General solution of the Nambu-Goto theory for a ( d=1\mathrm{d}=1d=1 )-brane (string) in twd spatial dimensions (on a plane) ..... 54 7 Towards a Non-Abelian Fluid Mechanics ..... 59 7.1 Proposal for non-Abelian fluid mechanics ..... 59 7.2 Non-Abelian Clebsch parameterization ..... 60 7.3 Proposal for non-Abelian magnetohydrodynamics ..... 64 Solutions to Problems ..... 66 References ..... 68

Précis

During the March 2000 meeting of the Workshop on Strings, Duality, and Geometry in Montréal, Canada, I delivered three lectures on topics in fluid mechanics, while titulary of the Aisenstadt Chair. Three more lectures were presented in June 2000, during the Montréal Workshop on Integrable Models in Condensed Matter and Non-Equilibrium Physics. Here are brief descriptive remarks on the content of the lectures.

  1. Introduction - The motivation for the research is explained.
  2. Classical Equations - The classical theory is reviewed, but in a manner different from textbook discussions. (a) Equations of motion - Summary of conservation and Euler equations. (b) A word on canonical formulations - An advertisement of the method for finding the canonical structure for the above (developed with L.D. Faddeev). (c) The irrotational case - C. Eckart's Lagrangian and a relativistic generalization for vortex-free motion. (d) Nonvanishing vorticity and the Clebsch parameterization - In the presence of vorticity, the velocity Chern-Simons term (kinetic helicity) provides an obstruction to the construction of a Lagrangian for the motion. C.C. Lin's method overcomes the obstruction, and leads to the Clebsch parameterization for the velocity vector. (e) Some further remarks on the Clebsch parameterization - Properties and peculiarities of this presentation for a 3 -vector.
  3. Specific Models - Nonrelativistic and relativistic fluid mechanics in spatial dimensions greater than one. (a) Galileo-invariant nonrelativistic model - The Chaplygin gas [negative pressure, inversely proportional to density] is studied, selected solutions are presented, unexpected symmetries are identified. (b) Lorentz-invariant relativistic model - The scalar Born-Infeld model is found to be the relativistic generalization of the Chaplygin gas, and shares with it unexpected symmetries. (c) Some remarks on relativistic fluid mechanics - Dynamics for isentropic relativistic fluids is given a Lagrangian formulation, and the Born-Infeld model is fitted into that framework.
  4. Common Ancestry: The Nambu-Goto Action - Both the Chaplygin gas and the BornInfeld model devolve from the parameterization-invariant Nambu-Goto action, when specific parameterization is made. (a) Light-cone parameterization - Chaplygin gas is derived. (b) Cartesian parameterization - Born-Infeld model is derived. (c) Hodographic transformation - Chaplygin gas is derived (again). (d) Interrelations - The Chaplygin gas and Born-Infeld are related because (1) the former is the nonrelativistic limit of the latter; (2) both descend from the same Nambu-Goto action.
  5. Supersymmetric Generalization - Fluid mechanics enhanced by supersymmetry. (a) Chaplygin gas with Grassmann variables - Vorticity is parameterized by Grassmann variables, which act like Gaussian potentials of the Clebsch parameterization. (b) Supersymmetry - Supercharges, transformations generated by them, and their algebra. (c) Supermembrane connection - Supermembrane Lagrangian in three spatial dimensions. (d) Hodographic transformation - Supersymmetric Chaplygin gas in two spatial dimensions is derived. (e) Light-cone parameterization - Supersymmetric Chaplygin gas in two spatial dimensions is derived (again). (f) Further consequences of the supermembrane connection - Hidden symmetries of the supersymmetric model.
  6. One-dimensional Case - The previous models in one spatial dimension are completely integrable. (a) Solutions for the Chaplygin gas on a line - Some special solutions are presented; infinite number of constants of motion is identified; Riemann coordinates are introduced and the fluid equations as well as constants of motion are expressed in terms of them. (b) Aside on the integrability of the cubic potential in one dimension - The one-dimensional problem with pressure ∝\propto∝ (density) 3{ }^{3}3 possesses the SO(2,1)\mathrm{SO}(2,1)SO(2,1) "Schrödinger symmetry" and the equations of motion, in Riemann form, become free. (c) General solution of the Chaplygin gas on a line - Solution obtained by linearization. (d) Born-Infeld model on a line - When formulated in terms of its Riemann coordinates, it becomes trivially equivalent to the Chaplygin gas. (e) General solution of the Nambu-Goto theory for a ( d=1d=1d=1 )-brane (string) in two spatial dimensions (on a plane) - The explicit string solution is transformed by a hodographic transformation to the Chaplygin gas solution, and a relation is established between this solution and the one found by linearization.
  7. Towards a Non-Abelian Fluid Mechanics - Motivation for this theory is given. (a) Proposal for non-Abelian fluid mechanics - A Lagrangian is proposed; it involves a non-Abelian auxiliary field whose Chern-Simons density should be a total derivative. (b) Non-Abelian Clebsch parameterization (or, casting the non-Abelian Chern-Simons density into total derivative form) - Total derivative form for the non-Abelian ChernSimons density is found, thereby generalizing the Abelian Clebsch parameterization, which achieves a total derivative form for the Abelian density. (c) Proposal for non-Abelian magnetohydrodynamics - Our proposal, which generalizes the one in Section 7.1 to include a dynamical non-Abelian gauge field, reduces in the Abelian limit to conventional magnetohydrodynamics.

1 Introduction

Field theory, as developed by particle physicists in the last quarter century, has enjoyed a tremendous expansion in concepts and calculational possibilities.

We learned about higher and unexpected symmetries, and discovered evidence for partial or complete integrability facilitated by these symmetries. We appreciated the relevance of topological ideas and structures, like solitons and instantons, and introduced new dynamical quantities, like the Chern-Simons terms in odd-dimensional gauge theories. We enlarged and unified numerous degrees of freedom by introducing organizing principles such as non-Abelian symmetries and supersymmetries. Indeed, application of field theory to particle physics has now been replaced by the study of fundamentally extended structures like strings and membranes, which bring with them new mathematically intricate ideas.

Thinking about research possibilities, I decided to investigate whether the novelties that we have introduced into particle physics field theory can be used in a different, non-particle physics, yet still field-theoretic context. In these Aisenstadt lectures I shall describe an approach to fluid mechanics, which is an ancient field theory, but which can be enhanced by the ideas that we gleaned from particle physics.

As an introduction, I shall begin with a review of the classical theory. Mostly, I duplicate what can be found in textbooks, but perhaps the emphasis will be new and different. After this I shall describe how some instances of the classical theory are related to d-branes and how this relation explains some integrability properties of various models. I shall then show how the degrees of freedom can be enlarged to accomodate supersymmetry and non-Abelian structures in fluid mechanics. A few problems are scattered throughout; solutions are given at the end of the text, before the references.

New work that I shall describe here was done in collaboration with D. Bazeia, V.P. Nair, S.-Y. Pi, and A.P. Polychronakos. Textbooks for the classical theory, which I recommend, are by Landau and Lifschitz [1] as well as by Arnold and Khesin [2].

2 Classical Equations

2.1 Equations of motion

We begin with nonrelativistic equations that govern a matter density field ρ(t,r)\rho(t, \boldsymbol{r})ρ(t,r) and a velocity field vector v(t,r)\boldsymbol{v}(t, \boldsymbol{r})v(t,r), taken in any number of dimensions. The equations of motion comprise a continuity equation,

∂∂tρ(t,r)+∇⋅(ρ(t,r)v(t,r))=0\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \rho(t, \boldsymbol{r})+\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\rho(t, \boldsymbol{r}) \boldsymbol{v}(t, \boldsymbol{r}))=0 \tag{1} \end{equation*}∂t∂​ρ(t,r)+∇⋅(ρ(t,r)v(t,r))=0​(1)​

which ensures matter conservation, that is, time independence, of N=∫drρN=\int \mathrm{d} r \rhoN=∫drρ, and Euler's equation, which is the expression of a nonrelativistic force law.

∂∂tv(t,r)+v(t,r)⋅∇v(t,r)=f(t,r)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \boldsymbol{v}(t, \boldsymbol{r})+\boldsymbol{v}(t, \boldsymbol{r}) \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \boldsymbol{v}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\boldsymbol{f}(t, \boldsymbol{r}) \tag{2} \end{equation*}∂t∂​v(t,r)+v(t,r)⋅∇v(t,r)=f(t,r)​(2)​

Here ρv\rho \boldsymbol{v}ρv is the current j\boldsymbol{j}j and f\boldsymbol{f}f is the force. We shall deal with an isentropic fluid, that is, entropy is constant and does not appear in our theory. Also we ignore dissipation and take the force to be given by the pressure P:f=−1ρ∇PP: \boldsymbol{f}=-\frac{1}{\rho} \boldsymbol{\nabla} PP:f=−ρ1​∇P. For isentropic motion PPP is a function only of ρ\rhoρ, so f\boldsymbol{f}f can also be written as −∇V′(ρ)-\boldsymbol{\nabla} V^{\prime}(\rho)−∇V′(ρ) :

f=−1ρ∇P=−∇V′(ρ)\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{f}=-\frac{1}{\rho} \nabla P=-\nabla V^{\prime}(\rho) \tag{3} \end{equation*}f=−ρ1​∇P=−∇V′(ρ)​(3)​

with the dash (also known as "prime") designating the derivative with respect to argument. V′(ρ)V^{\prime}(\rho)V′(ρ) is the enthalpy, ρV′(ρ)−V(ρ)=P(ρ)\rho V^{\prime}(\rho)-V(\rho)=P(\rho)ρV′(ρ)−V(ρ)=P(ρ), and P′(ρ)≡s\sqrt{P^{\prime}(\rho)} \equiv sP′(ρ)​≡s is the speed of sound. (Those familiar with the subject will recognize that I am using an Eulerian rather than a Lagrangian description of a fluid [3].)

The dynamics summarized in (11) and (2) and the definition (3) may be presented as continuity equations for an energy momentum tensor. The energy density E=Too\mathcal{E}=T^{o o}E=Too

E=12ρv2+V(ρ)=Too\begin{equation*} \mathcal{E}=\frac{1}{2} \rho v^{2}+V(\rho)=T^{o o} \tag{4a} \end{equation*}E=21​ρv2+V(ρ)=Too​(4a)​

together with the energy flux

Tjo=ρvj(12v2+V′)\begin{equation*} T^{j o}=\rho v^{j}\left(\frac{1}{2} v^{2}+V^{\prime}\right) \tag{4b} \end{equation*}Tjo=ρvj(21​v2+V′)​(4b)​

obey

∂∂tToo+∂jTjo=0\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial}{\partial t} T^{o o}+\partial_{j} T^{j o}=0 \tag{4c} \end{equation*}∂t∂​Too+∂j​Tjo=0​(4c)​

Similarly the momentum density, which in the nonrelativistic theory coincides with the current,

Pi=ρvi=Toi\begin{equation*} \mathcal{P}^{i}=\rho v^{i}=T^{o i} \tag{5a} \end{equation*}Pi=ρvi=Toi​(5a)​

and the stress tensor TijT^{i j}Tij

Tij=δij(ρV′−V)+ρvivj=δijP+ρvivj\begin{equation*} T^{i j}=\delta^{i j}\left(\rho V^{\prime}-V\right)+\rho v^{i} v^{j}=\delta^{i j} P+\rho v^{i} v^{j} \tag{5b} \end{equation*}Tij=δij(ρV′−V)+ρvivj=δijP+ρvivj​(5b)​

satisfy

∂∂tToi+∂jTji=0\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial}{\partial t} T^{o i}+\partial_{j} T^{j i}=0 \tag{5c} \end{equation*}∂t∂​Toi+∂j​Tji=0​(5c)​

Note that Toi≠TioT^{o i} \neq T^{i o}Toi=Tio because the theory is not Lorentz invariant, but Tij=TjiT^{i j}=T^{j i}Tij=Tji because it is invariant against spatial rotations. [Thus TμνT^{\mu \nu}Tμν is not, properly speaking, a "tensor", but an energy-momentum "complex".]

A simplification occurs for the irrotational case when the vorticity

ωij≡∂ivj−∂jvi\begin{equation*} \omega_{i j} \equiv \partial_{i} v^{j}-\partial_{j} v^{i} \tag{6} \end{equation*}ωij​≡∂i​vj−∂j​vi​(6)​

vanishes. For then the velocity can be given in terms of a velocity potential θ\thetaθ,

v=∇θ\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{v}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta \tag{7} \end{equation*}v=∇θ​(7)​

and equation (2) can be replaced by Bernoulli's equation.

∂θ∂t+v22=−V′(ρ)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial \theta}{\partial t}+\frac{v^{2}}{2}=-V^{\prime}(\rho) \tag{8} \end{equation*}∂t∂θ​+2v2​=−V′(ρ)​(8)​

The gradient of (8) gives (2), with help of (3) and (7).

Problem 1 In the free Schrödinger equation for a unit-mass particle, iℏ∂ψ∂t=−ℏ22∇2ψi \hbar \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial t}=-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2} \nabla^{2} \psiiℏ∂t∂ψ​=−2ℏ2​∇2ψ, set ψ=ρ1/2eiθ/ℏ\psi=\rho^{1 / 2} e^{i \theta / \hbar}ψ=ρ1/2eiθ/ℏ, and separate real and imaginary parts. Show that the resulting equations are like those of fluid mechanics. What is the velocity? Is vorticity supported? What is the force f\boldsymbol{f}f ?

Our equations can be presented in any dimensionality, but we shall mostly consider the cases of three, two, and one spatial dimensions. In the first case, the vorticity is a (pseudo-) vector

ω=∇×v\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{\omega}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{v} \tag{9} \end{equation*}ω=∇×v​(9)​

in the second, it is a (pseudo-)scalar

ω=εij∂ivj\begin{equation*} \omega=\varepsilon^{i j} \partial_{i} v^{j} \tag{10} \end{equation*}ω=εij∂i​vj​(10)​

while the last, lineal case is always simple because there is no vorticity and the velocity can always be written as the derivative (with respect to the single spatial variable) of a potential.

Dynamics of any particular system is most economically presented when a canonical/action formulation is available. To this end we note that the above equations of motion can be obtained by (Poisson) bracketing with the Hamiltonian

H=∫dr(12ρv2+V(ρ))=∫drE∂ρ∂t={H,ρ}∂v∂t={H,v}\begin{gather*} H=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(\frac{1}{2} \rho v^{2}+V(\rho)\right)=\int \mathrm{d} r \mathcal{E} \tag{11}\\ \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}=\{H, \rho\} \tag{12}\\ \frac{\partial \boldsymbol{v}}{\partial t}=\{H, \boldsymbol{v}\} \tag{13} \end{gather*}H=∫dr(21​ρv2+V(ρ))=∫drE∂t∂ρ​={H,ρ}∂t∂v​={H,v}​(11)(12)(13)​

provided the nonvanishing brackets of the fundamental (ρ,v)(\rho, \boldsymbol{v})(ρ,v) variables are taken to be

{vi(r),ρ(r′)}=∂iδ(r−r′){vi(r),vj(r′)}=−ωij(r)ρ(r)δ(r−r′)\begin{align*} \left\{v^{i}(\boldsymbol{r}), \rho\left(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right)\right\} & =\partial_{i} \delta\left(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right) \\ \left\{v^{i}(\boldsymbol{r}), v^{j}\left(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right)\right\} & =-\frac{\omega_{i j}(\boldsymbol{r})}{\rho(\boldsymbol{r})} \delta\left(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right) \tag{14} \end{align*}{vi(r),ρ(r′)}{vi(r),vj(r′)}​=∂i​δ(r−r′)=−ρ(r)ωij​(r)​δ(r−r′)​(14)​

(The fields in curly brackets are at equal times, hence the time argument is suppressed.) An equivalent, more transparent version of the algebra (14) is satisfied by the field momentum density,

P=ρv\begin{equation*} \mathcal{P}=\rho \boldsymbol{v} \tag{15} \end{equation*}P=ρv​(15)​

As a consequence of (14) we have

{Pi(r),ρ(r′)}=ρ(r)∂iδ(r−r′){Pi(r),Pj(r′)}=Pj(r)∂iδ(r−r′)+Pi(r′)∂jδ(r−r′)\begin{align*} \left\{\mathcal{P}^{i}(\boldsymbol{r}), \rho\left(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right)\right\} & =\rho(\boldsymbol{r}) \partial_{i} \delta\left(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right) \\ \left\{\mathcal{P}^{i}(\boldsymbol{r}), \mathcal{P}^{j}\left(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right)\right\} & =\mathcal{P}^{j}(\boldsymbol{r}) \partial_{i} \delta\left(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right)+\mathcal{P}^{i}\left(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right) \partial_{j} \delta\left(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right) \tag{16} \end{align*}{Pi(r),ρ(r′)}{Pi(r),Pj(r′)}​=ρ(r)∂i​δ(r−r′)=Pj(r)∂i​δ(r−r′)+Pi(r′)∂j​δ(r−r′)​(16)​

This is the familiar algebra of momentum densities. One verifies that the Jacobi identity is satisfied (4).

Naturally one asks whether there exists a Lagrangian whose canonical variables lead to the Poisson brackets (14) or (16) and to the Hamiltonian (11). In more mathematical language, we seek a canonical 1-form and a symplectic 2-form that lead to the algebra (14) or (16).

Problem 2 Second-quantized Schrödinger fields satisfy equal-time commutation (anticommutation) relations, when describing bosons (fermions): ⌈ψ(r),ψ∗(r′)⌋±=δ(r−r′)\left\lceil\psi(\boldsymbol{r}), \psi^{*}\left(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right)\right\rfloor_{ \pm}=\delta\left(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right)⌈ψ(r),ψ∗(r′)⌋±​=δ(r−r′). Show that the algebra (16) is reproduced (apart from factors of iℏi \hbariℏ ) when ρ=ψ∗ψ,P=Im⁡ℏψ∗∇ψ\rho=\psi^{*} \psi, \mathcal{P}=\operatorname{Im} \hbar \psi^{*} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psiρ=ψ∗ψ,P=Imℏψ∗∇ψ. Since in the nonrelativistic theory P=j\boldsymbol{\mathcal { P }}=\boldsymbol{j}P=j, find j\boldsymbol{j}j in terms of ρ\rhoρ and v\boldsymbol{v}v, with v\boldsymbol{v}v as determined in Problem 1.

2.2 A word on canonical formulations

I shall now describe an approach to canonical formulations of dynamics, publicized by Faddeev and me [5], which circumvents and simplifies the more elaborate approach of Dirac.

We begin with a Lagrangian that is first order in time. This entails no loss of generality because all second-order Lagrangians can be converted to first order by the familiar Legendre transformation, which produces a Hamiltonian: H(p,q)=pq˙−L(q˙,q)H(p, q)=p \dot{q}-L(\dot{q}, q)H(p,q)=pq˙​−L(q˙​,q), where p≡∂L/∂q˙p \equiv \partial L / \partial \dot{q}p≡∂L/∂q˙​ (the over-dot designates the time derivative). The equations of motion gotten by taking the Euler-Lagrange derivative with respect to ppp and qqq of the Lagrangian L(p˙,p;q˙,q)≡pq˙−L(\dot{p}, p ; \dot{q}, q) \equiv p \dot{q}-L(p˙​,p;q˙​,q)≡pq˙​− H(p,q)H(p, q)H(p,q) coincide with the "usual" equations of motion obtained by taking the qqq Euler-Lagrange derivative of L(q˙,q)L(\dot{q}, q)L(q˙​,q). [In fact L(p˙,p;q˙,q)L(\dot{p}, p ; \dot{q}, q)L(p˙​,p;q˙​,q) does not depend on p˙\dot{p}p˙​.] Moreover, some Lagrangians possess only a first-order formulation (for example, Lagrangians for the Schrödinger or Dirac fields; also the Klein-Gordon Lagrangian in light-cone coordinates is first order in the light-cone "time" derivative).

Denoting all variables by the generic symbol ξi\xi^{i}ξi, the most general first-order Lagrangian is

L=ai(ξ)ξ˙i−H(ξ)\begin{equation*} L=a_{i}(\xi) \dot{\xi}^{i}-H(\xi) \tag{17} \end{equation*}L=ai​(ξ)ξ˙​i−H(ξ)​(17)​

Note that although we shall ultimately be interested in fields defined on space-time, for present didactic purposes it suffices to consider variables ξi(t)\xi^{i}(t)ξi(t) that are functions only of time. The Euler-Lagrange equation that is implied by (17) reads

fij(ξ)ξ˙j=∂H(ξ)∂ξi\begin{equation*} f_{i j}(\xi) \dot{\xi}^{j}=\frac{\partial H(\xi)}{\partial \xi^{i}} \tag{18} \end{equation*}fij​(ξ)ξ˙​j=∂ξi∂H(ξ)​​(18)​

where

fij(ξ)=∂aj(ξ)∂ξi−∂ai(ξ)∂ξj.\begin{equation*} f_{i j}(\xi)=\frac{\partial a_{j}(\xi)}{\partial \xi^{i}}-\frac{\partial a_{i}(\xi)}{\partial \xi^{j}} . \tag{19} \end{equation*}fij​(ξ)=∂ξi∂aj​(ξ)​−∂ξj∂ai​(ξ)​.​(19)​

The first term in (17) determines the canonical 1-form: ai(ξ)ξ˙i dt=ai(ξ)dξia_{i}(\xi) \dot{\xi}^{i} \mathrm{~d} t=a_{i}(\xi) \mathrm{d} \xi^{i}ai​(ξ)ξ˙​i dt=ai​(ξ)dξi, while fijf_{i j}fij​ gives the symplectic 2-form: dai(ξ)dξi=12fij(ξ)dξi dξj\mathrm{d} a_{i}(\xi) \mathrm{d} \xi^{i}=\frac{1}{2} f_{i j}(\xi) \mathrm{d} \xi^{i} \mathrm{~d} \xi^{j}dai​(ξ)dξi=21​fij​(ξ)dξi dξj.

To set up a canonical formalism, we proceed directly. We do not make the frequently heard statement that "the canonical momenta ∂L/∂ξ˙i=ai(ξ)\partial L / \partial \dot{\xi}^{i}=a_{i}(\xi)∂L/∂ξ˙​i=ai​(ξ) are constrained to depend on the coordinates ξ\xiξ ", and we do not embark on Dirac's method for constrained systems.

In fact, if the matrix fijf_{i j}fij​ possesses the inverse fijf^{i j}fij there are no constraints. Then (18) implies

ξ˙i=fij(ξ)∂H(ξ)∂ξj\begin{equation*} \dot{\xi}^{i}=f^{i j}(\xi) \frac{\partial H(\xi)}{\partial \xi^{j}} \tag{20} \end{equation*}ξ˙​i=fij(ξ)∂ξj∂H(ξ)​​(20)​

When one wants to express this equation of motion by bracketing with the Hamiltonian

ξ˙i={H(ξ),ξi}={ξj,ξi}∂H(ξ)∂ξj\begin{equation*} \dot{\xi}^{i}=\left\{H(\xi), \xi^{i}\right\}=\left\{\xi^{j}, \xi^{i}\right\} \frac{\partial H(\xi)}{\partial \xi^{j}} \tag{21} \end{equation*}ξ˙​i={H(ξ),ξi}={ξj,ξi}∂ξj∂H(ξ)​​(21)​

one is directly led to postulating the fundamental bracket as

{ξi,ξj}=−fij(ξ)\begin{equation*} \left\{\xi^{i}, \xi^{j}\right\}=-f^{i j}(\xi) \tag{22} \end{equation*}{ξi,ξj}=−fij(ξ)​(22)​

The Poisson bracket between functions of ξ\xiξ is then defined by

{F1(ξ),F2(ξ)}=−∂F1(ξ)∂ξifij∂F2(ξ)∂ξj.\begin{equation*} \left\{F_{1}(\xi), F_{2}(\xi)\right\}=-\frac{\partial F_{1}(\xi)}{\partial \xi^{i}} f^{i j} \frac{\partial F_{2}(\xi)}{\partial \xi^{j}} . \tag{23} \end{equation*}{F1​(ξ),F2​(ξ)}=−∂ξi∂F1​(ξ)​fij∂ξj∂F2​(ξ)​.​(23)​

One verifies that (22) satisfies Jacobi identity by virtue of (19). When fijf_{i j}fij​ is singular and has no inverse, constraints do arise, and the development becomes more complicated (see [5]).

Our problem in connection with (14) and (16) is in fact the inverse of what I have here summarized. From (14) and (16), we know the form of fijf^{i j}fij and that the Jacobi identity holds. We then wish to determine the inverse fijf_{i j}fij​, and also aia_{i}ai​ from (19). Since we know the Hamiltonian from (11), construction of the Lagrangian (17) should follow immediately.

However, an obstacle may arise: If there exists a quantity C(ξ)C(\xi)C(ξ) whose Poisson bracket with all the ξi\xi^{i}ξi vanishes, then

0={ξi,C(ξ)}=−fij∂∂ξjC(ξ)\begin{equation*} 0=\left\{\xi^{i}, C(\xi)\right\}=-f^{i j} \frac{\partial}{\partial \xi^{j}} C(\xi) \tag{24} \end{equation*}0={ξi,C(ξ)}=−fij∂ξj∂​C(ξ)​(24)​

That is, fijf^{i j}fij has the zero mode ∂∂ξjC(ξ)\frac{\partial}{\partial \xi^{j}} C(\xi)∂ξj∂​C(ξ), and the inverse to fijf^{i j}fij, namely the symplectic 2 -form fijf_{i j}fij​, does not exist. In that case, something more has to be done, and we shall come back to this problem.

Totally commuting quantities like C(ξ)C(\xi)C(ξ) are called "Casimir invariants". Since they Poissoncommute with all the dynamical variables, they commute with the Hamiltonian, and are constants of motion. But these constants do not reflect any symmetry of the specific Hamiltonian, nor do they generate any infinitesimal transformation on ξi\xi^{i}ξi, since the {C(ξ),ξi}\left\{C(\xi), \xi^{i}\right\}{C(ξ),ξi} bracket vanishes.

As will be demonstrated below, the algebra (14), (16) admits Casimir invariants, which create an obstruction to the construction of a canonical formalism for fluid mechanics; this obstruction must be overcome to make progress. (In the Lagrangian formulation of fluid mechanics these Casimirs are related to a parameterization-invariance of that formalism [3].)

2.3 The irrotational case

We now return to the specific issue of determining the fluid dynamical Lagrangian. The problem of constructing a Lagrangian which leads to (14) and (16) can be solved by inspection for the irrotational case, with vanishing vorticity [see (6)]. For then the velocity commutator in (14) vanishes and (7) shows that the first equation in (14) can be satisfied by taking ρ\rhoρ and θ\thetaθ to be canonically conjugate.

{θ(r),ρ(r′)}=δ(r−r′)\begin{equation*} \left\{\theta(\boldsymbol{r}), \rho\left(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right)\right\}=\delta\left(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right) \tag{25} \end{equation*}{θ(r),ρ(r′)}=δ(r−r′)​(25)​

Thus the Lagrangian reads

Lirrotational =∫dr(θρ˙−Hv=∇θ)\begin{equation*} L_{\text {irrotational }}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(\theta \dot{\rho}-H_{\boldsymbol{v}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta}\right) \tag{26} \end{equation*}Lirrotational ​=∫dr(θρ˙​−Hv=∇θ​)​(26)​

where HHH is given by (11) with v\boldsymbol{v}v taken as in (7). The form of this Lagrangian can be understood by the following argument, due to C. Eckart [6].

Consider the Lagragian for NNN point-particles in free nonrelativistic motion. With the mass mmm set to unity, the Galileo-invariant, free Lagrangian is just the kinetic energy.

L0=12∑n=1Nvn2(t)\begin{equation*} L_{0}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{n=1}^{N} v_{n}^{2}(t) \tag{27} \end{equation*}L0​=21​n=1∑N​vn2​(t)​(27)​

In a continuum description, the particle-counting index nnn becomes the continuous variable r\boldsymbol{r}r, and the particles are distributed with density ρ\rhoρ, so that ∑n=1Nvn2(t)\sum_{n=1}^{N} v_{n}^{2}(t)∑n=1N​vn2​(t) becomes ∫drρ(t,r)v2(t,r)\int \mathrm{d} r \rho(t, \boldsymbol{r}) v^{2}(t, \boldsymbol{r})∫drρ(t,r)v2(t,r). But we also need to link the density with the current j=ρv\boldsymbol{j}=\rho \boldsymbol{v}j=ρv, so that the continuity equation holds. This can be enforced with the help of a Lagrange multiplier θ\thetaθ. We thus arrive at the free, continuum Lagrangian.

Lˉ0Galileo =∫dr(12ρv2+θ(ρ˙+∇⋅(ρv)))\begin{equation*} \bar{L}_{0}^{\text {Galileo }}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(\frac{1}{2} \rho v^{2}+\theta(\dot{\rho}+\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\rho \boldsymbol{v}))\right) \tag{28} \end{equation*}Lˉ0Galileo ​=∫dr(21​ρv2+θ(ρ˙​+∇⋅(ρv)))​(28)​

Since Lˉ0Galileo \bar{L}_{0}^{\text {Galileo }}Lˉ0Galileo ​ is first order in time and the canonical 1-form ∫drθρ˙\int \mathrm{d} r \theta \dot{\rho}∫drθρ˙​ does not contain v\boldsymbol{v}v, the latter may be varied, evaluated, and eliminated (5). Doing this, we find

ρv−ρ∇θ=0\begin{equation*} \rho \boldsymbol{v}-\rho \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta=0 \tag{29} \end{equation*}ρv−ρ∇θ=0​(29)​

and we conclude that ∇θ\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta∇θ is the velocity or, more precisely, that ∇θ\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta∇θ is the v\boldsymbol{v}v derivative of the kinetic energy, that is, the momentum p\boldsymbol{p}p, which in this nonrelativistic setting coincides with v\boldsymbol{v}v.

∇θ=∂∂v12v2≡p=v\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta=\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{v}} \frac{1}{2} v^{2} \equiv \boldsymbol{p}=\boldsymbol{v} \tag{30} \end{equation*}∇θ=∂v∂​21​v2≡p=v​(30)​

Substituting this in (28), we obtain

L0Galileo =∫dr(θρ˙−12ρ(∇θ)2)\begin{equation*} L_{0}^{\text {Galileo }}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(\theta \dot{\rho}-\frac{1}{2} \rho(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}\right) \tag{31} \end{equation*}L0Galileo ​=∫dr(θρ˙​−21​ρ(∇θ)2)​(31)​

which reproduces (26) with the interaction V(ρ)V(\rho)V(ρ) in (11) set to zero, and leads to the free version of the Bernoulli equation of motion ( 8 ).

θ˙+(∇θ)22=0\begin{equation*} \dot{\theta}+\frac{(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}}{2}=0 \tag{32} \end{equation*}θ˙+2(∇θ)2​=0​(32)​

Taking the gradient gives

v˙+v⋅∇v=0\begin{equation*} \dot{\boldsymbol{v}}+\boldsymbol{v} \cdot \nabla \boldsymbol{v}=0 \tag{33} \end{equation*}v˙+v⋅∇v=0​(33)​

Problem 3 The Lagrange density for the unit-mass Schrödinger equation can be taken as LSchro¨dinger =iℏψ∗∂∂tψ−ℏ22m∇ψ∗⋅∇ψ\mathcal{L}_{\text {Schrödinger }}=i \hbar \psi^{*} \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \psi-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi^{*} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psiLSchro¨dinger ​=iℏψ∗∂t∂​ψ−2mℏ2​∇ψ∗⋅∇ψ. What form does this take after ψ\psiψ is represented by ρ1/2eiθ/ℏ\rho^{1 / 2} e^{i \theta / \hbar}ρ1/2eiθ/ℏ ? Compare with (26).

Remarkably, the same equation (33) emerges for a kinetic energy T(v)T(\boldsymbol{v})T(v) that is an arbitrary function of v\boldsymbol{v}v. This will be useful for us when we study a relativistic generalization of the theory. If we replace (28) by

Lˉ0=∫dr(ρT(v)+θ(ρ˙+∇⋅(ρv)))\begin{equation*} \bar{L}_{0}=\int \mathrm{d} r(\rho T(\boldsymbol{v})+\theta(\dot{\rho}+\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\rho \boldsymbol{v}))) \tag{34} \end{equation*}Lˉ0​=∫dr(ρT(v)+θ(ρ˙​+∇⋅(ρv)))​(34)​

and vary v\boldsymbol{v}v to eliminate it, we get in a generalization of (30)

∇θ=∂T∂v≡p\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta=\frac{\partial T}{\partial \boldsymbol{v}} \equiv \boldsymbol{p} \tag{35} \end{equation*}∇θ=∂v∂T​≡p​(35)​

So in the general case, it is the momentum - the v\boldsymbol{v}v derivative of T(v)T(\boldsymbol{v})T(v) - that is irrotational. The Lagrange density becomes

L0=∫dr(θρ˙−ρh(p)p=∇θ)\begin{equation*} L_{0}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(\theta \dot{\rho}-\rho h(\boldsymbol{p})_{\boldsymbol{p}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta}\right) \tag{36} \end{equation*}L0​=∫dr(θρ˙​−ρh(p)p=∇θ​)​(36)​

where h(p)h(\boldsymbol{p})h(p) is the Legendre transform of T(v)T(\boldsymbol{v})T(v).

h(p)=v⋅p−T(v)∂h∂p=v\begin{equation*} h(\boldsymbol{p})=\boldsymbol{v} \cdot \boldsymbol{p}-T(\boldsymbol{v}) \quad \frac{\partial h}{\partial \boldsymbol{p}}=\boldsymbol{v} \tag{37} \end{equation*}h(p)=v⋅p−T(v)∂p∂h​=v​(37)​

Again varying θ\thetaθ in (36) gives the continuity equation

0=δL0δθ=ρ˙−∫drρ∂h(p)∂p⋅δpδθ=ρ˙−∫drρv⋅δδθ∇θ=ρ˙+∇⋅(ρv)\begin{align*} 0=\frac{\delta L_{0}}{\delta \theta} & =\dot{\rho}-\int \mathrm{d} r \rho \frac{\partial h(\boldsymbol{p})}{\partial \boldsymbol{p}} \cdot \frac{\delta \boldsymbol{p}}{\delta \theta} \\ & =\dot{\rho}-\int \mathrm{d} r \rho \boldsymbol{v} \cdot \frac{\delta}{\delta \theta} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta \\ & =\dot{\rho}+\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\rho \boldsymbol{v}) \tag{38} \end{align*}0=δθδL0​​​=ρ˙​−∫drρ∂p∂h(p)​⋅δθδp​=ρ˙​−∫drρv⋅δθδ​∇θ=ρ˙​+∇⋅(ρv)​(38)​

Varying ρ\rhoρ gives

0=δL0δρ=−θ˙−h(p)\begin{equation*} 0=\frac{\delta L_{0}}{\delta \rho}=-\dot{\theta}-h(\boldsymbol{p}) \tag{39} \end{equation*}0=δρδL0​​=−θ˙−h(p)​(39)​

Taking the gradient, this implies with the help of (35)

∂iθ˙=−v⋅∂∂rip=−vj∂∂rjpi=−vj∂pi∂vk∂∂rjvk\begin{align*} \partial_{i} \dot{\theta} & =-\boldsymbol{v} \cdot \frac{\partial}{\partial r^{i}} \boldsymbol{p} \\ & =-v^{j} \frac{\partial}{\partial r^{j}} p^{i} \\ & =-v^{j} \frac{\partial p^{i}}{\partial v^{k}} \frac{\partial}{\partial r^{j}} v^{k} \tag{40} \end{align*}∂i​θ˙​=−v⋅∂ri∂​p=−vj∂rj∂​pi=−vj∂vk∂pi​∂rj∂​vk​(40)​

On the other hand, (35) implies that

∂iθ˙=∂pi∂vkv˙k\begin{equation*} \partial_{i} \dot{\theta}=\frac{\partial p^{i}}{\partial v^{k}} \dot{v}^{k} \tag{41} \end{equation*}∂i​θ˙=∂vk∂pi​v˙k​(41)​

The two are consistent, provided the free Euler equation holds, that is,

v˙k+vj∂jvk=0\begin{equation*} \dot{v}^{k}+v^{j} \partial_{j} v^{k}=0 \tag{42} \end{equation*}v˙k+vj∂j​vk=0​(42)​

(as long as ∂pi/∂vk=∂2T/∂vi∂vk\partial p^{i} / \partial v^{k}=\partial^{2} T / \partial v^{i} \partial v^{k}∂pi/∂vk=∂2T/∂vi∂vk has an inverse). Let me observe that free motion is here governed by a Lagrangian that is not quadratic and the free equations are not linear. Nevertheless, the equations of motion (38) and (42) can be solved in terms of initial data.

ρ(t=0,r)≡ρ0(r)v(t=0,r)≡v0(r)\begin{align*} \rho(t=0, \boldsymbol{r}) & \equiv \rho_{0}(\boldsymbol{r}) \tag{43}\\ \boldsymbol{v}(t=0, \boldsymbol{r}) & \equiv \boldsymbol{v}_{0}(\boldsymbol{r}) \tag{44} \end{align*}ρ(t=0,r)v(t=0,r)​≡ρ0​(r)≡v0​(r)​(43)(44)​

Upon determining the retarded position q(t,r)\boldsymbol{q}(t, \boldsymbol{r})q(t,r) from the equation

q+tv0(q)=r\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{q}+t \boldsymbol{v}_{0}(\boldsymbol{q})=\boldsymbol{r} \tag{45} \end{equation*}q+tv0​(q)=r​(45)​

one verifies that the solution to the free equations reads

v(t,r)=v0(q)ρ(t,r)=ρ0(q)∣det⁡∂qi∂rj∣\begin{align*} \boldsymbol{v}(t, \boldsymbol{r}) & =\boldsymbol{v}_{0}(\boldsymbol{q}) \tag{46}\\ \rho(t, \boldsymbol{r}) & =\rho_{0}(\boldsymbol{q})\left|\operatorname{det} \frac{\partial q^{i}}{\partial r^{j}}\right| \tag{47} \end{align*}v(t,r)ρ(t,r)​=v0​(q)=ρ0​(q)​det∂rj∂qi​​​(46)(47)​

A final remark: Note that the free Bernoulli equation (8) coincides with the free HamiltonJacobi equation for the action.

2.4 Nonvanishing vorticity and the Clebsch parameterization

We now return to our original Galileo-invariant problem and enquire about the Lagrangian for velocity fields that are not irrotational, that is, whose vorticity is nonvanishing. Here we specify the spatial dimensionality to be 3 , and observe that the algebra (14) possesses a zero mode, since the quantity

C(v)≡∫drεijkvi∂jvk=∫drv⋅ω\begin{equation*} C(\boldsymbol{v}) \equiv \int \mathrm{d} r \varepsilon^{i j k} v^{i} \partial_{j} v^{k}=\int \mathrm{d} r \boldsymbol{v} \cdot \boldsymbol{\omega} \tag{48} \end{equation*}C(v)≡∫drεijkvi∂j​vk=∫drv⋅ω​(48)​

(Poisson) commutes with both ρ\rhoρ and v\boldsymbol{v}v. So the symplectic 2 -form does not exist: in the language developed above, fijf^{i j}fij has no inverse. (Notice that CCC, also called the "fluid helicity", coincides with the Abelian Chern-Simons term for v\boldsymbol{v}v [7.) (In the irrotational case with vanishing ω\boldsymbol{\omega}ω, the obstacle obviously is absent.)

To make progress, one must neuteralize the obstruction. This is achieved in the following manner, as was shown by C.C. Lin [8].

We use the Clebsch parameterization for the vector field v\boldsymbol{v}v. Any three-dimensional vector, which involves three functions, can be presented as

v=∇θ+α∇β\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{v}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta+\alpha \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta \tag{49} \end{equation*}v=∇θ+α∇β​(49)​

with three suitably chosen scalar functions θ,α\theta, \alphaθ,α, and β\betaβ. This is called the "Clebsch parameterization", and (α,β)(\alpha, \beta)(α,β) are called "Gaussian potentials" 9]. In this parameterization, the vorticity reads

ω=∇α×∇β\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{\omega}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \alpha \times \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta \tag{50} \end{equation*}ω=∇α×∇β​(50)​

and the Lagrangian is taken as

L=−∫drρ(θ˙+αβ˙)−Hv=∇θ+α∇β\begin{equation*} L=-\int \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{r} \rho(\dot{\theta}+\alpha \dot{\beta})-H_{\boldsymbol{v}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta+\alpha \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta} \tag{51} \end{equation*}L=−∫drρ(θ˙+αβ˙​)−Hv=∇θ+α∇β​​(51)​

with v\boldsymbol{v}v in HHH expressed as in (49). Thus (ρ,θ)(\rho, \theta)(ρ,θ) remain canonically conjugate but another canonical pair appears: (ρα,β)(\rho \alpha, \beta)(ρα,β). The phase space is 4 -dimensional, corresponding to the four observables ρ\rhoρ and v\boldsymbol{v}v, and a straightforward calculation shows that the Poisson brackets (14) are reproduced, with v\boldsymbol{v}v constructed by (49).

But how has the obstacle been overcome? Let us observe that in the Clebsch parameterization CCC is given by

C=∫drεijk∂iθ∂jα∂kβ\begin{equation*} C=\int \mathrm{d} r \varepsilon^{i j k} \partial_{i} \theta \partial_{j} \alpha \partial_{k} \beta \tag{52} \end{equation*}C=∫drεijk∂i​θ∂j​α∂k​β​(52)​

which is just a surface integral

C=∫dS⋅(θω)\begin{equation*} C=\int \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{S} \cdot(\theta \boldsymbol{\omega}) \tag{53} \end{equation*}C=∫dS⋅(θω)​(53)​

In this form, CCC has no bulk contribution, and presents no obstacle to constructing a symplectic 2 -form and a canonical 1 -form in terms of θ,α\theta, \alphaθ,α and β\betaβ, which are defined in the bulk, that is, for all finite r\boldsymbol{r}r.

Lin gave an Eckart-type derivation of (51): Return to Lˉ0Galileo \bar{L}_{0}^{\text {Galileo }}Lˉ0Galileo ​ in (28) and add a further constraint, beyond the one enforcing current conservation [8].

Lˉ0Galileo =∫dr(12ρv2+θ(ρ˙+∇⋅(ρv))−ρα(β˙+v⋅∇β))\begin{equation*} \bar{L}_{0}^{\text {Galileo }}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(\frac{1}{2} \rho v^{2}+\theta(\dot{\rho}+\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\rho \boldsymbol{v}))-\rho \alpha(\dot{\beta}+\boldsymbol{v} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta)\right) \tag{54} \end{equation*}Lˉ0Galileo ​=∫dr(21​ρv2+θ(ρ˙​+∇⋅(ρv))−ρα(β˙​+v⋅∇β))​(54)​

Setting the variation (with respect to v\boldsymbol{v}v ) to zero evaluates v\boldsymbol{v}v as in (49); eliminating v\boldsymbol{v}v from (54) gives rise to (51).

This procedure works in any number of dimensions, producing the same canonical 1-form in any dimension. This means that in two spatial dimensions, on the plane, where the (ρ,v)(\rho, \boldsymbol{v})(ρ,v) space is three-dimensional, the four-dimensional phase space (ρ,θ;ρα,β)(\rho, \theta ; \rho \alpha, \beta)(ρ,θ;ρα,β) is larger. Moreover, the analog to CCC in two spatial dimensions, that is, the obstruction to constructing a symplectic 2 -form, is not a single quantity: an infinite number of objects (Poisson) commute with ρ\rhoρ and v\boldsymbol{v}v. These are

Cn=∫drρ(ωρ)nn=0,±1,±2,…\begin{equation*} C_{n}=\int \mathrm{d} r \rho\left(\frac{\omega}{\rho}\right)^{n} \quad n=0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots \tag{55} \end{equation*}Cn​=∫drρ(ρω​)nn=0,±1,±2,…​(55)​

(Of course, the CnC_{n}Cn​ vanish in the irrotational case where there is no obstruction.) One can understand why there is an infinite number of obstructions by observing that phase space must be even dimensional, but (ρ,v)(\rho, \boldsymbol{v})(ρ,v) comprise three quantities on the plane. So a nonsingular symplectic form can be constructed either by increasing the number of canonical variables to four, or decreasing to two. The Lin/Clebsch method increases the variables. On the other hand, decreasing to two entails suppressing of one continuous and local degree of freedom, and evidently this is equivalent to neutralizing the infinite number of global obstructions, namely, the CnC_{n}Cn​. But I do not know how to effect such a suppression, so I remain with (51).

Note that Lˉ0Galileo \bar{L}_{0}^{\text {Galileo }}Lˉ0Galileo ​ in (54), apart from a total time derivative, can also be written in any number of dimensions as

Lˉ0Galileo =∫dr(ρT(v)−ρ(θ˙+αβ˙)−ρv⋅(∇θ+α∇β))=∫dr(ρT(v)−jμ(∂μθ+α∂μβ))\begin{align*} \bar{L}_{0}^{\text {Galileo }} & =\int \mathrm{d} r(\rho T(\boldsymbol{v})-\rho(\dot{\theta}+\alpha \dot{\beta})-\rho \boldsymbol{v} \cdot(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta+\alpha \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta)) \\ & =\int \mathrm{d} r\left(\rho T(\boldsymbol{v})-j^{\mu}\left(\partial_{\mu} \theta+\alpha \partial_{\mu} \beta\right)\right) \tag{56} \end{align*}Lˉ0Galileo ​​=∫dr(ρT(v)−ρ(θ˙+αβ˙​)−ρv⋅(∇θ+α∇β))=∫dr(ρT(v)−jμ(∂μ​θ+α∂μ​β))​(56)​

where we have introduced the current four-vector

jμ=(cρ,ρv),\begin{equation*} j^{\mu}=(c \rho, \rho \boldsymbol{v}), \tag{57} \end{equation*}jμ=(cρ,ρv),​(57)​

employed the four-vector gradient ∂μ=(1c∂∂t,∇)\partial_{\mu}=\left(\frac{1}{c} \frac{\partial}{\partial t}, \boldsymbol{\nabla}\right)∂μ​=(c1​∂t∂​,∇), and denoted the kinetic energy by T(v)T(\boldsymbol{v})T(v). These expressions will form our starting point for a relativistic generalization of the theory as well as a non-Abelian generalization. (That is why we have introduced the velocity of light in the above definitions; of course ccc disappears in the Galilean theory, as it has no role there.)

Finally we observed that in one spatial dimension, where vvv can always be written as θ′\theta^{\prime}θ′ and the vorticity vanishes, the irrotational canonical 1-form ∫dxθρ˙\int \mathrm{d} x \theta \dot{\rho}∫dxθρ˙​ is generally applicable and can equivalently be written as −12∫ dx dyρ(x)ε(x−y)v˙(y)-\frac{1}{2} \int \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} y \rho(x) \varepsilon(x-y) \dot{v}(y)−21​∫ dx dyρ(x)ε(x−y)v˙(y), where ε\varepsilonε is a ±1\pm 1±1-step function, determined by the sign of its argument. Evidently this leads to a spatially nonlocal, but otherwise completely satisfactory canonical formulation of fluid motion on a line.

2.5 Some further remarks on the Clebsch parameterization

Let me elaborate on the Clebsch parameterization for a vector field, which was presented for the velocity vector in (49). Here I shall use the notation of electromagnetism and discuss the Clebsch parameterization of a vector potential A\boldsymbol{A}A, which also leads to the magnetic field B=∇×A\boldsymbol{B}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{A}B=∇×A. (Of course the same observations apply when the vector in question is the velocity field v\boldsymbol{v}v, with ∇×v\boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{v}∇×v giving the vorticity.)

The familiar parameterization of a three-component vector employs a scalar function θ\thetaθ (the "gauge" or "longitudinal" part) and a two-component transverse vector AT:A=∇θ+AT\boldsymbol{A}_{T}: \boldsymbol{A}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta+\boldsymbol{A}_{T}AT​:A=∇θ+AT​, ∇⋅AT=0\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \boldsymbol{A}_{T}=0∇⋅AT​=0. This decomposition is unique and invertible (on a space with simple topology). In contrast, the Clebsch parameterization uses three scalar functions, θ,α\theta, \alphaθ,α, and β\betaβ,

A=∇θ+α∇β\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{A}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta+\alpha \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta \tag{58} \end{equation*}A=∇θ+α∇β​(58)​

which are not uniquely determined by A\boldsymbol{A}A (see below). The associated magnetic field reads

B=∇α×∇β\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{B}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \alpha \times \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta \tag{59} \end{equation*}B=∇α×∇β​(59)​

Repeating the above in form notation, the 1-form A=Ai driA=A_{i} \mathrm{~d} r^{i}A=Ai​ dri is presented as

A=dθ+αdβ\begin{equation*} A=\mathrm{d} \theta+\alpha \mathrm{d} \beta \tag{60} \end{equation*}A=dθ+αdβ​(60)​

and the 2 -form is

dA=dα dβ.\begin{equation*} \mathrm{d} A=\mathrm{d} \alpha \mathrm{~d} \beta . \tag{61} \end{equation*}dA=dα dβ.​(61)​

Darboux's theorem ensures that the Clebsch parameterization is attainable locally in space [in the form (60)] 10]. Additionally, an explicit construction of α,β\alpha, \betaα,β, and θ\thetaθ can be given by the following (11.

Solve the equations

dxBx=dyBy=dzBz\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{B_{x}}=\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{B_{y}}=\frac{\mathrm{d} z}{B_{z}} \tag{62a} \end{equation*}Bx​dx​=By​dy​=Bz​dz​​(62a)​

which may also be presented as

εijk drjBk=0\begin{equation*} \varepsilon^{i j k} \mathrm{~d} r^{j} B^{k}=0 \tag{62b} \end{equation*}εijk drjBk=0​(62b)​

Solutions of these relations define two surfaces, called "magnetic surfaces", that are given by equations of the form

Sn(r)= constant (n=1,2).\begin{equation*} S_{n}(\boldsymbol{r})=\text { constant } \quad(n=1,2) . \tag{63} \end{equation*}Sn​(r)= constant (n=1,2).​(63)​

It follows from (62) that these also satisfy

B⋅∇Sn=0(n=1,2)\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{B} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} S_{n}=0 \quad(n=1,2) \tag{64} \end{equation*}B⋅∇Sn​=0(n=1,2)​(64)​

that is, the normals to SnS_{n}Sn​ are orthogonal to B\boldsymbol{B}B, or B\boldsymbol{B}B is parallel to the tangent of SnS_{n}Sn​. The intersection of the two surfaces forms the so-called "magnetic lines", that is, loci that solve the dynamical system

dr(τ)dτ=B(r(τ))\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{r}(\tau)}{\mathrm{d} \tau}=\boldsymbol{B}(\boldsymbol{r}(\tau)) \tag{65} \end{equation*}dτdr(τ)​=B(r(τ))​(65)​

where τ\tauτ is an evolution parameter. Finally, the Gaussian potentials α\alphaα and β\betaβ are constructed as functions of r\boldsymbol{r}r only through a dependence on the magnetic surfaces,

α(r)=α(Sn(r))β(r)=β(Sn(r))\begin{align*} & \alpha(\boldsymbol{r})=\alpha\left(S_{n}(\boldsymbol{r})\right) \\ & \beta(\boldsymbol{r})=\beta\left(S_{n}(\boldsymbol{r})\right) \tag{66} \end{align*}​α(r)=α(Sn​(r))β(r)=β(Sn​(r))​(66)​

so that

∇α×∇β=(∇S1×∇S2)εmn∂α∂Sm∂β∂Sn.\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \alpha \times \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta=\left(\boldsymbol{\nabla} S_{1} \times \boldsymbol{\nabla} S_{2}\right) \varepsilon^{m n} \frac{\partial \alpha}{\partial S_{m}} \frac{\partial \beta}{\partial S_{n}} . \tag{67} \end{equation*}∇α×∇β=(∇S1​×∇S2​)εmn∂Sm​∂α​∂Sn​∂β​.​(67)​

Evidently as a consequence of (64), ∇α×∇β\boldsymbol{\nabla} \alpha \times \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta∇α×∇β in (67) is parallel to B\boldsymbol{B}B, and because B\boldsymbol{B}B is divergence-free α\alphaα and β\betaβ can be adjusted so that the norm of ∇α×∇β\boldsymbol{\nabla} \alpha \times \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta∇α×∇β coincides with ∣B∣|\boldsymbol{B}|∣B∣. Once α\alphaα and β\betaβ have been fixed in this way, θ\thetaθ can easily be computed from A−α∇β\boldsymbol{A}-\alpha \boldsymbol{\nabla} \betaA−α∇β.

Neither the individual magnetic surfaces nor the Gauss potentials are unique. [By viewing AAA as a canonical 1-form, it is clear that the expression (60) retains its form after a canonical transformation of α,β\alpha, \betaα,β.] One may therefore require that the Gaussian potentials α\alphaα and β\betaβ simply coincide with the two magnetic surfaces: α=S1,β=S2\alpha=S_{1}, \beta=S_{2}α=S1​,β=S2​. Nevertheless, for a given A\boldsymbol{A}A and B\boldsymbol{B}B it may not be possible to solve (62) explicitly.

The Chern-Simons integrand A⋅B\boldsymbol{A} \cdot \boldsymbol{B}A⋅B becomes in the Clebsch parameterization

A⋅B=∇θ⋅(∇α×∇β)=∇⋅(θB)=B⋅∇θ\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{A} \cdot \boldsymbol{B}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta \cdot(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \alpha \times \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta)=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\theta \boldsymbol{B})=\boldsymbol{B} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta \tag{68} \end{equation*}A⋅B=∇θ⋅(∇α×∇β)=∇⋅(θB)=B⋅∇θ​(68)​

Thus having identified the Gauss potentials α\alphaα and β\betaβ with the two magnetic surfaces, we deduce from (64) and (68) three equations for the three functions (θ,α,β)(\theta, \alpha, \beta)(θ,α,β) that comprise the Clebsch parameterization.

B⋅∇α=B⋅∇β=0B⋅∇θ= Chern-Simons density A⋅B\begin{align*} \boldsymbol{B} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \alpha & =\boldsymbol{B} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta=0 \\ \boldsymbol{B} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta & =\text { Chern-Simons density } \boldsymbol{A} \cdot \boldsymbol{B} \tag{69} \end{align*}B⋅∇αB⋅∇θ​=B⋅∇β=0= Chern-Simons density A⋅B​(69)​

Eq. (68) also shows that in the Clebsch parameterization the Chern-Simons density becomes a total derivative.

A⋅B=∇⋅(θB)\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{A} \cdot \boldsymbol{B}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\theta \boldsymbol{B}) \tag{70} \end{equation*}A⋅B=∇⋅(θB)​(70)​

This does not mean that the Clebsch parameterization is unavailable when the Chern-Simons integral over all space is nonzero. Rather for a nonvanishing integral and well-behaved B\boldsymbol{B}B field, one must conclude that the Clebsch function θ\thetaθ is singular either in the finite volume of the integration region or on the surface at infinity bounding the integration domain. Then the Chern-Simons volume integral over (Ω)(\Omega)(Ω) becomes a surface integral on the surfaces ( ∂Ω\partial \Omega∂Ω ) bounding the singularities.

∫ΩdrA⋅B=∫∂ΩdS⋅(θB)\begin{equation*} \int_{\Omega} \mathrm{d} r \boldsymbol{A} \cdot \boldsymbol{B}=\int_{\partial \Omega} \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{S} \cdot(\theta \boldsymbol{B}) \tag{71} \end{equation*}∫Ω​drA⋅B=∫∂Ω​dS⋅(θB)​(71)​

Eq. (71) shows that the Chern-Simons integral measures the magnetic flux, modulated by θ\thetaθ and passing through the surfaces that surround the singularities of θ\thetaθ.

The following explicit example illustrates the above points. Consider the vector potential whose spherical components are given by

Ar=(cos⁡Θ)a′(r)AΘ=−(sin⁡Θ)1rsin⁡a(r)AΦ=−(sin⁡Θ)1r(1−cos⁡a(r))\begin{align*} A_{r} & =(\cos \Theta) a^{\prime}(r) \\ A_{\Theta} & =-(\sin \Theta) \frac{1}{r} \sin a(r) \\ A_{\Phi} & =-(\sin \Theta) \frac{1}{r}(1-\cos a(r)) \tag{72} \end{align*}Ar​AΘ​AΦ​​=(cosΘ)a′(r)=−(sinΘ)r1​sina(r)=−(sinΘ)r1​(1−cosa(r))​(72)​

( rrr, and Θ,Φ\Theta, \PhiΘ,Φ denote the conventional radial coordinate and the polar, azimuthal angles.) The function a(r)a(r)a(r) is taken to vanish at the origin, and to behave as 2πν2 \pi \nu2πν at infinity ( ν\nuν integer or half-integer). The corresponding magnetic field reads

Br=−2(cos⁡Θ)1r2(1−cos⁡a(r))BΘ=(sin⁡Θ)1ra′(r)sin⁡a(r)BΦ=(sin⁡Θ)1ra′(r)(1−cos⁡a(r))\begin{align*} B_{r} & =-2(\cos \Theta) \frac{1}{r^{2}}(1-\cos a(r)) \\ B_{\Theta} & =(\sin \Theta) \frac{1}{r} a^{\prime}(r) \sin a(r) \\ B_{\Phi} & =(\sin \Theta) \frac{1}{r} a^{\prime}(r)(1-\cos a(r)) \tag{73} \end{align*}Br​BΘ​BΦ​​=−2(cosΘ)r21​(1−cosa(r))=(sinΘ)r1​a′(r)sina(r)=(sinΘ)r1​a′(r)(1−cosa(r))​(73)​

and the Chern-Simons integral - also called the "magnetic helicity" in the electrodynamical context - is quantized (in multiples of 16π216 \pi^{2}16π2 ) by the behavior of a(r)a(r)a(r) at infinity

∫drA⋅B=−8π∫0∞dr d dr(a(r)−sin⁡a(r))=−16π2ν\begin{align*} \int \mathrm{d} r \boldsymbol{A} \cdot \boldsymbol{B} & =-8 \pi \int_{0}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} r \frac{\mathrm{~d}}{\mathrm{~d} r}(a(r)-\sin a(r)) \\ & =-16 \pi^{2} \nu \tag{74} \end{align*}∫drA⋅B​=−8π∫0∞​dr dr d​(a(r)−sina(r))=−16π2ν​(74)​

In spite of the nonvanishing magnetic helicity, a Clebsch parameterization for (72) is readily constructed. In form notation, it reads

A=d(−2Φ)+2(1−(sin⁡2a2)sin⁡2Θ)d(Φ+tan⁡−1[(tan⁡a2)cos⁡Θ])\begin{equation*} A=\mathrm{d}(-2 \Phi)+2\left(1-\left(\sin ^{2} \frac{a}{2}\right) \sin ^{2} \Theta\right) \mathrm{d}\left(\Phi+\tan ^{-1}\left[\left(\tan \frac{a}{2}\right) \cos \Theta\right]\right) \tag{75} \end{equation*}A=d(−2Φ)+2(1−(sin22a​)sin2Θ)d(Φ+tan−1[(tan2a​)cosΘ])​(75)​

The magnetic surfaces can be taken from formula (75) to coincide with the Gauss potentials.

S1=2(1−(sin⁡2a2)sin⁡2Θ)= constant S2=Φ+tan⁡−1[(tan⁡a2)cos⁡Θ]=constant\begin{align*} & S_{1}=2\left(1-\left(\sin ^{2} \frac{a}{2}\right) \sin ^{2} \Theta\right)=\text { constant } \\ & S_{2}=\Phi+\tan ^{-1}\left[\left(\tan \frac{a}{2}\right) \cos \Theta\right]=\mathrm{constant} \tag{76} \end{align*}​S1​=2(1−(sin22a​)sin2Θ)= constant S2​=Φ+tan−1[(tan2a​)cosΘ]=constant​(76)​

The magnetic lines are determined by the intersection of S1S_{1}S1​ and S2S_{2}S2​.

cos⁡a2=εcos⁡(Φ−φ0)sin⁡Θ=1−ε21−ε2cos⁡2(Φ−φ0)\begin{align*} & \cos \frac{a}{2}=\varepsilon \cos \left(\Phi-\varphi_{0}\right) \\ & \sin \Theta=\sqrt{\frac{1-\varepsilon^{2}}{1-\varepsilon^{2} \cos ^{2}\left(\Phi-\varphi_{0}\right)}} \tag{77} \end{align*}​cos2a​=εcos(Φ−φ0​)sinΘ=1−ε2cos2(Φ−φ0​)1−ε2​​​(77)​

where ε\varepsilonε and φ0\varphi_{0}φ0​ are constants. The potential θ=−2Φ\theta=-2 \Phiθ=−2Φ is multivalued. Consequently the "surface" integral determining the Chern-Simons term reads

∫drA⋅B=∫dr∇⋅(−2ΦB)=∫0∞r dr∫0πdΘBΦ∣Φ=2π.\begin{equation*} \int \mathrm{d} r \boldsymbol{A} \cdot \boldsymbol{B}=\int \mathrm{d} r \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(-2 \Phi \boldsymbol{B})=\left.\int_{0}^{\infty} r \mathrm{~d} r \int_{0}^{\pi} \mathrm{d} \Theta B_{\Phi}\right|_{\Phi=2 \pi} . \tag{78} \end{equation*}∫drA⋅B=∫dr∇⋅(−2ΦB)=∫0∞​r dr∫0π​dΘBΦ​​Φ=2π​.​(78)​

That is, the magnetic helicity is the flux of the toroidal magnetic field through the positive- xxx (x,z)(x, z)(x,z) half-plane.

Problem 4 Consider a vector potential A\boldsymbol{A}A, whose Clebsch parameterization reads Ai=∂iΦ+A_{i}=\partial_{i} \Phi+Ai​=∂i​Φ+ cos⁡Θ∂ih(r)\cos \Theta \partial_{i} h(r)cosΘ∂i​h(r), where Θ\ThetaΘ and Φ\PhiΦ are the azimuthal and polar angles of the vector r\boldsymbol{r}r, and hhh is a nonsingular function of the magnitude of r\boldsymbol{r}r. Show that the Chern-Simons density (magnetic helicity density) is given by εijkAi∂jAk=εijk∂iΦ∂jcos⁡Θ∂kh(r)\varepsilon^{i j k} A_{i} \partial_{j} A_{k}=\varepsilon^{i j k} \partial_{i} \Phi \partial_{j} \cos \Theta \partial_{k} h(r)εijkAi​∂j​Ak​=εijk∂i​Φ∂j​cosΘ∂k​h(r). Consider the integral of the Chern-Simons density over all space. This integral may first be evaluated over a spherical ball Ω\OmegaΩ, and then the radius RRR of the ball is taken to infinity. When the integrand is a divergence of a vector, Gauss's theorem casts the volume integral onto a surface integral over the sphere ∂Ω\partial \Omega∂Ω bounding the ball: I=∫Ωd3r∇⋅V=∫∂ΩdS⋅V=∫02π dΦ∫0πdΘsin⁡Θr2Vr∣r=RI=\int_{\Omega} \mathrm{d}^{3} r \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \boldsymbol{V}=\int_{\partial \Omega} \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{S} \cdot \boldsymbol{V}=\left.\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \mathrm{~d} \Phi \int_{0}^{\pi} \mathrm{d} \Theta \sin \Theta r^{2} V^{r}\right|_{r=R}I=∫Ω​d3r∇⋅V=∫∂Ω​dS⋅V=∫02π​ dΦ∫0π​dΘsinΘr2Vr​r=R​, but singularities in V\boldsymbol{V}V may modify the equality. The three derivatives in the above Chern-Simons density may be extracted in three different ways. Show that the result always is 4π[h(R)−4 \pi[h(R)-4π[h(R)− h(0)h(0)h(0) ], but various singularities must be carefully handled.

Problem 5 Show that ∫d3rB⋅δA\int \mathrm{d}^{3} r \boldsymbol{B} \cdot \delta \boldsymbol{A}∫d3rB⋅δA vanishes (apart from surface terms) where δA\delta \boldsymbol{A}δA is a variation and A,B=∇×A\boldsymbol{A}, \boldsymbol{B}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{A}A,B=∇×A, as well as δA\delta \boldsymbol{A}δA are presented in the Clebsch parameterization. When the variational principle is implemented by varying the components of A\boldsymbol{A}A, one finds that 12∫ d3rB2\frac{1}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{3} r B^{2}21​∫ d3rB2 is stationary provided ∇×B=0\boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{B}=0∇×B=0. Show that implementing the variation by varying the scalar functions in the Clebsch parameterization for A\boldsymbol{A}A gives the weaker condition ∇×B=μB\boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{B}=\mu \boldsymbol{B}∇×B=μB, where μ\muμ can depend on r\boldsymbol{r}r. How is this r\boldsymbol{r}r-dependence constrained? How is the constraint satisfied?

There is another approach to the construction of (Abelian) vector potentials for which the (Abelian) Chern-Simons density is a total derivative, and as a consequence a Clebsch parameterization for these potentials is readily found. The method relies on projecting an Abelian potential from a non-Abelian one, and it can be generalized to a construction of non-Abelian vectors for which the non-Abelian Chern-Simons density is again a total derivative. This will be useful for us when we come to discuss non-Abelian fluid mechanics. Therefore, I shall now explain this method - in its Abelian realization (12].

We consider an SU(2)\mathrm{SU}(2)SU(2) group element ggg and a pure gauge SU(2)\mathrm{SU}(2)SU(2) gauge field, whose matrixvalued 1 -form is

g−1 dg=Vaσa2i\begin{equation*} g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g=V^{a} \frac{\sigma^{a}}{2 i} \tag{79} \end{equation*}g−1 dg=Va2iσa​​(79)​

where σa\sigma^{a}σa are Pauli matrices. It is known that

tr⁡(g−1 dg)3=−14εabcVaVbVc=−32V1V2V3\begin{equation*} \operatorname{tr}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)^{3}=-\frac{1}{4} \varepsilon^{a b c} V^{a} V^{b} V^{c}=-\frac{3}{2} V^{1} V^{2} V^{3} \tag{80} \end{equation*}tr(g−1 dg)3=−41​εabcVaVbVc=−23​V1V2V3​(80)​

is a total derivative; indeed its spatial integral measures the winding number of the gauge function ggg [13]. Since VaV^{a}Va is a pure gauge, we have

dVa=−12εabcVbVc\begin{equation*} \mathrm{d} V^{a}=-\frac{1}{2} \varepsilon^{a b c} V^{b} V^{c} \tag{81} \end{equation*}dVa=−21​εabcVbVc​(81)​

so that if we define an Abelian gauge potential AAA by projecting one SU(2)\mathrm{SU}(2)SU(2) component of (79) (say the third) A=V3A=V^{3}A=V3, the Abelian Chern-Simons density for AAA is a total derivative, as is seen from the chain of equation that relies on (80) and (81).

A dA=V3 dV3=−V1V2V3=23tr⁡(g−1 dg)3\begin{equation*} A \mathrm{~d} A=V^{3} \mathrm{~d} V^{3}=-V^{1} V^{2} V^{3}=\frac{2}{3} \operatorname{tr}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)^{3} \tag{82} \end{equation*}A dA=V3 dV3=−V1V2V3=32​tr(g−1 dg)3​(82)​

Of course A=V3A=V^{3}A=V3 is not an Abelian pure gauge. Note that ggg depends on three arbitrary functions, the three SU(2)\mathrm{SU}(2)SU(2) local gauge functions. Hence V3V^{3}V3 enjoys sufficient generality to represent the 3 -dimensional vector AAA. Moreover, since AAA 's Abelian Chern-Simons density is given by tr⁡(g−1 dg)3\operatorname{tr}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)^{3}tr(g−1 dg)3, which is a total derivative, a Clebsch parameterization for AAA is easily constructed. We also observe that when the SU(2)\mathrm{SU}(2)SU(2) group element ggg has nonvanishing winding number, the resultant Abelian vector possesses a nonvanishing Chern-Simons integral, that is, nonzero magnetic helicity.

Finally we remark that the example of a Clebsch-parameterized gauge potential AAA, presented above in (72), is gotten by a projection onto the third isospin direction of a pure gauge SU(2)\mathrm{SU}(2)SU(2) potential, constructed from group element g=exp⁡((σa/2i)r^aa(r))g=\exp \left(\left(\sigma^{a} / 2 i\right) \widehat{r}^{a} a(r)\right)g=exp((σa/2i)raa(r)) 12.

Further intricacies arise when the Clebsch parameterization is used in variational calculations involving vector fields; see Ref. (14].

33 \quad3 Specific Models

We now return to our irrotational models both relativistic and nonrelativistic, for which we shall specify an explicit force law and discuss further properties.

3.1 Galileo-invariant nonrelativistic model

Recall that the nonrelativistic Lagrangian for irrotational motion reads

LGalileo =∫dr(θρ˙−ρ(∇θ)22−V(ρ))\begin{equation*} L^{\text {Galileo }}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(\theta \dot{\rho}-\rho \frac{(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}}{2}-V(\rho)\right) \tag{83} \end{equation*}LGalileo =∫dr(θρ˙​−ρ2(∇θ)2​−V(ρ))​(83)​

where ∇θ=v\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta=\boldsymbol{v}∇θ=v. The Hamiltonian density H\mathcal{H}H is composed of the last two terms beyond the canonical 1-form ∫drθρ˙\int \mathrm{d} r \theta \dot{\rho}∫drθρ˙​,

H=∫dr(ρ(∇θ)22+V(ρ))=∫drH.\begin{equation*} H=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(\rho \frac{(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}}{2}+V(\rho)\right)=\int \mathrm{d} r \mathcal{H} . \tag{84} \end{equation*}H=∫dr(ρ2(∇θ)2​+V(ρ))=∫drH.​(84)​

Various expressions for VVV appear in the literature. V(ρ)∝ρnV(\rho) \propto \rho^{n}V(ρ)∝ρn is a popular choice, appropriate for the adiabatic equation of state. We shall be specifically interested in the "Chaplygin gas".

V(ρ)=λρ,λ>0\begin{equation*} V(\rho)=\frac{\lambda}{\rho}, \quad \lambda>0 \tag{85} \end{equation*}V(ρ)=ρλ​,λ>0​(85)​

According to what we said before, the Chaplygin gas has enthalpy V′=−λ/ρ2V^{\prime}=-\lambda / \rho^{2}V′=−λ/ρ2, negative pressure P=−2λ/ρP=-2 \lambda / \rhoP=−2λ/ρ, and speed of sound s=2λ/ρs=\sqrt{2 \lambda} / \rhos=2λ​/ρ (hence λ>0\lambda>0λ>0 ).

Chaplygin introduced his equation of state as a mathematical approximation to the physically relevant adiabatic expressions with n>0n>0n>0. (Constants are arranged so that the Chaplygin formula is tangent at one point to the adiabatic profile [15].) Also it was realized that certain deformable solids can be described by the Chaplygin equation of state 16. These days negative pressure is recognized as a possible physical effect: exchange forces in atoms give rise to negative pressure; stripe states in the quantum Hall effect may be a consequence of negative pressure; the recently discovered cosmological constant may be exerting negative pressure on the cosmos, thereby accelerating expansion.

For any form of VVV, the model possesses the Galileo symmetry appropriate to nonrelativistic dynamics. The Galileo transformations comprise the time and space translations, as well as space rotations. The corresponding constants of motion are the energy EEE.

E=∫drH=∫dr(ρ(∇θ)22+V(ρ)) (time translation) \begin{equation*} E=\int \mathrm{d} r \mathcal{H}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(\rho \frac{(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}}{2}+V(\rho)\right) \quad \text { (time translation) } \tag{86} \end{equation*}E=∫drH=∫dr(ρ2(∇θ)2​+V(ρ)) (time translation) ​(86)​

the momentum P\boldsymbol{P}P (whose density P\boldsymbol{\mathcal { P }}P equals the spatial current),

P=∫drP=∫drj=∫drρv (space translation) \begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{P}=\int \mathrm{d} r \boldsymbol{\mathcal { P }}=\int \mathrm{d} r \boldsymbol{j}=\int \mathrm{d} r \rho \boldsymbol{v} \quad \text { (space translation) } \tag{87} \end{equation*}P=∫drP=∫drj=∫drρv (space translation) ​(87)​

and the angular momentum MijM^{i j}Mij.

Mij=∫dr(riPj−rjPi) (rotation) \begin{equation*} M^{i j}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(r^{i} \mathcal{P}^{j}-r^{j} \mathcal{P}^{i}\right) \quad \text { (rotation) } \tag{88} \end{equation*}Mij=∫dr(riPj−rjPi) (rotation) ​(88)​

The action of these transformations on the fields is straightforward: the time and space arguments are shifted or the space argument is rotated. Slightly less trivial is the action of Galileo boosts, which boost the spatial coordinate by a velocity u\boldsymbol{u}u

r→R=r−tu\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{r} \rightarrow \boldsymbol{R}=\boldsymbol{r}-t \boldsymbol{u} \tag{89} \end{equation*}r→R=r−tu​(89)​

The density field transforms trivially: its spatial argument is boosted,

ρ(t,r)→ρu(t,r)=ρ(t,R)\begin{equation*} \rho(t, \boldsymbol{r}) \rightarrow \rho_{\boldsymbol{u}}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\rho(t, \boldsymbol{R}) \tag{90} \end{equation*}ρ(t,r)→ρu​(t,r)=ρ(t,R)​(90)​

but the velocity potential acquires an inhomogeneous term.

θ(t,r)→θu(t,r)=θ(t,R)+u⋅r−u22t\begin{equation*} \theta(t, \boldsymbol{r}) \rightarrow \theta_{\boldsymbol{u}}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\theta(t, \boldsymbol{R})+\boldsymbol{u} \cdot \boldsymbol{r}-\frac{u^{2}}{2} t \tag{91} \end{equation*}θ(t,r)→θu​(t,r)=θ(t,R)+u⋅r−2u2​t​(91)​

Those of you familiar with field theoretic realizations of the Galileo group will recognize the inhomogeneous term as the well-known Galileo 1-cocyle. It ensures that the velocity, the gradient of θ\thetaθ, transforms appropriately.

v(t,r)→vu(t,r)=v(t,r−tu)+u\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{v}(t, \boldsymbol{r}) \rightarrow \boldsymbol{v}_{\boldsymbol{u}}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\boldsymbol{v}(t, \boldsymbol{r}-t \boldsymbol{u})+\boldsymbol{u} \tag{92} \end{equation*}v(t,r)→vu​(t,r)=v(t,r−tu)+u​(92)​

The associated conserved quantity is the "boost generator".

B=tP−∫drρr (Galileo boost) \begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{B}=t \boldsymbol{P}-\int \mathrm{d} r \rho \boldsymbol{r} \quad \text { (Galileo boost) } \tag{93} \end{equation*}B=tP−∫drρr (Galileo boost) ​(93)​

Finally, also conserved is the total number.

N=∫drρ (particle number) \begin{equation*} N=\int \mathrm{d} r \rho \quad \text { (particle number) } \tag{94} \end{equation*}N=∫drρ (particle number) ​(94)​

The corresponding transformation shifts θ\thetaθ by a constant. These transformations and constants of motion fit into the general theory: the action is invariant against the transformations; Noether's theorem can be used to derive the constants of motion; their time independence is verified with the help of the equations of motion indeed, the continuity equations (17), (4), and (5) as well as the symmetry of TijT^{i j}Tij guarantee this. Also, using the basic Poisson brackets (25) for the (ρ,θ)(\rho, \theta)(ρ,θ) variables, one can check that each infinitesimal transformation is generated by Poisson bracketing with the appropriate constant; Poisson bracketing the constants with each other reproduces the Galileo Lie algebra with a central extension given by NNN, which corresponds to the familiar Galileo 2-cocycle. There are a total of 12(d+1)(d+2)\frac{1}{2}(d+1)(d+2)21​(d+1)(d+2) Galileo generators in ddd space plus one time dimensions. Together with the central term, we have a total of 12(d+1)(d+2)+1\frac{1}{2}(d+1)(d+2)+121​(d+1)(d+2)+1 generators.

Another useful consequence of the symmetry transformations is that they map solutions of the equations of motion into new solutions. Of course, "new" solutions produced by Galileo transformations are trivially related to the old ones: they are simply shifted, boosted or rotated. [The free theory as well as the adiabatic theory with n=1+2/dn=1+2 / dn=1+2/d are also invariant against the SO(2,1)\mathrm{SO}(2,1)SO(2,1) group of time translation, dilation, and conformal transformation [17], which together with the Galileo group form the "Schrödinger group" of nonrelativistic motion, whenever the energy-momentum "tensor" satisfies 2Too=Tii2 T^{o o}=T^{i}{ }_{i}2Too=Tii​ [18].]

But we shall now turn to the specific Chaplygin gas model, with V(ρ)=λ/ρV(\rho)=\lambda / \rhoV(ρ)=λ/ρ, which possesses additional and unexpected symmetries.

The Chaplygin gas action and consequent Bernoulli equation for the Chaplygin gas in (d,1)(d, 1)(d,1) space-time read

IλChaplygin =∫dt∫ dr(θρ˙−12ρ(∇θ)2−λρ)θ˙+(∇θ)22=λρ2\begin{gather*} I_{\lambda}^{\text {Chaplygin }}=\int \mathrm{d} t \int \mathrm{~d} r\left(\theta \dot{\rho}-\frac{1}{2} \rho(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}-\frac{\lambda}{\rho}\right) \tag{95}\\ \dot{\theta}+\frac{(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}}{2}=\frac{\lambda}{\rho^{2}} \tag{96} \end{gather*}IλChaplygin ​=∫dt∫ dr(θρ˙​−21​ρ(∇θ)2−ρλ​)θ˙+2(∇θ)2​=ρ2λ​​(95)(96)​

This model possesses further space-time symmetries beyond those of the Galileo group [19]. First of all, there is a one-parameter ( ω\omegaω ) time rescaling transformation

t→T=eωt\begin{equation*} t \rightarrow T=e^{\omega} t \tag{97} \end{equation*}t→T=eωt​(97)​

under which the fields transform as

θ(t,r)→θω(t,r)=eωθ(T,r)ρ(t,r)→ρω(t,r)=e−ωρ(T,r).\begin{align*} & \theta(t, \boldsymbol{r}) \rightarrow \theta_{\omega}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=e^{\omega} \theta(T, \boldsymbol{r}) \tag{98}\\ & \rho(t, \boldsymbol{r}) \rightarrow \rho_{\omega}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=e^{-\omega} \rho(T, \boldsymbol{r}) . \tag{99} \end{align*}​θ(t,r)→θω​(t,r)=eωθ(T,r)ρ(t,r)→ρω​(t,r)=e−ωρ(T,r).​(98)(99)​

Second, in ddd spatial dimensions, there is a vectorial, ddd-parameter (ω)(\boldsymbol{\omega})(ω) space-time mixing transformation

t→T(t,r)=t+ω⋅r+12ω2θ(T,R)r→R(t,r)=r+ωθ(T,R)\begin{align*} t & \rightarrow T(t, \boldsymbol{r})=t+\boldsymbol{\omega} \cdot \boldsymbol{r}+\frac{1}{2} \omega^{2} \theta(T, \boldsymbol{R}) \tag{100}\\ \boldsymbol{r} & \rightarrow \boldsymbol{R}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\boldsymbol{r}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \theta(T, \boldsymbol{R}) \tag{101} \end{align*}tr​→T(t,r)=t+ω⋅r+21​ω2θ(T,R)→R(t,r)=r+ωθ(T,R)​(100)(101)​

Note that the transformation law for the coordinates involves the θ\thetaθ field itself. Under this transformation, the fields transform according to

θ(t,r)→θω(t,r)=θ(T,R)ρ(t,r)→ρω(t,r)=ρ(T,R)1∣J∣\begin{align*} & \theta(t, \boldsymbol{r}) \rightarrow \theta_{\boldsymbol{\omega}}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\theta(T, \boldsymbol{R}) \tag{102}\\ & \rho(t, \boldsymbol{r}) \rightarrow \rho_{\boldsymbol{\omega}}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\rho(T, \boldsymbol{R}) \frac{1}{|J|} \tag{103} \end{align*}​θ(t,r)→θω​(t,r)=θ(T,R)ρ(t,r)→ρω​(t,r)=ρ(T,R)∣J∣1​​(102)(103)​

with JJJ the Jacobian of the transformation linking (T,R)→(t,r)(T, \boldsymbol{R}) \rightarrow(t, \boldsymbol{r})(T,R)→(t,r).

J=det⁡(∂T∂t∂T∂rj∂Ri∂t∂Ri∂rj)=(1−ω⋅∇θ(T,R)−ω22θ˙(T,R))−1(104)J=\operatorname{det}\left(\begin{array}{cc} \frac{\partial T}{\partial t} & \frac{\partial T}{\partial r^{j}} \tag{104}\\ \frac{\partial R^{i}}{\partial t} & \frac{\partial R^{i}}{\partial r^{j}} \end{array}\right)=\left(1-\boldsymbol{\omega} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta(T, \boldsymbol{R})-\frac{\omega^{2}}{2} \dot{\theta}(T, \boldsymbol{R})\right)^{-1}J=det(∂t∂T​∂t∂Ri​​∂rj∂T​∂rj∂Ri​​)=(1−ω⋅∇θ(T,R)−2ω2​θ˙(T,R))−1(104)

(The time and space derivatives in the last element are with respect to ttt and r\boldsymbol{r}r.) One can again tell the complete story for these transformations: The action is invariant; Noether's theorem gives the conserved quantities, which for the time rescaling is

D=tH−∫drρθ (time rescaling) \begin{equation*} D=t H-\int \mathrm{d} r \rho \theta \quad \text { (time rescaling) } \tag{105} \end{equation*}D=tH−∫drρθ (time rescaling) ​(105)​

while for the space-time mixing one finds

G=∫dr(rH−θP) (space-time mixing). \begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{G}=\int \mathrm{d} r(\boldsymbol{r} \mathcal{H}-\theta \boldsymbol{\mathcal { P }}) \quad \text { (space-time mixing). } \tag{106} \end{equation*}G=∫dr(rH−θP) (space-time mixing). ​(106)​

The time independence of DDD and G\boldsymbol{G}G can be verified with the help of the equations of motion (continuity and Bernoulli). Poisson bracketing the fields θ\thetaθ and ρ\rhoρ with DDD and G\boldsymbol{G}G generates the appropriate infinitesimal transformation on the fields.

So now the total number of generators is the sum of the previous 12(d+1)(d+2)+1\frac{1}{2}(d+1)(d+2)+121​(d+1)(d+2)+1 with 1+d1+d1+d additional ones

12(d+1)(d+2)+1+1+d=12(d+2)(d+3)\begin{equation*} \frac{1}{2}(d+1)(d+2)+1+1+d=\frac{1}{2}(d+2)(d+3) \tag{107} \end{equation*}21​(d+1)(d+2)+1+1+d=21​(d+2)(d+3)​(107)​

When one computes the Poisson brackets of all these with each other one finds the Poincaré Lie algebra in one higher spatial dimension, that is, in (d+1,1)(d+1,1)(d+1,1)-dimensional space-time, where the Poincaré group possesses 12(d+2)(d+3)\frac{1}{2}(d+2)(d+3)21​(d+2)(d+3) generators [20]. Moreover, one verifies that (t,θ,r)(t, \theta, \boldsymbol{r})(t,θ,r) transform linearly as a (d+2)(d+2)(d+2) Lorentz vector in light-cone components, with ttt being the " + " component and θ\thetaθ the " - " component 21].

Presently, we shall use these additional symmetries to generate new solutions from old ones, but, in contrast with what we saw earlier, the new solutions will be nontrivially linked to the former ones. Note that the additional symmetry holds even in the free theory.

Before proceeding, let us observe that ρ\rhoρ may be eliminated by using the Bernoulli equation to express it in terms of θ\thetaθ. In this way, one is led to the following ρ\rhoρ-independent action for θ\thetaθ in the Chaplygin gas problem:

IλChaplygin =−2λ∫dt∫ drθ˙+(∇θ)22\begin{equation*} I_{\lambda}^{\text {Chaplygin }}=-2 \sqrt{\lambda} \int d t \int \mathrm{~d} r \sqrt{\dot{\theta}+\frac{(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}}{2}} \tag{108} \end{equation*}IλChaplygin ​=−2λ​∫dt∫ drθ˙+2(∇θ)2​​​(108)​

Although this operation is possible only in the interacting case, the interaction strength is seen to disappear from the equations of motion.

∂∂t1θ˙+(∇θ)22+∇⋅∇θθ˙+(∇θ)22=0\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{\dot{\theta}+\frac{(\nabla \theta)^{2}}{2}}}+\nabla \cdot \frac{\nabla \theta}{\sqrt{\dot{\theta}+\frac{(\nabla \theta)^{2}}{2}}}=0 \tag{109} \end{equation*}∂t∂​θ˙+2(∇θ)2​​1​+∇⋅θ˙+2(∇θ)2​​∇θ​=0​(109)​

λ\lambdaλ merely serves as an overall factor in the action. The action (108) looks unfamiliar; yet it is Galileo invariant. [The combination θ˙+12(∇θ)2\dot{\theta}+\frac{1}{2}(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}θ˙+21​(∇θ)2 responds to Galileo transformations without a 1-cocycle; see (91).] Also IλChaplygin I_{\lambda}^{\text {Chaplygin }}IλChaplygin ​ possesses the additional symmetries described above, with θ\thetaθ transforming according to the previously recorded equations.

Let us discuss some solutions. For example, the free theory is solved by

θ(t,r)=r22t\begin{equation*} \theta(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\frac{r^{2}}{2 t} \tag{110} \end{equation*}θ(t,r)=2tr2​​(110)​

which corresponds to the velocity

v(t,r)=rt\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{v}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\frac{\boldsymbol{r}}{t} \tag{111} \end{equation*}v(t,r)=tr​​(111)​

Galileo transforms generalize this in an obvious manner into a set of solutions. (The charge density ρ\rhoρ is determined by its initial condition. In the free theory, ρ\rhoρ is an independent quantity, and I shall not discuss it here.) Performing on the above formula for θ\thetaθ the new transformations of time-rescaling and space-time mixing, we find that the solution is invariant.

We can find a solution similar to (110) in the interacting case, for d>1d>1d>1, which we henceforth assume (the d=1d=1d=1 case will be separately discussed later). One verifies that a solution is

θ(t,r)=−r22(d−1)tρ(t,r)=2λd(d−1)∣t∣rv(t,r)=−r(d−1)tj(t,r)=−ε(t)2λdr^\begin{align*} \theta(t, \boldsymbol{r}) & =-\frac{r^{2}}{2(d-1) t} & \rho(t, \boldsymbol{r}) & =\sqrt{\frac{2 \lambda}{d}}(d-1) \frac{|t|}{r} \tag{112}\\ \boldsymbol{v}(t, \boldsymbol{r}) & =-\frac{\boldsymbol{r}}{(d-1) t} & \boldsymbol{j}(t, \boldsymbol{r}) & =-\varepsilon(t) \sqrt{\frac{2 \lambda}{d}} \widehat{r} \tag{113} \end{align*}θ(t,r)v(t,r)​=−2(d−1)tr2​=−(d−1)tr​​ρ(t,r)j(t,r)​=d2λ​​(d−1)r∣t∣​=−ε(t)d2λ​​r​(112)(113)​

Note that the speed of sound

s=2λρ=dr(d−1)t=dv\begin{equation*} s=\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\rho}=\frac{\sqrt{d} r}{(d-1) t}=\sqrt{d} v \tag{114} \end{equation*}s=ρ2λ​​=(d−1)td​r​=d​v​(114)​

exceeds vvv. Again this solution can be translated, rotated, and boosted. Moreover, the solution is time-rescaling-invariant. However, the space-time mixing transformation produces a wholly different kind of solution. This is best shown graphically, where the d=2d=2d=2 case is exhibited (see figure) [22].

Another interesting solution, which is essentially one-dimensional (lineal), even though it exists in arbitrary spatial dimension, is given by

θ(t,r)=Θ(n^⋅r)+u⋅r−12t(u2−(n^⋅u)2)\begin{equation*} \theta(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\Theta(\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{r})+\boldsymbol{u} \cdot \boldsymbol{r}-\frac{1}{2} t\left(u^{2}-(\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{u})^{2}\right) \tag{115} \end{equation*}θ(t,r)=Θ(n⋅r)+u⋅r−21​t(u2−(n⋅u)2)​(115)​

Here n^\widehat{n}n is a spatial unit vector, u\boldsymbol{u}u is an arbitrary vector with dimension of velocity, while Θ\ThetaΘ is an arbitrary function with static argument, which can be boosted by the Galileo transform (91). The corresponding charge density is time-independent.

ρ(t,r)=2λn^⋅u+Θ′(n^⋅r)\begin{equation*} \rho(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{u}+\Theta^{\prime}(\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{r})} \tag{116} \end{equation*}ρ(t,r)=n⋅u+Θ′(n⋅r)2λ​​​(116)​

The current is static and divergenceless.

j(t,r)=2λ(n^+u−n^(n^⋅u)n^⋅r+Θ′(n^⋅r))\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{j}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\sqrt{2 \lambda}\left(\widehat{n}+\frac{\boldsymbol{u}-\widehat{n}(\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{u})}{\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{r}+\Theta^{\prime}(\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{r})}\right) \tag{117} \end{equation*}j(t,r)=2λ​(n+n⋅r+Θ′(n⋅r)u−n(n⋅u)​)​(117)​

The sound speed s=2λ/ρ=Θ′(n^⋅r)+n^⋅us=\sqrt{2 \lambda} / \rho=\Theta^{\prime}(\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{r})+\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{u}s=2λ​/ρ=Θ′(n⋅r)+n⋅u is just the n^\widehat{n}n component of the velocity v=∇θ=n^Θ′(n^⋅r)+u\boldsymbol{v}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta=\widehat{n} \Theta^{\prime}(\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{r})+\boldsymbol{u}v=∇θ=nΘ′(n⋅r)+u.

Finally, we record a planar static solution to (109)

θ(r)=Θ(n^1⋅r/n^2⋅r)\begin{equation*} \theta(\boldsymbol{r})=\Theta\left(\widehat{n}_{1} \cdot \boldsymbol{r} / \widehat{n}_{2} \cdot \boldsymbol{r}\right) \tag{118} \end{equation*}θ(r)=Θ(n1​⋅r/n2​⋅r)​(118)​

where n^1\widehat{n}_{1}n1​ and n^2\widehat{n}_{2}n2​ are two orthogonal unit vectors [23].

Problem 6 Show that the solution for θ\thetaθ given in (110) is invariant under the time rescaling transformation (97), (98), and under the space-time mixing transformation (109)-(102).

The transformed density ρ(t,r)\rho(t, \mathbf{r})ρ(t,r).

3.2 Lorentz-invariant relativistic model

We now turn to a Lorentz-invariant generalization of our Galileo-invariant Chaplygin model in ( d,1d, 1d,1 )-dimensional space-time. We already know from (34)-(37) how to construct the free Lagrangian by using Eckart's method with a relativistic kinetic energy.

T(v)=−c21−v2/c2\begin{equation*} T(\boldsymbol{v})=-c^{2} \sqrt{1-v^{2} / c^{2}} \tag{119} \end{equation*}T(v)=−c21−v2/c2​​(119)​

Recall that mass has been scaled to unity, and that we retain the velocity of light ccc to keep track of the nonrelativistic c→∞c \rightarrow \inftyc→∞ limit. Evidently, the momentum is

p=∂T(v)∂v=v1−v2/c2\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{p}=\frac{\partial T(\boldsymbol{v})}{\partial \boldsymbol{v}}=\frac{\boldsymbol{v}}{\sqrt{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}} \tag{120} \end{equation*}p=∂v∂T(v)​=1−v2/c2​v​​(120)​

Thus the free relativistic Lagrangian, with current conservation enforced by the Lagrange multiplier θ\thetaθ, reads [compare (34)]

Lˉ0Lorentz=∫dr(−c2ρ1−v2/c2+θ(ρ˙+∇⋅(ρv)))\begin{equation*} \bar{L}_{0}^{\mathrm{Lorentz}}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(-c^{2} \rho \sqrt{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}+\theta(\dot{\rho}+\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\rho \boldsymbol{v}))\right) \tag{121} \end{equation*}Lˉ0Lorentz​=∫dr(−c2ρ1−v2/c2​+θ(ρ˙​+∇⋅(ρv)))​(121)​

This may be presented in a Lorentz-covariant form in terms of a current four-vector jμ=j^{\mu}=jμ= (cρ,ρv).Lˉ0Lorentz(c \rho, \rho \boldsymbol{v}) . \bar{L}_{0}^{\mathrm{Lorentz}}(cρ,ρv).Lˉ0Lorentz​ of equation (121) is thus equivalent to [compare (56), (57)]

Lˉ0Lorentz =∫dr(−jμ∂μθ−cjμjμ)\begin{equation*} \bar{L}_{0}^{\text {Lorentz }}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(-j^{\mu} \partial_{\mu} \theta-c \sqrt{j^{\mu} j_{\mu}}\right) \tag{122} \end{equation*}Lˉ0Lorentz ​=∫dr(−jμ∂μ​θ−cjμjμ​​)​(122)​

Eliminating v\boldsymbol{v}v in (121), we find, as before, that

p=∂T∂v=v1−v2/c2=∇θ,v=∇θ1+(θθ)2/c2\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{p}=\frac{\partial T}{\partial \boldsymbol{v}}=\frac{\boldsymbol{v}}{\sqrt{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta, \quad \boldsymbol{v}=\frac{\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta}{\sqrt{1+(\boldsymbol{\theta} \theta)^{2} / c^{2}}} \tag{123} \end{equation*}p=∂v∂T​=1−v2/c2​v​=∇θ,v=1+(θθ)2/c2​∇θ​​(123)​

and the free Lorentz-invariant Lagrangian reads [compare (36), (37)]

L0Lorentz=∫dr(θρ˙−ρc21+(∇θ)2/c2)\begin{equation*} L_{0}^{\mathrm{Lorentz}}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(\theta \dot{\rho}-\rho c^{2} \sqrt{1+(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2} / c^{2}}\right) \tag{124} \end{equation*}L0Lorentz​=∫dr(θρ˙​−ρc21+(∇θ)2/c2​)​(124)​

To find L0Galileo L_{0}^{\text {Galileo }}L0Galileo ​ of (31) as the nonrelativistic limit of L0Lorentz L_{0}^{\text {Lorentz }}L0Lorentz ​ in (124), a nonrelativistic θ\thetaθ variable must be extracted from its relativistic counterpart. Calling the former θNR\theta_{\mathrm{NR}}θNR​ and the latter, which occurs in (124), θR\theta_{\mathrm{R}}θR​, we define

θR≡−c2t+θNR\begin{equation*} \theta_{\mathrm{R}} \equiv-c^{2} t+\theta_{\mathrm{NR}} \tag{125} \end{equation*}θR​≡−c2t+θNR​​(125)​

It then follows that apart from a total time derivative

L0Lorentz ⟶c→∞L0Galileo \begin{equation*} L_{0}^{\text {Lorentz }} \underset{c \rightarrow \infty}{\longrightarrow} L_{0}^{\text {Galileo }} \tag{126} \end{equation*}L0Lorentz ​c→∞⟶​L0Galileo ​​(126)​

Next, one wants to include interactions. While there are many ways to allow for Lorentzinvariant interactions, we seek an expression that reduces to the Chaplygin gas in the nonrelativistic limit. Thus, we choose (24]

LaBorn-Infeld =∫dr(θρ˙−ρ2c2+a2c2+(∇θ)2),\begin{equation*} L_{a}^{\text {Born-Infeld }}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left(\theta \dot{\rho}-\sqrt{\rho^{2} c^{2}+a^{2}} \sqrt{c^{2}+(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}}\right), \tag{127} \end{equation*}LaBorn-Infeld ​=∫dr(θρ˙​−ρ2c2+a2​c2+(∇θ)2​),​(127)​

where aaa is the interaction strength. [The reason for the nomenclature will emerge presently.] We see that, as c→∞c \rightarrow \inftyc→∞,

LaBorn-Infeld c→∞Lλ=a2/2Chaplygin \begin{equation*} L_{a}^{\text {Born-Infeld }} \underset{c \rightarrow \infty}{ } L_{\lambda=a^{2} / 2}^{\text {Chaplygin }} \tag{128} \end{equation*}LaBorn-Infeld ​c→∞​Lλ=a2/2Chaplygin ​​(128)​

[Again θNR\theta_{\mathrm{NR}}θNR​ is extracted from θR\theta_{\mathrm{R}}θR​ as in (125) and a total time derivative is ignored.] Although it perhaps is not obvious, (127) defines a Poincaré-invariant theory, and this will be explicitly demonstrated below.
