Therefore, LaBorn-Infeld L_{a}^{\text {Born-Infeld }}LaBorn-Infeld ​ possesses Lorentz and Poincaré symmetries in (d,1)(d, 1)(d,1) space-time, with a total of 12(d+1)(d+2)+1\frac{1}{2}(d+1)(d+2)+121​(d+1)(d+2)+1 generators, where the last " +1 " refers to the total number N=∫drρN=\int \mathrm{d} r \rhoN=∫drρ.

When a=0a=0a=0, the model is free and elementary. It was demonstrated previously [eqs. (34)(42)] that the free equations of motion are precisely the same as in the nonrelativistic free model, so the complete solution (43)-(47) works here as well. For a≠0a \neq 0a=0, in the presence of interactions, one can eliminate ρ\rhoρ as before, and one is left with a Lagrangian just for the θ\thetaθ field. It reads

LaBorn-Infeld =−a∫ drc2−(∂μθ)2\begin{equation*} L_{a}^{\text {Born-Infeld }}=-a \int \mathrm{~d} r \sqrt{c^{2}-\left(\partial_{\mu} \theta\right)^{2}} \tag{129} \end{equation*}LaBorn-Infeld ​=−a∫ drc2−(∂μ​θ)2​​(129)​

This is a Born-Infeld-type theory for a scalar field θ\thetaθ; its Poincaré invariance is manifest, and again, the elimination of ρ\rhoρ is only possible with nonvanishing aaa, which however disappears from the dynamics, serving merely to normalize the Lagrangian.

The equations of motion that follow from (127) read

ρ˙+∇⋅(∇θρ2c2+a2c2+(∇θ)2)=0θ˙+ρc2c2+(∇θ)2ρ2c2+a2=0\begin{align*} \dot{\rho}+\nabla \cdot\left(\nabla \theta \sqrt{\frac{\rho^{2} c^{2}+a^{2}}{c^{2}+(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}}}\right) & =0 \tag{130}\\ \dot{\theta}+\rho c^{2} \sqrt{\frac{c^{2}+(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}}{\rho^{2} c^{2}+a^{2}}} & =0 \tag{131} \end{align*}ρ˙​+∇⋅(∇θc2+(∇θ)2ρ2c2+a2​​)θ˙+ρc2ρ2c2+a2c2+(∇θ)2​​​=0=0​(130)(131)​

The density ρ\rhoρ can be evaluated in terms of θ\thetaθ from (131); then (130) reads

∂α(1c2−(∂μθ)2∂αθ)=0\begin{equation*} \partial^{\alpha}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{c^{2}-\left(\partial_{\mu} \theta\right)^{2}}} \partial_{\alpha} \theta\right)=0 \tag{132} \end{equation*}∂α​c2−(∂μ​θ)2​1​∂α​θ​=0​(132)​

which also follows from (129). After θNR\theta_{\mathrm{NR}}θNR​ is extracted from θR\theta_{\mathrm{R}}θR​ as in (125) we see that in the

LaBorn-Infeld c→∞Lλ=a2/2Chaplygin \begin{equation*} L_{a}^{\text {Born-Infeld }} \underset{c \rightarrow \infty}{ } L_{\lambda=a^{2} / 2}^{\text {Chaplygin }} \tag{133} \end{equation*}LaBorn-Infeld ​c→∞​Lλ=a2/2Chaplygin ​​(133)​

and the equations of motion (130) -(132) reduce to (11), (96), and (109). In view of all the similarities to the nonrelativistic Chaplygin gas, it comes as no surprise that the relativistic Born-Infeld theory possesses additional symmetries. These additional symmetry transformations, which leave (127) or (129) invariant, involve a one-parameter ( ω\omegaω ) reparameterization of time, and a ddd-parameter (ω)(\boldsymbol{\omega})(ω) vectorial reparameterization of space. Both transformations are field dependent.

The time transformation is given by an implicit formula involving also the field θ\thetaθ [25],

t→T(t,r)=tcosh⁡c2ω+θ(T,r)c2tanh⁡c2ω\begin{equation*} t \rightarrow T(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\frac{t}{\cosh c^{2} \omega}+\frac{\theta(T, \boldsymbol{r})}{c^{2}} \tanh c^{2} \omega \tag{134} \end{equation*}t→T(t,r)=coshc2ωt​+c2θ(T,r)​tanhc2ω​(134)​

while the field transforms according to

θ(t,r)→θω(t,r)=θ(T,r)cosh⁡c2ω−c2ttanh⁡c2ω.\begin{equation*} \theta(t, \boldsymbol{r}) \rightarrow \theta_{\omega}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\frac{\theta(T, \boldsymbol{r})}{\cosh c^{2} \omega}-c^{2} t \tanh c^{2} \omega . \tag{135} \end{equation*}θ(t,r)→θω​(t,r)=coshc2ωθ(T,r)​−c2ttanhc2ω.​(135)​

[We record here only the transformation on θ\thetaθ; how ρ\rhoρ transforms can be determined from the (relativistic) Bernoulli equation, obtained by varying ρ\rhoρ in (127), which expresses ρ\rhoρ in terms of θ\thetaθ. Moreover, (135) is sufficient for discussing the invariance of (129).] The infinitesimal generator, which is time independent by virtue of the equations of motion, is (26]

D=∫dr(c4tρ+θρ2c2+a2c2+(∇θ)2)=∫dr(c4tρ+θH) (time reparameterization). \begin{align*} D & =\int \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{r}\left(c^{4} t \rho+\theta \sqrt{\rho^{2} c^{2}+a^{2}} \sqrt{c^{2}+(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}}\right) \\ & =\int \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{r}\left(c^{4} t \rho+\theta \mathcal{H}\right) \quad \text { (time reparameterization). } \tag{136} \end{align*}D​=∫dr(c4tρ+θρ2c2+a2​c2+(∇θ)2​)=∫dr(c4tρ+θH) (time reparameterization). ​(136)​

A second class of transformations involving a reparameterization of the spatial variables is implicitly defined by (25).

r→R(t,r)=r−ω^θ(t,R)tan⁡cωc+ω^(ω^⋅r)(1−cos⁡cωcos⁡cω)θ(t,r)→θω(t,r)=θ(t,R)−c(ω^⋅r)sin⁡cωcos⁡cω\begin{gather*} \boldsymbol{r} \rightarrow \boldsymbol{R}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\boldsymbol{r}-\widehat{\omega} \theta(t, \boldsymbol{R}) \frac{\tan c \omega}{c}+\widehat{\omega}(\widehat{\omega} \cdot \boldsymbol{r})\left(\frac{1-\cos c \omega}{\cos c \omega}\right) \tag{137}\\ \theta(t, \boldsymbol{r}) \rightarrow \theta_{\omega}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\frac{\theta(t, \boldsymbol{R})-c(\widehat{\omega} \cdot \boldsymbol{r}) \sin c \omega}{\cos c \omega} \tag{138} \end{gather*}r→R(t,r)=r−ωθ(t,R)ctancω​+ω(ω⋅r)(coscω1−coscω​)θ(t,r)→θω​(t,r)=coscωθ(t,R)−c(ω⋅r)sincω​​(137)(138)​

ω^\widehat{\omega}ω is the unit vector ω/ω\boldsymbol{\omega} / \omegaω/ω and ω=ω⋅ω\omega=\sqrt{\boldsymbol{\omega} \cdot \boldsymbol{\omega}}ω=ω⋅ω​. The time-independent generator of the infinitesimal transformation reads [26]

G=∫dr(c2rρ+θρ∇θ)=∫dr(c2rρ+θP) (space reparameterization). \begin{align*} \boldsymbol{G} & =\int \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{r}\left(c^{2} \boldsymbol{r} \rho+\theta \rho \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta\right) \\ & =\int \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{r}\left(c^{2} \boldsymbol{r} \rho+\theta \mathcal{P}\right) \quad \text { (space reparameterization). } \tag{139} \end{align*}G​=∫dr(c2rρ+θρ∇θ)=∫dr(c2rρ+θP) (space reparameterization). ​(139)​

Of course the Born-Infeld action (127) or (129) is invariant against these transformations, whose infinitesimal form is generated by the constants.

With the addition of DDD and G\boldsymbol{G}G to the previous generators, the Poincaré algebra in (d+1,1)(d+1,1)(d+1,1) dimension is reconstructed, and (t,r,θ)(t, \boldsymbol{r}, \theta)(t,r,θ) transforms linearly as a (d+2)(d+2)(d+2)-dimensional Lorentz vector (in Cartesian components) (21]. Note that this symmetry also holds in the free, a=0a=0a=0, theory.

It is easy to exhibit solutions of the relativistic equation (132), which reduce to solutions of the nonrelativistic, Chaplygin gas equation (109) [after −c2t-c^{2} t−c2t has been removed, as in (125)]. For example

θ(t,r)=−cc2t2+r2d−1\begin{equation*} \theta(t, \boldsymbol{r})=-c \sqrt{c^{2} t^{2}+\frac{r^{2}}{d-1}} \tag{140} \end{equation*}θ(t,r)=−cc2t2+d−1r2​​​(140)​

solves (132) and reduces to (112). The relativistic analog of the lineal solution (115) is

θ(t,r)=Θ(n^⋅r)+n⋅r−ctc2+u2−(n^⋅u)2\begin{equation*} \theta(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\Theta(\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{r})+\boldsymbol{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{r}-c t \sqrt{c^{2}+u^{2}-(\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{u})^{2}} \tag{141} \end{equation*}θ(t,r)=Θ(n⋅r)+n⋅r−ctc2+u2−(n⋅u)2​​(141)​

[Note that the above profiles continue to solve (132), even when the sign of the square root is reversed, but then they no longer possess a nonrelativistic limit.]

Additionally there exists an essentially relativistic solution, describing massless propagation in one direction: according to (132), θ\thetaθ can satisfy the wave equation □θ=0\square \theta=0□θ=0, provided (∂μθ)2=\left(\partial_{\mu} \theta\right)^{2}=(∂μ​θ)2= constant, as for example with plane waves

θ(t,r)=f(n^⋅r±ct)\begin{equation*} \theta(t, \boldsymbol{r})=f(\widehat{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{r} \pm c t) \tag{142} \end{equation*}θ(t,r)=f(n⋅r±ct)​(142)​

where (∂μθ)2\left(\partial_{\mu} \theta\right)^{2}(∂μ​θ)2 vanishes. Then ρ\rhoρ reads, from (131),

ρ=∓ac2f′\begin{equation*} \rho=\mp \frac{a}{c^{2}} f^{\prime} \tag{143} \end{equation*}ρ=∓c2a​f′​(143)​

Other solutions are given in ref. 27.

3.3 Some remarks on relativistic fluid mechanics

The Born-Infeld model reduces in the nonrelativistic limit to the Chaplygin gas. Equations governing the latter belong to fluid mechanics, but the Born-Infeld equations do not readily expose their fluid mechanical structure. Nevertheless they do in fact describe a relativistic fluid. In order to demonstrate this, we give a précis of relativistic fluid mechanics.

Usually the dynamics of a relativistic fluid is presented in terms of the energy-momentum tensor, θμν\theta^{\mu \nu}θμν, and the equations of motion are just the conservation equations ∂μθμν=0\partial_{\mu} \theta^{\mu \nu}=0∂μ​θμν=0 [28]. [We denote the relativistic energy-momentum tensor by θμν\theta^{\mu \nu}θμν, to distinguish it from the nonrelativistic TμνT^{\mu \nu}Tμν introduced in (4) and (5). The limiting relation between the two is given below.] But we prefer to begin with a Lagrange density

L=−jμaμ−f(jμjμ).\begin{equation*} \mathcal{L}=-j^{\mu} a_{\mu}-f\left(\sqrt{j^{\mu} j_{\mu}}\right) . \tag{144} \end{equation*}L=−jμaμ​−f(jμjμ​​).​(144)​

Here jμj^{\mu}jμ is the current Lorentz vector jμ=(cρ,j)j^{\mu}=(c \rho, \boldsymbol{j})jμ=(cρ,j). The aμa_{\mu}aμ​ comprise a set of auxilliary variables; in the relativistic analog of irrotational fluids we take aμ=∂μθa_{\mu}=\partial_{\mu} \thetaaμ​=∂μ​θ, more generally

aμ=∂μθ+α∂μβ\begin{equation*} a_{\mu}=\partial_{\mu} \theta+\alpha \partial_{\mu} \beta \tag{145} \end{equation*}aμ​=∂μ​θ+α∂μ​β​(145)​

so that the Chern-Simons density of aia_{i}ai​ is a total derivative [compare (56), (57)]. The function fff depends on the Lorentz invariant jμjμ=c2ρ2−j2j^{\mu} j_{\mu}=c^{2} \rho^{2}-j^{2}jμjμ​=c2ρ2−j2 and encodes the specific dyanamics (equation of state).

The energy momentum tensor for L\mathcal{L}L is

θμν=−gμνL+jμjνjαjαf′(jαjα)\begin{equation*} \theta_{\mu \nu}=-g_{\mu \nu} \mathcal{L}+\frac{j_{\mu} j_{\nu}}{\sqrt{j^{\alpha} j_{\alpha}}} f^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{j^{\alpha} j_{\alpha}}\right) \tag{146} \end{equation*}θμν​=−gμν​L+jαjα​​jμ​jν​​f′(jαjα​​)​(146)​

[One way to derive (146) from (144) is to embed that expression in an external metric tensor gμνg_{\mu \nu}gμν​, which is then varied; in the variation jμj^{\mu}jμ and aμa_{\mu}aμ​ are taken to be metric-independent and jμ=gμνjνj_{\mu}=g_{\mu \nu} j^{\nu}jμ​=gμν​jν.] Furthermore, varying jμj^{\mu}jμ in (144) shows that

aμ=−jμjαjαf′(jαjα)\begin{equation*} a_{\mu}=-\frac{j_{\mu}}{\sqrt{j^{\alpha} j_{\alpha}}} f^{\prime}\left(\sqrt{j^{\alpha} j_{\alpha}}\right) \tag{147} \end{equation*}aμ​=−jαjα​​jμ​​f′(jαjα​​)​(147)​

so that (146) becomes

θμν=−gμν[nf′(n)−f(n)]+uμuνnf′(n)\begin{equation*} \theta_{\mu \nu}=-g_{\mu \nu}\left[n f^{\prime}(n)-f(n)\right]+u_{\mu} u_{\nu} n f^{\prime}(n) \tag{148} \end{equation*}θμν​=−gμν​[nf′(n)−f(n)]+uμ​uν​nf′(n)​(148)​

where we have introduced the proper velocity uμu_{\mu}uμ​ by

jμ=nuμuμuμ=1\begin{equation*} j_{\mu}=n u_{\mu} \quad u^{\mu} u_{\mu}=1 \tag{149} \end{equation*}jμ​=nuμ​uμuμ​=1​(149)​

so that nnn is proportional to the proper density and 1/n1 / n1/n is proportional to the specific volume. Eq. (148) identifies the proper energy density eee and the pressure PPP (which coincides with L\mathcal{L}L ) through the conventional formula 28.

θμν=−gμνP+uμuv(P+e)\begin{equation*} \theta_{\mu \nu}=-g_{\mu \nu} P+u_{\mu} u_{v}(P+e) \tag{150} \end{equation*}θμν​=−gμν​P+uμ​uv​(P+e)​(150)​

Therefore, in our case

e=f(n)P=nf′(n)−f(n).\begin{align*} e & =f(n) \tag{151}\\ P & =n f^{\prime}(n)-f(n) . \tag{152} \end{align*}eP​=f(n)=nf′(n)−f(n).​(151)(152)​

The thermodynamic relation involving entropy SSS reads

P d(1n)+d(en)∝dS\begin{equation*} P \mathrm{~d}\left(\frac{1}{n}\right)+\mathrm{d}\left(\frac{e}{n}\right) \propto \mathrm{d} S \tag{153} \end{equation*}P d(n1​)+d(ne​)∝dS​(153)​

where the proportionality constant is determined by the temperature. With (151) and (152) the left side of (153) vanishes and we verify that entropy is constant, that is, we are dealing with an isentropic system, as has been stated in the very beginning.

For the free system, the pressure vanishes, so we choose f(n)=cnf(n)=c nf(n)=cn

L0=−jμaμ−cjμjμ.\begin{equation*} \mathcal{L}_{0}=-j^{\mu} a_{\mu}-c \sqrt{j^{\mu} j_{\mu}} . \tag{154} \end{equation*}L0​=−jμaμ​−cjμjμ​​.​(154)​

In the "irrotational" case, aμ=∂μθa_{\mu}=\partial_{\mu} \thetaaμ​=∂μ​θ, and with j=ρv\boldsymbol{j}=\rho \boldsymbol{v}j=ρv this Lagrange density produces the free Lˉ0Lorentz \bar{L}_{0}^{\text {Lorentz }}Lˉ0Lorentz ​ of (121), (122) (apart from a total time derivative).

For the Born-Infeld theory, we present the pressure PPP in (152) by choosing f(n)=ca2+n2f(n)=c \sqrt{a^{2}+n^{2}}f(n)=ca2+n2​, which corresponds to the pressure P=−a2c/a2+n2P=-a^{2} c / \sqrt{a^{2}+n^{2}}P=−a2c/a2+n2​. When the current is written as

jμ=a∂μθc2−(∂μθ)2\begin{equation*} j_{\mu}=\frac{a \partial_{\mu} \theta}{\sqrt{c^{2}-\left(\partial_{\mu} \theta\right)^{2}}} \tag{155a} \end{equation*}jμ​=c2−(∂μ​θ)2​a∂μ​θ​​(155a)​

so that

n=a(∂μθ)2c2−(∂μθ)2\begin{equation*} n=a \sqrt{\frac{\left(\partial_{\mu} \theta\right)^{2}}{c^{2}-\left(\partial_{\mu} \theta\right)^{2}}} \tag{155b} \end{equation*}n=ac2−(∂μ​θ)2(∂μ​θ)2​​​(155b)​

the Lagrange density

L=P=−a2ca2+n2\begin{equation*} \mathcal{L}=P=-\frac{a^{2} c}{\sqrt{a^{2}+n^{2}}} \tag{155c} \end{equation*}L=P=−a2+n2​a2c​​(155c)​

coincides with that for the Born-Infeld model in eq. (129). Other forms for fff give rise to relativistic fluid mechanics with other equations of state. It is interesting to see how the nonrelativistic limit of θμν\theta^{\mu \nu}θμν in (148) produces TμνT^{\mu \nu}Tμν of (7)-(司). It is especially intriguing to notice that θμν\theta^{\mu \nu}θμν is symmetric but TμνT^{\mu \nu}Tμν is not. To make the connection we recall that uμ=1/1−v2/c2(1,v/c)u^{\mu}=1 / \sqrt{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}(1, \boldsymbol{v} / c)uμ=1/1−v2/c2​(1,v/c), we observe that n=ρ2c2−j2n=\sqrt{\rho^{2} c^{2}-\boldsymbol{j}^{2}}n=ρ2c2−j2​, set j=ρv\boldsymbol{j}=\rho \boldsymbol{v}j=ρv and conclude that n === ρc1−v2/c2∼ρc−(ρv2/2c)\rho c \sqrt{1-v^{2} / c^{2}} \sim \rho c-\left(\rho v^{2} / 2 c\right)ρc1−v2/c2​∼ρc−(ρv2/2c). Also f(n)f(n)f(n) is chosen to be cn+V(n/c)c n+V(n / c)cn+V(n/c), and thus P=P=P= nf′(n)−f(n)=(n/c)V′(n/c)−V(n/c)n f^{\prime}(n)-f(n)=(n / c) V^{\prime}(n / c)-V(n / c)nf′(n)−f(n)=(n/c)V′(n/c)−V(n/c). It follows that

θoo=nc−(v2n/c3)V′1−v2/c2+V≈ρc2−ρv2/21−v2/c2+V(ρ)≈ρc2+ρv22+V(ρ)=ρc2+Too\begin{align*} \theta^{o o} & =\frac{n c-\left(v^{2} n / c^{3}\right) V^{\prime}}{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}+V \approx \frac{\rho c^{2}-\rho v^{2} / 2}{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}+V(\rho) \\ & \approx \rho c^{2}+\frac{\rho v^{2}}{2}+V(\rho)=\rho c^{2}+T^{o o} \tag{156} \end{align*}θoo​=1−v2/c2nc−(v2n/c3)V′​+V≈1−v2/c2ρc2−ρv2/2​+V(ρ)≈ρc2+2ρv2​+V(ρ)=ρc2+Too​(156)​

Thus, apart from the relativistic "rest energy" ρc2,θoo\rho c^{2}, \theta^{o o}ρc2,θoo passes to TooT^{o o}Too. The relativistic energy flux is cθjoc \theta^{j o}cθjo (because ∂∂xμθμo=1cθ˙oo+∂jθjo\frac{\partial}{\partial x^{\mu}} \theta^{\mu o}=\frac{1}{c} \dot{\theta}^{o o}+\partial_{j} \theta^{j o}∂xμ∂​θμo=c1​θ˙oo+∂j​θjo )

cθjo=vj1−v2/c2(nc+ncV′)≈vjρc2−ρv2/2+ρV′(ρ)1−v2/c2≈jjc2+ρvj(v2/2+V′(ρ))=jjc+Tjo.\begin{align*} c \theta^{j o} & =\frac{v^{j}}{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}\left(n c+\frac{n}{c} V^{\prime}\right) \approx v^{j} \frac{\rho c^{2}-\rho v^{2} / 2+\rho V^{\prime}(\rho)}{1-v^{2} / c^{2}} \\ & \approx j^{j} c^{2}+\rho v^{j}\left(v^{2} / 2+V^{\prime}(\rho)\right)=j^{j} c+T^{j o} . \tag{157} \end{align*}cθjo​=1−v2/c2vj​(nc+cn​V′)≈vj1−v2/c2ρc2−ρv2/2+ρV′(ρ)​≈jjc2+ρvj(v2/2+V′(ρ))=jjc+Tjo.​(157)​

Again, apart from the O(c2)O\left(c^{2}\right)O(c2) current, associated with the O(c2)O\left(c^{2}\right)O(c2) rest energy in θoo,Tjo\theta^{o o}, T^{j o}θoo,Tjo is obtained in the limit. The momentum density is θoi/c\theta^{o i} / cθoi/c (because θμν\theta^{\mu \nu}θμν has dimension of energy density). Thus

θoi/c=vi/c21−v2/c2(nc+ncV′)≈ρvi=Pi\begin{equation*} \theta^{o i} / c=\frac{v^{i} / c^{2}}{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}\left(n c+\frac{n}{c} V^{\prime}\right) \approx \rho v^{i}=\mathcal{P}^{i} \tag{158} \end{equation*}θoi/c=1−v2/c2vi/c2​(nc+cn​V′)≈ρvi=Pi​(158)​

Finally, the momentum flux is obtained directly from θij\theta^{i j}θij.

θij=δij(ncV′−V)+vivjc2−v2(nc+ncV′)≈δij(ρV′(ρ)−V(ρ))+vivjρ=Tij\begin{align*} \theta^{i j} & =\delta^{i j}\left(\frac{n}{c} V^{\prime}-V\right)+\frac{v^{i} v^{j}}{c^{2}-v^{2}}\left(n c+\frac{n}{c} V^{\prime}\right) \\ & \approx \delta^{i j}\left(\rho V^{\prime}(\rho)-V(\rho)\right)+v^{i} v^{j} \rho=T^{i j} \tag{159} \end{align*}θij​=δij(cn​V′−V)+c2−v2vivj​(nc+cn​V′)≈δij(ρV′(ρ)−V(ρ))+vivjρ=Tij​(159)​

From the limiting formula n∼ρcn \sim \rho cn∼ρc we also see that the pressure in (155d) tends to the Chaplygin expression −a/ρ-a / \rho−a/ρ.

4 Common Ancestry: The Nambu-Goto Action

The "hidden" symmetries and the associated transformation laws for the Chaplygin and BornInfeld models may be given a coherent setting by considering the Nambu-Goto action for a d-brane in (d+1)(d+1)(d+1) spatial dimensions, moving on (d+1,1)(d+1,1)(d+1,1)-dimensional space-time. In our context, a d-brane is simply a ddd-dimensional extended object: a 1-brane is a string, a 2 -brane is a membrane and so on. A d-brane in (d+1)(d+1)(d+1) space divides that space in two.

The Nambu-Goto action reads

ING=∫dφ0 dφLNG=∫dφ0 dφ1⋯ dφdGG=(−1)ddet⁡∂Xμ∂φα∂Xμ∂φβ\begin{align*} I_{\mathrm{NG}} & =\int \mathrm{d} \varphi^{0} \mathrm{~d} \varphi \mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{NG}}=\int \mathrm{d} \varphi^{0} \mathrm{~d} \varphi^{1} \cdots \mathrm{~d} \varphi^{d} \sqrt{G} \tag{160}\\ G & =(-1)^{d} \operatorname{det} \frac{\partial X^{\mu}}{\partial \varphi^{\alpha}} \frac{\partial X_{\mu}}{\partial \varphi^{\beta}} \tag{161} \end{align*}ING​G​=∫dφ0 dφLNG​=∫dφ0 dφ1⋯ dφdG​=(−1)ddet∂φα∂Xμ​∂φβ∂Xμ​​​(160)(161)​

Here XμX^{\mu}Xμ is a (d+1,1)(d+1,1)(d+1,1) target space-time (d-brane) variable, with μ\muμ extending over the range μ=0,1,…,d,d+1\mu=0,1, \ldots, d, d+1μ=0,1,…,d,d+1. The φα\varphi^{\alpha}φα are "world-volume" variables describing the extended object with α\alphaα ranging α=0,1,…,d;φα,α=1,…,d\alpha=0,1, \ldots, d ; \varphi^{\alpha}, \alpha=1, \ldots, dα=0,1,…,d;φα,α=1,…,d, parameterizes the ddd-dimensional d-brane that evolves in φ0\varphi^{0}φ0.

The Nambu-Goto action is parameterization invariant, and we shall show that two different choices of parameterization ("light-cone" and "Cartesian") lead to the Chaplygin gas and BornInfeld actions, respectively. For both parameterizations we choose (X1,…,Xd)\left(X^{1}, \ldots, X^{d}\right)(X1,…,Xd) to coincide with (φ1,…,φd)\left(\varphi^{1}, \ldots, \varphi^{d}\right)(φ1,…,φd), renaming them as r\boldsymbol{r}r (a ddd-dimensional vector). This is usually called the "static parameterization". (The ability to carry out this parameterization globally presupposes that the extended object is topologically trivial; in the contrary situation, singularities will appear, which are spurious in the sense that they disappear in different parameterizations, and parameterization-invariant quantities are singularity-free.)

4.1 Light-cone parameterization

For the light-cone parameterization we define X±X^{ \pm}X±as 12(X0±Xd+1).X+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(X^{0} \pm X^{d+1}\right) . X^{+}2​1​(X0±Xd+1).X+is renamed ttt and identified with 2λφ0\sqrt{2 \lambda} \varphi^{0}2λ​φ0. This completes the fixing of the parameterization and the remaining variable is X−X^{-}X−, which is a function of φ0\varphi^{0}φ0 and φ\boldsymbol{\varphi}φ, or after redefinitions, of ttt and r.X−\boldsymbol{r} . X^{-}r.X−is renamed as θ(t,r)\theta(t, \boldsymbol{r})θ(t,r) and then the Nambu-Goto action in this parameterization coincides with the Chaplygin gas action IλChaplygin I_{\lambda}^{\text {Chaplygin }}IλChaplygin ​ in (108) (29.

4.2 Cartesian parameterization

For the second, Cartesian parameterization X0X^{0}X0 is renamed ctc tct and identified with cφ0c \varphi^{0}cφ0. The remaining target space variable Xd+1X^{d+1}Xd+1, a function of φ0\varphi^{0}φ0 and φ\boldsymbol{\varphi}φ, equivalently of ttt and r\boldsymbol{r}r, is renamed θ(t,r)/c\theta(t, \boldsymbol{r}) / cθ(t,r)/c. Then the Nambu-Goto action reduces to the Born-Infeld action ∫dtLaBorn-Infeld \int \mathrm{d} t L_{a}^{\text {Born-Infeld }}∫dtLaBorn-Infeld ​, (129) (29].

4.3 Hodographic transformation

There is another derivation of the Chaplygin gas from the Nambu-Goto action that makes use of a hodographic transformation, in which independent and dependent variables are interchanged. Although the derivation is more involved than the light-cone/static parameterization used in Section 4.1 above, the hodographic approach is instructive in that it gives a natural definition for the density ρ\rhoρ, which in the above static parameterization approach is determined from θ\thetaθ by the Bernoulli equation (96).

We again use light-cone combinations: 12(X0+Xd+1)\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(X^{0}+X^{d+1}\right)2​1​(X0+Xd+1) is called τ\tauτ and is identified with φ0\varphi^{0}φ0, while 12(X0−Xd+1)\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(X^{0}-X^{d+1}\right)2​1​(X0−Xd+1) is renamed θ\thetaθ. At this stage the dependent, target-space variables are θ\thetaθ and the transverse coordinates X:Xi,(i=1,…,d)\boldsymbol{X}: X^{i},(i=1, \ldots, d)X:Xi,(i=1,…,d), and all are functions of the worldvolume parameters φ0=τ\varphi^{0}=\tauφ0=τ and φ:φr,(r=1,…,d);∂τ\boldsymbol{\varphi}: \varphi^{r},(r=1, \ldots, d) ; \partial_{\tau}φ:φr,(r=1,…,d);∂τ​ indicates differentiation with respect to τ=φ0\tau=\varphi^{0}τ=φ0, while ∂r\partial_{r}∂r​ denotes derivatives with respect to φr\varphi^{r}φr. The induced metric Gαβ=∂Xμ∂φα∂Xμ∂φβG_{\alpha \beta}=\frac{\partial X^{\mu}}{\partial \varphi^{\alpha}} \frac{\partial X_{\mu}}{\partial \varphi^{\beta}}Gαβ​=∂φα∂Xμ​∂φβ∂Xμ​​ takes the form

Gαβ=(GooGosGro−grs)=(2∂τθ−(∂τX)2∂sθ−∂τX⋅∂sX∂rθ−∂rX⋅∂τX−∂rX⋅∂sX)(162)G_{\alpha \beta}=\left(\begin{array}{cc} G_{o o} & G_{o s} \tag{162}\\ G_{r o} & -g_{r s} \end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc} 2 \partial_{\tau} \theta-\left(\partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X}\right)^{2} & \partial_{s} \theta-\partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X} \cdot \partial_{s} \boldsymbol{X} \\ \partial_{r} \theta-\partial_{r} \boldsymbol{X} \cdot \partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X} & -\partial_{r} \boldsymbol{X} \cdot \partial_{s} \boldsymbol{X} \end{array}\right)Gαβ​=(Goo​Gro​​Gos​−grs​​)=(2∂τ​θ−(∂τ​X)2∂r​θ−∂r​X⋅∂τ​X​∂s​θ−∂τ​X⋅∂s​X−∂r​X⋅∂s​X​)(162)

The Nambu-Goto Lagrangian now leads to the canonical momenta

∂LNG∂∂τX=p∂LNG∂∂τθ=Π\begin{align*} & \frac{\partial \mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{N} G}}{\partial \partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X}}=\boldsymbol{p} \tag{163a}\\ & \frac{\partial \mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{N} G}}{\partial \partial_{\tau} \theta}=\Pi \tag{163b} \end{align*}​∂∂τ​X∂LNG​​=p∂∂τ​θ∂LNG​​=Π​(163a)(163b)​

and can be presented in first-order form as

LNG=p⋅∂τX+Π∂τθ+12Π(p2+g)+ur(p⋅∂rX+Π∂rθ)\begin{equation*} \mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{N} G}=\boldsymbol{p} \cdot \partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X}+\Pi \partial_{\tau} \theta+\frac{1}{2 \Pi}\left(p^{2}+g\right)+u^{r}\left(\boldsymbol{p} \cdot \partial_{r} \boldsymbol{X}+\Pi \partial_{r} \theta\right) \tag{164} \end{equation*}LNG​=p⋅∂τ​X+Π∂τ​θ+2Π1​(p2+g)+ur(p⋅∂r​X+Π∂r​θ)​(164)​

where g=det⁡grsg=\operatorname{det} g_{r s}g=detgrs​ and

ur≡∂τX⋅∂rX−∂rθ\begin{equation*} u_{r} \equiv \partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X} \cdot \partial_{r} \boldsymbol{X}-\partial_{r} \theta \tag{165} \end{equation*}ur​≡∂τ​X⋅∂r​X−∂r​θ​(165)​

acts as a Lagrange multiplier. Evidently the equations of motion are

∂τX=−1Πp−ur∂rX∂τθ=12Π2(p2+g)−ur∂rθ∂τp=−∂r(1Πggrs∂sX)−∂r(urp)∂τΠ=−∂r(urΠ)\begin{align*} \partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X} & =-\frac{1}{\Pi} \boldsymbol{p}-u^{r} \partial_{r} \boldsymbol{X} \tag{166a}\\ \partial_{\tau} \theta & =\frac{1}{2 \Pi^{2}}\left(p^{2}+g\right)-u^{r} \partial_{r} \theta \tag{166b}\\ \partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{p} & =-\partial_{r}\left(\frac{1}{\Pi} g g^{r s} \partial_{s} \boldsymbol{X}\right)-\partial_{r}\left(u^{r} \boldsymbol{p}\right) \tag{166c}\\ \partial_{\tau} \Pi & =-\partial_{r}\left(u^{r} \Pi\right) \tag{166d} \end{align*}∂τ​X∂τ​θ∂τ​p∂τ​Π​=−Π1​p−ur∂r​X=2Π21​(p2+g)−ur∂r​θ=−∂r​(Π1​ggrs∂s​X)−∂r​(urp)=−∂r​(urΠ)​(166a)(166b)(166c)(166d)​

Also there is the constraint

p⋅∂rX+Π∂rθ=0\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{p} \cdot \partial_{r} \boldsymbol{X}+\Pi \partial_{r} \theta=0 \tag{167} \end{equation*}p⋅∂r​X+Π∂r​θ=0​(167)​

[That uru^{r}ur is still given by (165) is a consequence of (166a) and (167).] Here grsg^{r s}grs is inverse to grsg_{r s}grs​, and the two metrics are used to move the (r,s)(r, s)(r,s) indices. The theory still possesses an invariance against redefining the spatial parameters with a τ\tauτ-dependent function of the parameters; infinitesimally: δφr=−fr(τ,φ),δθ=fr∂rθ,δXi=fr∂rXi\delta \varphi^{r}=-f^{r}(\tau, \varphi), \delta \theta=f^{r} \partial_{r} \theta, \delta X^{i}=f^{r} \partial_{r} X^{i}δφr=−fr(τ,φ),δθ=fr∂r​θ,δXi=fr∂r​Xi. This freedom may be used to set uru^{r}ur to zero and Π\PiΠ to -1 .

Next the hodographic transformation is performed: Rather than viewing the dependent variables p,θ\boldsymbol{p}, \thetap,θ, and X\boldsymbol{X}X as functions of τ\tauτ and φ,X(τ,φ)\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{X}(\tau, \boldsymbol{\varphi})φ,X(τ,φ) is inverted so that φ\boldsymbol{\varphi}φ becomes a function of τ\tauτ and X\boldsymbol{X}X (renamed ttt and r\boldsymbol{r}r, respectively), and p\boldsymbol{p}p and θ\thetaθ also become functions of ttt and r\boldsymbol{r}r. It then follows from the chain rule that the constraint (167) (at Π=−1\Pi=-1Π=−1 ) becomes

0=∂Xi∂φr(pi−∂∂Xiθ)\begin{equation*} 0=\frac{\partial X^{i}}{\partial \varphi^{r}}\left(p^{i}-\frac{\partial}{\partial X^{i}} \theta\right) \tag{168} \end{equation*}0=∂φr∂Xi​(pi−∂Xi∂​θ)​(168)​

and is solved by

p=∇θ\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{p}=\nabla \theta \tag{169} \end{equation*}p=∇θ​(169)​

Moreover, according to the chain rule and the implicit function theorem, the partial derivative with respect to τ\tauτ at fixed φ[\varphi[φ[ this derivative is present in (164)] is related to the partial derivative with respect to τ\tauτ at fixed X=r\boldsymbol{X}=\boldsymbol{r}X=r by

∂τ=∂∂t+∇θ⋅∇\begin{equation*} \partial_{\tau}=\frac{\partial}{\partial t}+\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \tag{170} \end{equation*}∂τ​=∂t∂​+∇θ⋅∇​(170)​

where we have used the new name " ttt " on the right. Thus the Nambu-Goto Lagrangian - the φ\varphiφ integral of the Lagrange density (164) (at ur=0,Π=−1u^{r}=0, \Pi=-1ur=0,Π=−1 ) - reads

LNG=∫dφ{p⋅∇θ−θ˙−∇θ⋅∇θ−12(p2+g)}.\begin{equation*} L_{\mathrm{N} G}=\int \mathrm{d} \varphi\left\{\boldsymbol{p} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta-\dot{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta-\frac{1}{2}\left(p^{2}+g\right)\right\} . \tag{171a} \end{equation*}LNG​=∫dφ{p⋅∇θ−θ˙−∇θ⋅∇θ−21​(p2+g)}.​(171a)​

But use of (169) and of the Jacobian relation dφ=drdet⁡∂φs∂X2=dr9\mathrm{d} \varphi=\mathrm{d} r \operatorname{det} \frac{\partial \varphi^{s}}{\partial X^{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{d} r}{\sqrt{9}}dφ=drdet∂X2∂φs​=9​dr​ shows that

LNG=∫dr{−1gθ˙−12g(∇θ)2−12g}.\begin{equation*} L_{N G}=\int \mathrm{d} r\left\{-\frac{1}{\sqrt{g}} \dot{\theta}-\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{g}}(\nabla \theta)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{g}\right\} . \tag{171b} \end{equation*}LNG​=∫dr{−g​1​θ˙−2g​1​(∇θ)2−21​g​}.​(171b)​

With the definition

g=2λ/ρ\begin{equation*} \sqrt{g}=\sqrt{2 \lambda} / \rho \tag{171c} \end{equation*}g​=2λ​/ρ​(171c)​

LNGL_{\mathrm{N} G}LNG​ becomes, apart from a total time derivative

LNG=12λ∫ dr{θρ˙−12ρ(∇θ)2−λρ}.\begin{equation*} L_{\mathrm{N} G}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \lambda}} \int \mathrm{~d} r\left\{\theta \dot{\rho}-\frac{1}{2} \rho(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}-\frac{\lambda}{\rho}\right\} . \tag{171d} \end{equation*}LNG​=2λ​1​∫ dr{θρ˙​−21​ρ(∇θ)2−ρλ​}.​(171d)​

Up to an overall factor, this is just the Chaplygin gas Lagrangian in (95). The present derivation has the advantage of relating the density ρ\rhoρ to the Jacobian of the Xi→φ\boldsymbol{X}^{i} \rightarrow \varphiXi→φ transformation: ρ=2λdet⁡∂φs∂Xi\rho=\sqrt{2 \lambda} \operatorname{det} \frac{\partial \varphi^{s}}{\partial X^{i}}ρ=2λ​det∂Xi∂φs​. (This in turn shows that the hodographic transformation is just exactly the passage from Lagrangian to Eulerian fluid variables - a remark aimed at those who are acquainted with the Lagrange formulation of fluid motion [3].)

Finally, let me observe that the expansion of the Galileo symmetry in (d,1)(d, 1)(d,1) space-time to a Poincaré symmetry in (d+1,1)(d+1,1)(d+1,1) space-time can be understood from a Kaluza-Klein-type framework [30].

4.4 Interrelations

The relation to the Nambu-Goto action explains the origin of the hidden (d+1,1)(d+1,1)(d+1,1) Poincaré group in our two nonlinear models on (d,1)(d, 1)(d,1) space-time: Poincaré invariance is what remains of the reparameterization invariance of the Nambu-Goto action after choosing either the lightcone or Cartesian parameterizations. Also the nonlinear, field dependent form of the transformation laws leading to the additional symmetries is understood: it arises from the identification of some of the dependent variables (Xμ)\left(X^{\mu}\right)(Xμ) with the independent variables (φα)\left(\varphi^{\alpha}\right)(φα).

The complete integrability of the d=1d=1d=1 Chaplygin gas and Born-Infeld model is a consequence of the fact that both descend from a string in 2-space; the associated Nambu-Goto theory being completely integrable. We shall discuss this in Section 6 .

We observe that in addition to the nonrelativistic descent from the Born-Infeld theory to the Chaplygin gas, there exists a mapping of one system on another, and between solutions of one system and the other, because both have the same d-brane ancestor. The mapping is achieved by passing from the light-cone parameterization to the Cartesian, or vice-versa. Specifically this is accomplished as follows:

Chaplygin gas →\rightarrow→ Born-Infeld: Given θNR(t,r)\theta_{N R}(t, \boldsymbol{r})θNR​(t,r), a nonrelativistic solution, determine T(t,r)T(t, \boldsymbol{r})T(t,r) from the equation

T+1c2θNR(T,r)=2t\begin{equation*} T+\frac{1}{c^{2}} \theta_{N R}(T, \boldsymbol{r})=\sqrt{2} t \tag{172} \end{equation*}T+c21​θNR​(T,r)=2​t​(172)​

Then the relativistic solution is

θR(t,r)=12c2T−12θNR(T,r)=c2(2T−t)\begin{equation*} \theta_{R}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} c^{2} T-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \theta_{N R}(T, \boldsymbol{r})=c^{2}(\sqrt{2} T-t) \tag{173} \end{equation*}θR​(t,r)=2​1​c2T−2​1​θNR​(T,r)=c2(2​T−t)​(173)​

Born-Infeld →\rightarrow→ Chaplygin gas: Given θR(t,r)\theta_{R}(t, \boldsymbol{r})θR​(t,r), a relativistic solution, find T(t,r)T(t, \boldsymbol{r})T(t,r) from

T+1c2θR(T,r)=2t\begin{equation*} T+\frac{1}{c^{2}} \theta_{R}(T, \boldsymbol{r})=\sqrt{2} t \tag{174} \end{equation*}T+c21​θR​(T,r)=2​t​(174)​

Then the nonrelativistic solution is

θNR(t,r)=12c2T−12θR(T,r)=c2(2T−t)\begin{equation*} \theta_{N R}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} c^{2} T-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \theta_{R}(T, \boldsymbol{r})=c^{2}(\sqrt{2} T-t) \tag{175} \end{equation*}θNR​(t,r)=2​1​c2T−2​1​θR​(T,r)=c2(2​T−t)​(175)​

The relation between the different models is depicted in the figure below. As a final comment, I recall that the elimination of ρ\rhoρ, both in the nonrelativistic (Chaplygin) and relativistic (Born-Infeld) models is possible only in the presence of interactions. Nevertheless, the θ\thetaθ-dependent ( ρ\rhoρ-independent) resultant Lagrangians contain the interaction strengths only as overall factors; see (108) and (129). It is these θ\thetaθ-dependent Lagrangians that correspond to the Nambu-Goto action in various parameterizations. Let us further recall the the Nambu-Goto action also carries an overall multiplicative factor: the d-brane "tension", which has been suppressed in (160). Correspondingly, for a "tensionless" d-brane, the NambuGoto expression vanishes, and cannot generate dynamics. This suggests that an action for

Dualities and other relations between nonlinear equations. "tensionless" d-branes could be the noninteracting fluid mechanical expressions (95), (127), with vanishing coupling strengths λ\lambdaλ and aaa, respectively. Furthermore, we recall that the noninteracting models retain the higher, dynamical symmetries, appropriate to a d-brane in one higher dimension.

5 Supersymmetric Generalization

Once proven the fact that a bosonic Nambu-Goto theory gives rise to and links together the Chaplygin gas and Born-Infeld models, which are irrotational in that the velocity of the former and the momentum of the latter are given by a gradient of a potential, one can ask whether there is a d-brane that produces a fluid model with nonvanishing vorticity.

We shall show that this indeed can be achieved if one starts with a super-d-brane, and moreover the resulting fluid model possesses supersymmetry. However, since theories of extended "super" objects cannot be formulated in arbitrary dimensions, we shall consider the fluid in two spatial dimensions, namely, on the plane (31].

5.1 Chaplygin gas with Grassmann variables

We begin by positing the fluid model. The Chaplygin gas Lagrangian in (95) is supplemented by Grassmann variables ψa\psi_{a}ψa​ that are Majorana spinors [real, two-component: ψa∗=ψa,a=1,2\psi_{a}^{*}=\psi_{a}, a=1,2ψa∗​=ψa​,a=1,2, (ψ1ψ2)∗=ψ1∗ψ2∗]\left.\left(\psi_{1} \psi_{2}\right)^{*}=\psi_{1}^{*} \psi_{2}^{*}\right](ψ1​ψ2​)∗=ψ1∗​ψ2∗​].

The associated Lagrange density reads

L=−ρ(θ˙−12ψψ˙)−12ρ(∇θ−12ψ∇ψ)2−λρ−2λ2ψα⋅∇ψ.\begin{equation*} \mathcal{L}=-\rho\left(\dot{\theta}-\frac{1}{2} \psi \dot{\psi}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \rho\left(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta-\frac{1}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi\right)^{2}-\frac{\lambda}{\rho}-\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi . \tag{176} \end{equation*}L=−ρ(θ˙−21​ψψ˙​)−21​ρ(∇θ−21​ψ∇ψ)2−ρλ​−22λ​​ψα⋅∇ψ.​(176)​

Here αi\alpha^{i}αi are two ( i=1,2i=1,2i=1,2 ), 2×22 \times 22×2, real symmetric Dirac "alpha" matrices; in terms of Pauli matrices we can take α1=σ1,α2=σ3\alpha^{1}=\sigma^{1}, \alpha^{2}=\sigma^{3}α1=σ1,α2=σ3. Note that the matrices satisfy the following relations, which are needed to verify subsequent formulas

εabαbci=εijαacjαabiαbcj=δijδac−εijεacαabiαcdi=δacδbd−δabδcd+δadδbc\begin{align*} \varepsilon_{a b} \alpha_{b c}^{i} & =\varepsilon^{i j} \alpha_{a c}^{j} \\ \alpha_{a b}^{i} \alpha_{b c}^{j} & =\delta^{i j} \delta_{a c}-\varepsilon^{i j} \varepsilon_{a c} \\ \alpha_{a b}^{i} \alpha_{c d}^{i} & =\delta_{a c} \delta_{b d}-\delta_{a b} \delta_{c d}+\delta_{a d} \delta_{b c} \tag{177} \end{align*}εab​αbci​αabi​αbcj​αabi​αcdi​​=εijαacj​=δijδac​−εijεac​=δac​δbd​−δab​δcd​+δad​δbc​​(177)​

εab\varepsilon_{a b}εab​ is the 2×22 \times 22×2 antisymmetric matrix ε≡iσ2\varepsilon \equiv i \sigma^{2}ε≡iσ2. In equation (176) λ\lambdaλ is a coupling strength which is assumed to be positive. The Grassmann term enters with coupling 2λ\sqrt{2 \lambda}2λ​, which is correlated with the strength of the Chaplygin potential V(ρ)=λ/ρV(\rho)=\lambda / \rhoV(ρ)=λ/ρ in order to ensure supersymmetry, as we shall show below. It is evident that the velocity should be defined as

v=∇θ−12ψ∇ψ\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{v}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta-\frac{1}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi \tag{178} \end{equation*}v=∇θ−21​ψ∇ψ​(178)​

The Grassmann variables directly give rise to a Clebsch formula for v\boldsymbol{v}v, and provide the Gauss potentials. The two-dimensional vorticity reads ω=εij∂ivj=−12εij∂iψ∂jψ=−12∇ψ×\omega=\varepsilon^{i j} \partial_{i} v^{j}=-\frac{1}{2} \varepsilon^{i j} \partial_{i} \psi \partial_{j} \psi=-\frac{1}{2} \nabla \psi \timesω=εij∂i​vj=−21​εij∂i​ψ∂j​ψ=−21​∇ψ× ∇ψ\boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi∇ψ. The variables {θ,ρ}\{\theta, \rho\}{θ,ρ} remain a canonical pair, while the canonical 1-form in (176) indicates that the canonically independent Grassmann variables are ρψ\sqrt{\rho} \psiρ​ψ so that the antibracket of the ψ\psiψ 's is

{ψa(r),ψb(r′)}=−δabρ(r)δ(r−r′)\begin{equation*} \left\{\psi_{a}(\boldsymbol{r}), \psi_{b}\left(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right)\right\}=-\frac{\delta_{a b}}{\rho(\boldsymbol{r})} \delta\left(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right) \tag{179} \end{equation*}{ψa​(r),ψb​(r′)}=−ρ(r)δab​​δ(r−r′)​(179)​

One verifies that the algebra (14) or (16) is satisfied, and further, one has

{θ(r),ψ(r)}=−12ρ(r)ψ(r)δ(r−r′){v(r),ψ(r′)}=−∇ψ(r)ρ(r)δ(r−r′){P(r),ψ(r′)}=−∇ψ(r)δ(r−r′)\begin{align*} \{\theta(\boldsymbol{r}), \psi(\boldsymbol{r})\} & =-\frac{1}{2 \rho(\boldsymbol{r})} \psi(\boldsymbol{r}) \delta\left(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right) \tag{180}\\ \left\{\boldsymbol{v}(\boldsymbol{r}), \psi\left(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right)\right\} & =-\frac{\boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi(\boldsymbol{r})}{\rho(\boldsymbol{r})} \delta\left(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right) \tag{181}\\ \left\{\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{r}), \psi\left(\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right)\right\} & =-\boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi(\boldsymbol{r}) \delta\left(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}^{\prime}\right) \tag{182} \end{align*}{θ(r),ψ(r)}{v(r),ψ(r′)}{P(r),ψ(r′)}​=−2ρ(r)1​ψ(r)δ(r−r′)=−ρ(r)∇ψ(r)​δ(r−r′)=−∇ψ(r)δ(r−r′)​(180)(181)(182)​

The momentum density P\mathcal{P}P is given by the bosonic formula P=ρv\mathcal{P}=\rho \boldsymbol{v}P=ρv, but the Grassmann variables are hidden in v\boldsymbol{v}v, by virtue of (178).

The equations of motion read

ρ˙+∇⋅(ρv)=0θ˙+v⋅∇θ=12v2+λρ2+2λ2ρψα⋅∇ψψ˙+v⋅∇ψ=2λρα⋅∇ψ\begin{align*} \dot{\rho}+\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\rho \boldsymbol{v}) & =0 \tag{183}\\ \dot{\theta}+\boldsymbol{v} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta & =\frac{1}{2} v^{2}+\frac{\lambda}{\rho^{2}}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{2 \rho} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi \tag{184}\\ \dot{\psi}+\boldsymbol{v} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi & =\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\rho} \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi \tag{185} \end{align*}ρ˙​+∇⋅(ρv)θ˙+v⋅∇θψ˙​+v⋅∇ψ​=0=21​v2+ρ2λ​+2ρ2λ​​ψα⋅∇ψ=ρ2λ​​α⋅∇ψ​(183)(184)(185)​

and together with (178) they imply

v˙+v⋅∇v=∇λρ2+2λρ(∇ψ)α⋅∇ψ\begin{equation*} \dot{\boldsymbol{v}}+\boldsymbol{v} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \boldsymbol{v}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \frac{\lambda}{\rho^{2}}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\rho}(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi) \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi \tag{186} \end{equation*}v˙+v⋅∇v=∇ρ2λ​+ρ2λ​​(∇ψ)α⋅∇ψ​(186)​

All these equations may be obtained by bracketing with the Hamiltonian

H=∫d2r(12ρv2+λρ+2λ2ψα⋅∇ψ)=∫d2rH\begin{equation*} H=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r\left(\frac{1}{2} \rho v^{2}+\frac{\lambda}{\rho}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi\right)=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r \mathcal{H} \tag{187} \end{equation*}H=∫d2r(21​ρv2+ρλ​+22λ​​ψα⋅∇ψ)=∫d2rH​(187)​

when (144), (16) as well as (179)-(181) are used. We record the components of the energy-momentum "tensor", and the continuity equations they satisfy. The energy density E=Too\mathcal{E}=T^{o o}E=Too, given by

E=12ρv2+λρ+2λ2ψα⋅∇ψ=Too\begin{equation*} \mathcal{E}=\frac{1}{2} \rho v^{2}+\frac{\lambda}{\rho}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi=T^{o o} \tag{188} \end{equation*}E=21​ρv2+ρλ​+22λ​​ψα⋅∇ψ=Too​(188)​

satisfies a continuity equation with the energy flux TjoT^{j o}Tjo.

Tjo=ρvj(12v2−λρ2)+2λ2ψαjv⋅∇ψ−λρψ∂jψ+λρεjkψε∂kψT˙oo+∂jTjo=0\begin{gather*} T^{j o}=\rho v^{j}\left(\frac{1}{2} v^{2}-\frac{\lambda}{\rho^{2}}\right)+\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{2} \psi \alpha^{j} \boldsymbol{v} \cdot \nabla \psi-\frac{\lambda}{\rho} \psi \partial_{j} \psi+\frac{\lambda}{\rho} \varepsilon^{j k} \psi \varepsilon \partial_{k} \psi \tag{189}\\ \dot{T}^{o o}+\partial_{j} T^{j o}=0 \tag{190} \end{gather*}Tjo=ρvj(21​v2−ρ2λ​)+22λ​​ψαjv⋅∇ψ−ρλ​ψ∂j​ψ+ρλ​εjkψε∂k​ψT˙oo+∂j​Tjo=0​(189)(190)​

This ensures that the total energy, that is, the Hamiltonian, is time-independent. Conservation of the total momentum

P=∫d2rP\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{P}=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r \boldsymbol{\mathcal { P }} \tag{191} \end{equation*}P=∫d2rP​(191)​

follows from the continuity equation satisfied by the momentum density Pi=Toi\mathcal{P}^{i}=T^{o i}Pi=Toi and the momentum flux, that is, the stress tensor TijT^{i j}Tij.

Tji=ρvivj−δij(2λρ+2λ2ψα⋅∇ψ)+2λ2ψαj∂iψT˙oi+∂jTji=0\begin{gather*} T^{j i}=\rho v^{i} v^{j}-\delta^{i j}\left(\frac{2 \lambda}{\rho}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \nabla \psi\right)+\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{2} \psi \alpha^{j} \partial_{i} \psi \tag{192}\\ \dot{T}^{o i}+\partial_{j} T^{j i}=0 \tag{193} \end{gather*}Tji=ρvivj−δij(ρ2λ​+22λ​​ψα⋅∇ψ)+22λ​​ψαj∂i​ψT˙oi+∂j​Tji=0​(192)(193)​

But TijT^{i j}Tij is not symmetric in its spatial indices, owing to the presence of spin in the problem. However, rotational symmetry makes it possible to effect an "improvement", which modifies the momentum density by a total derivative term, leaving the integrated total momentum unchanged (provided surface terms can be ignored) and rendering the stress tensor symmetric. The improved quantities are

PIi=TIoi=ρvi+18εij∂j(ρψεψ)TIij=ρvivj−δij(2λρ+2λ2ψα⋅∇ψ)+2λ4(ψαi∂jψ+ψαj∂iψ)−18∂k[(εkivj+εkjvi)ρψεψ]T˙Ioi+∂jTIij=0.\begin{gather*} \mathcal{P}_{I}^{i}=T_{I}^{o i}=\rho v^{i}+\frac{1}{8} \varepsilon^{i j} \partial_{j}(\rho \psi \varepsilon \psi) \tag{194}\\ T_{I}^{i j}=\rho v^{i} v^{j}-\delta^{i j}\left(\frac{2 \lambda}{\rho}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi\right)+\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{4}\left(\psi \alpha^{i} \partial_{j} \psi+\psi \alpha^{j} \partial_{i} \psi\right) \\ -\frac{1}{8} \partial_{k}\left[\left(\varepsilon^{k i} v^{j}+\varepsilon^{k j} v^{i}\right) \rho \psi \varepsilon \psi\right] \tag{195}\\ \dot{T}_{I}^{o i}+\partial_{j} T_{I}^{i j}=0 . \tag{196} \end{gather*}PIi​=TIoi​=ρvi+81​εij∂j​(ρψεψ)TIij​=ρvivj−δij(ρ2λ​+22λ​​ψα⋅∇ψ)+42λ​​(ψαi∂j​ψ+ψαj∂i​ψ)−81​∂k​[(εkivj+εkjvi)ρψεψ]T˙Ioi​+∂j​TIij​=0.​(194)(195)(196)​

It immediately follows from the symmetry of TIijT_{I}^{i j}TIij​ that the angular momentum

M=∫d2rεijriPIj=∫d2rρεijrivj+14∫ d2rρψεψ\begin{equation*} M=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r \varepsilon^{i j} r^{i} \mathcal{P}_{I}^{j}=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r \rho \varepsilon^{i j} r^{i} v^{j}+\frac{1}{4} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} r \rho \psi \varepsilon \psi \tag{197} \end{equation*}M=∫d2rεijriPIj​=∫d2rρεijrivj+41​∫ d2rρψεψ​(197)​

is conserved. The first term is clearly the orbital part (which still receives a Grassmann contribution through v\boldsymbol{v}v ), whereas the second, coming from the improvement, is the spin part. Indeed, since i2ε=12σ2≡Σ\frac{i}{2} \varepsilon=\frac{1}{2} \sigma^{2} \equiv \Sigma2i​ε=21​σ2≡Σ, we recognize this as the spin matrix in (2+1) dimensions. The extra term in the improved momentum density (194), 18εij∂j(ρψεψ)\frac{1}{8} \varepsilon^{i j} \partial_{j}(\rho \psi \varepsilon \psi)81​εij∂j​(ρψεψ), can then be readily interpreted as an additional localized momentum density, generated by the nonhomogeneity of the spin density. This is analogous to the magnetostatics formula giving the localized current density jm\boldsymbol{j}_{m}jm​ in a magnet in terms of its magnetization m:jm=∇×m\boldsymbol{m}: \boldsymbol{j}_{m}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{m}m:jm​=∇×m. All in all, we are describing a fluid with spin.

Also the total number

N=∫d2rρ\begin{equation*} N=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r \rho \tag{198} \end{equation*}N=∫d2rρ​(198)​

is conserved by virtue of the continuity equation (183) satisfied by ρ\rhoρ. Finally, the theory is Galileo invariant, as is seen from the conservation of the Galileo boost,

B=tP−∫d2rrρ\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{B}=t \boldsymbol{P}-\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r \boldsymbol{r} \rho \tag{199} \end{equation*}B=tP−∫d2rrρ​(199)​

which follows from (183) and (191). The generators H,P,M,BH, \boldsymbol{P}, M, \boldsymbol{B}H,P,M,B and NNN close on the (extended) Galileo group. [The theory is not Lorentz invariant in (2+1)(2+1)(2+1)-dimensional space-time, hence the energy flux TjoT^{j o}Tjo does not coincide with the momentum density, improved or not.]

We observe that ρ\rhoρ can be eliminated from (176) so that L\mathcal{L}L involves only θ\thetaθ and ψ\psiψ. From (184) and (185) it follows that

ρ=λ(θ˙−12ψψ˙+12v2)−1/2.\begin{equation*} \rho=\sqrt{\lambda}\left(\dot{\theta}-\frac{1}{2} \psi \dot{\psi}+\frac{1}{2} v^{2}\right)^{-1 / 2} . \tag{200} \end{equation*}ρ=λ​(θ˙−21​ψψ˙​+21​v2)−1/2.​(200)​

Substituting into (176) produces the supersymmetric generalization of the Chaplygin gas Lagrange density in (108).

L=−2λ{2θ˙−ψψ˙+(∇θ−12ψ∇ψ)2+12ψα⋅∇ψ}\begin{equation*} \mathcal{L}=-2 \sqrt{\lambda}\left\{\sqrt{2 \dot{\theta}-\psi \dot{\psi}+\left(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta-\frac{1}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi\right)^{2}}+\frac{1}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi\right\} \tag{201} \end{equation*}L=−2λ​⎩⎨⎧​2θ˙−ψψ˙​+(∇θ−21​ψ∇ψ)2​+21​ψα⋅∇ψ⎭⎬⎫​​(201)​

Note that the coupling strength has disappeared from the dynamical equations, remaining only as a normalization factor for the Lagrangian. Consequently the above elimination of ρ\rhoρ cannot be carried out in the free case, λ=0\lambda=0λ=0.

5.2 Supersymmetry

As we said earlier, this theory possesses supersymmetry. This can be established, first of all, by verifying that the following two-component supercharges are time-independent Grassmann quantities.

Qa=∫d2r[ρv⋅(αabψb)+2λψa]\begin{equation*} Q_{a}=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r\left[\rho \boldsymbol{v} \cdot\left(\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{a b} \psi_{b}\right)+\sqrt{2 \lambda} \psi_{a}\right] \tag{202} \end{equation*}Qa​=∫d2r[ρv⋅(αab​ψb​)+2λ​ψa​]​(202)​

Taking a time derivative and using the evolution equations (183)-(186) establishes that Q˙a=0\dot{Q}_{a}=0Q˙​a​=0. Next, the supersymmetric transformation rule for the dynamical variables is found by constructing a bosonic symmetry generator QQQ, obtained by contracting the Grassmann charge with a constant Grassmann parameter ηa,Q=ηaQa\eta^{a}, Q=\eta^{a} Q_{a}ηa,Q=ηaQa​, and commuting with the dynamical variables. Using the canonical brackets one verifies the following field transformation rules:

δρ={Q,ρ}=−∇⋅ρ(ηαψ)δθ={Q,θ}=−12(ηαψ)⋅∇θ−14(ηαψ)⋅ψ∇ψ+2λ2ρηψδψ={Q,ψ}=−(ηαψ)⋅∇ψ−v⋅αη−2λρηδv={Q,v}=−(ηαψ)⋅∇v+2λρη∇ψ.\begin{align*} & \delta \rho=\{Q, \rho\}=-\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \rho(\eta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \psi) \tag{203}\\ & \delta \theta=\{Q, \theta\}=-\frac{1}{2}(\eta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \psi) \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta-\frac{1}{4}(\eta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \psi) \cdot \psi \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi+\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{2 \rho} \eta \psi \tag{204}\\ & \delta \psi=\{Q, \psi\}=-(\eta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \psi) \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi-\boldsymbol{v} \cdot \boldsymbol{\alpha} \eta-\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\rho} \eta \tag{205}\\ & \delta \boldsymbol{v}=\{Q, \boldsymbol{v}\}=-(\eta \boldsymbol{\alpha} \psi) \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \boldsymbol{v}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\rho} \eta \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi . \tag{206} \end{align*}​δρ={Q,ρ}=−∇⋅ρ(ηαψ)δθ={Q,θ}=−21​(ηαψ)⋅∇θ−41​(ηαψ)⋅ψ∇ψ+2ρ2λ​​ηψδψ={Q,ψ}=−(ηαψ)⋅∇ψ−v⋅αη−ρ2λ​​ηδv={Q,v}=−(ηαψ)⋅∇v+ρ2λ​​η∇ψ.​(203)(204)(205)(206)​

Supersymmetry is reestablished by determining the variation of the action ∫dt d2rL\int \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d}^{2} r \mathcal{L}∫dt d2rL consequent to the above field variations: the action is invariant. One then reconstructs the supercharges (202) by Noether's theorem. Finally, upon computing the bracket of two supercharges, one finds

{η1aQa,η2bQb}=2(η1η2)H\begin{equation*} \left\{\eta_{1}^{a} Q_{a}, \eta_{2}^{b} Q_{b}\right\}=2\left(\eta_{1} \eta_{2}\right) H \tag{207} \end{equation*}{η1a​Qa​,η2b​Qb​}=2(η1​η2​)H​(207)​

which again confirms that the charges are time-independent:

{H,Qa}=0\begin{equation*} \left\{H, Q_{a}\right\}=0 \tag{208} \end{equation*}{H,Qa​}=0​(208)​

Additionally a further, kinematical, supersymmetry can be identified. According to the equations of motion the following two supercharges are also time-independent:

Qˉa=∫d2rρψa\begin{equation*} \bar{Q}_{a}=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r \rho \psi_{a} \tag{209} \end{equation*}Qˉ​a​=∫d2rρψa​​(209)​

Qˉ=ηˉaQˉa\bar{Q}=\bar{\eta}^{a} \bar{Q}_{a}Qˉ​=ηˉ​aQˉ​a​ effects a shift of the Grassmann field:

δˉρ={Qˉ,ρ}δˉθ={Qˉ,θ}δˉψ={Qˉ,−12(ηˉψ)δˉv={Qˉ,v}=−ηˉ=0.\begin{align*} \bar{\delta} \rho & =\{\bar{Q}, \rho\} \tag{210}\\ \bar{\delta} \theta & =\{\bar{Q}, \theta\} \tag{211}\\ \bar{\delta} \psi & =\left\{\bar{Q},-\frac{1}{2}(\bar{\eta} \psi)\right. \tag{212}\\ \bar{\delta} \boldsymbol{v} & =\{\bar{Q}, \boldsymbol{v}\} \tag{213}\\ =-\bar{\eta} & =0 . \end{align*}δˉρδˉθδˉψδˉv=−ηˉ​​={Qˉ​,ρ}={Qˉ​,θ}={Qˉ​,−21​(ηˉ​ψ)={Qˉ​,v}=0.​(210)(211)(212)(213)​

This transformation leaves the Lagrangian invariant, and Noether's theorem reproduces (209). The algebra of these charges closes on the total number NNN.

{ηˉ1aQˉa,ηˉ2bQˉb}=(ηˉ1ηˉ2)N\begin{equation*} \left\{\bar{\eta}_{1}^{a} \bar{Q}_{a}, \bar{\eta}_{2}^{b} \bar{Q}_{b}\right\}=\left(\bar{\eta}_{1} \bar{\eta}_{2}\right) N \tag{214} \end{equation*}{ηˉ​1a​Qˉ​a​,ηˉ​2b​Qˉ​b​}=(ηˉ​1​ηˉ​2​)N​(214)​

while the algebra with the generators (202), closes on the total momentum, together with a central extension, proportional to volume of space Ω=∫d2r\Omega=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} rΩ=∫d2r

{ηˉaQˉa,ηbQb}=(ηˉαη)⋅P+2λ(ηˉεη)Ω.\begin{equation*} \left\{\bar{\eta}^{a} \bar{Q}_{a}, \eta^{b} Q_{b}\right\}=(\bar{\eta} \boldsymbol{\alpha} \eta) \cdot \boldsymbol{P}+\sqrt{2 \lambda}(\bar{\eta} \varepsilon \eta) \Omega . \tag{215} \end{equation*}{ηˉ​aQˉ​a​,ηbQb​}=(ηˉ​αη)⋅P+2λ​(ηˉ​εη)Ω.​(215)​

The supercharges Qa,QˉaQ_{a}, \bar{Q}_{a}Qa​,Qˉ​a​, together with the Galileo generators (H,P,M(H, \boldsymbol{P}, M(H,P,M, and B)\boldsymbol{B})B), with NNN form a superextended Galileo algebra. The additional, nonvanishing brackets are

{M,Qa}=12εabQb{M,Qˉa}=12εabQˉb{B,Qa}=αabQˉb.\begin{align*} & \left\{M, Q_{a}\right\}=\frac{1}{2} \varepsilon^{a b} Q_{b} \tag{216}\\ & \left\{M, \bar{Q}_{a}\right\}=\frac{1}{2} \varepsilon^{a b} \bar{Q}_{b} \tag{217}\\ & \left\{\boldsymbol{B}, Q_{a}\right\}=\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{a b} \bar{Q}_{b} . \tag{218} \end{align*}​{M,Qa​}=21​εabQb​{M,Qˉ​a​}=21​εabQˉ​b​{B,Qa​}=αab​Qˉ​b​.​(216)(217)(218)​

5.3 Supermembrane Connection

The equations for the supersymmetric Chaplygin fluid devolve from a supermembrane Lagrangian, LML_{M}LM​. We shall give two different derivations of this result, which make use of two different parameterizations for the parameterization-invariant membrane action and give rise, respectively, to (176) and (201). The two derivations follow what has been done in the bosonic case in Sections 4.1 and 4.3 .

We work in a light-cone gauge-fixed theory: The supermembrane in 4-dimensional spacetime is described by coordinates Xμ(μ=0,1,2,3)X^{\mu}(\mu=0,1,2,3)Xμ(μ=0,1,2,3), which are decomposed into light-cone components X±=12(X0±X3)X^{ \pm}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(X^{0} \pm X^{3}\right)X±=2​1​(X0±X3) and transverse components Xi{i=1,2}X^{i}\{i=1,2\}Xi{i=1,2}. These depend on an evolution parameter φ0≡τ\varphi^{0} \equiv \tauφ0≡τ and two space-like parameters φr{r=1,2}\varphi^{r}\{r=1,2\}φr{r=1,2}. Additionally there are two-component, real Grassmann spinors ψ\psiψ, which also depend on τ\tauτ and φr\varphi^{r}φr. In the lightcone gauge, X+X^{+}X+is identified with τ,X−\tau, X^{-}τ,X−is renamed θ\thetaθ, and the supermembrane Lagrangian is (32]

LM=∫d2φLM=−∫d2φ{G−12εrs∂rψα∂sψ⋅X}\begin{equation*} L_{M}=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \varphi \mathcal{L}_{M}=-\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \varphi\left\{\sqrt{G}-\frac{1}{2} \varepsilon^{r s} \partial_{r} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \partial_{s} \psi \cdot \boldsymbol{X}\right\} \tag{219} \end{equation*}LM​=∫d2φLM​=−∫d2φ{G​−21​εrs∂r​ψα∂s​ψ⋅X}​(219)​

where G=det⁡GαβG=\operatorname{det} G_{\alpha \beta}G=detGαβ​;

Gαβ=(GooGosGro−grs)=(2∂τθ−(∂τX)2−ψ∂τψusur−grs)G=gΓΓ≡2∂τθ−(∂τX)2−ψ∂τψ+grsurusgrs≡∂rX⋅∂sX,g=det⁡grsus≡∂sθ−12ψ∂sψ−∂τX⋅∂sX.\begin{align*} G_{\alpha \beta} & =\left(\begin{array}{cc} G_{o o} & G_{o s} \\ G_{r o} & -g_{r s} \end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cr} 2 \partial_{\tau} \theta-\left(\partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X}\right)^{2}-\psi \partial_{\tau} \psi & u_{s} \\ u_{r} & -g_{r s} \end{array}\right) \tag{220}\\ G & =g \Gamma \\ \Gamma & \equiv 2 \partial_{\tau} \theta-\left(\partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X}\right)^{2}-\psi \partial_{\tau} \psi+g^{r s} u_{r} u_{s} \\ g_{r s} & \equiv \partial_{r} \boldsymbol{X} \cdot \partial_{s} \boldsymbol{X}, \quad g=\operatorname{det} g_{r s} \\ u_{s} & \equiv \partial_{s} \theta-\frac{1}{2} \psi \partial_{s} \psi-\partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X} \cdot \partial_{s} \boldsymbol{X} . \tag{221} \end{align*}Gαβ​GΓgrs​us​​=(Goo​Gro​​Gos​−grs​​)=(2∂τ​θ−(∂τ​X)2−ψ∂τ​ψur​​us​−grs​​)=gΓ≡2∂τ​θ−(∂τ​X)2−ψ∂τ​ψ+grsur​us​≡∂r​X⋅∂s​X,g=detgrs​≡∂s​θ−21​ψ∂s​ψ−∂τ​X⋅∂s​X.​(220)(221)​

Here ∂τ\partial_{\tau}∂τ​ signifies differentiation with respect to the evolution parameter τ\tauτ, while ∂r\partial_{r}∂r​ differentiates with respect to the space-like parameters φr;grs\varphi^{r} ; g^{r s}φr;grs is the inverse of grsg_{r s}grs​, and the two are used to move the (r,s)(r, s)(r,s) indices. Note that the dimensionality of the transverse coordinates XiX^{i}Xi is the same as of the parameters φr\varphi^{r}φr, namely two.

5.4 Hodographic transformation

To give our first derivation following the procedure in Section 4.3, we rewrite the Lagrangian in canonical, first-order form, with the help of bosonic canonical momenta defined by

∂LM∂∂τX=p=−Π∂τX−Πur∂rX∂LM∂∂τθ=Π=g/Γ.\begin{align*} \frac{\partial \mathcal{L}_{M}}{\partial \partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X}} & =\boldsymbol{p}=-\Pi \partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X}-\Pi u^{r} \partial_{r} \boldsymbol{X} \tag{222a}\\ \frac{\partial \mathcal{L}_{M}}{\partial \partial_{\tau} \theta} & =\Pi=\sqrt{g / \Gamma} . \tag{222b} \end{align*}∂∂τ​X∂LM​​∂∂τ​θ∂LM​​​=p=−Π∂τ​X−Πur∂r​X=Π=g/Γ​.​(222a)(222b)​

(The Grassmann variables already enter with first-order derivatives.) The supersymmetric extension of (164) then reads

LM=p⋅∂τX+Π∂τθ−12Πψ∂τψ+12Π(p2+g)+12εrs∂rψα∂sψ⋅X+ur(p⋅∂rX+Π∂rθ−12Πψ∂rψ).\begin{align*} \mathcal{L}_{M}= & \boldsymbol{p} \cdot \partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X}+\Pi \partial_{\tau} \theta-\frac{1}{2} \Pi \psi \partial_{\tau} \psi+\frac{1}{2 \Pi}\left(p^{2}+g\right)+\frac{1}{2} \varepsilon^{r s} \partial_{r} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \partial_{s} \psi \cdot \boldsymbol{X} \\ & +u^{r}\left(\boldsymbol{p} \cdot \partial_{r} \boldsymbol{X}+\Pi \partial_{r} \theta-\frac{1}{2} \Pi \psi \partial_{r} \psi\right) . \tag{223} \end{align*}LM​=​p⋅∂τ​X+Π∂τ​θ−21​Πψ∂τ​ψ+2Π1​(p2+g)+21​εrs∂r​ψα∂s​ψ⋅X+ur(p⋅∂r​X+Π∂r​θ−21​Πψ∂r​ψ).​(223)​

In (223) uru^{r}ur serves as a Lagrange multiplier enforcing a subsidiary condition on the canonical variables, and g=det⁡grsg=\operatorname{det} g_{r s}g=detgrs​. The equations that follow from (223) coincide with the EulerLagrange equations for (219). The theory still possesses an invariance against redefining the spatial parameters with a τ\tauτ-dependent function of the parameters. This freedom may be used to set uτu_{\tau}uτ​ to zero and fix Π\PiΠ at -1 . Next we introduce the hodographic transformation, as in Section 4.3, whereby independent-dependent variables are interchanged, namely we view the φr\varphi^{r}φr to be functions of XiX^{i}Xi. It then follows that the constraint on (223), which with Π=−1\Pi=-1Π=−1 reads

p⋅∂rX−∂rθ+12ψ∂rψ=0\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{p} \cdot \partial_{r} \boldsymbol{X}-\partial_{r} \theta+\frac{1}{2} \psi \partial_{r} \psi=0 \tag{224} \end{equation*}p⋅∂r​X−∂r​θ+21​ψ∂r​ψ=0​(224)​

becomes

∂rX⋅(p−∇θ+12ψ∇ψ)=0.\begin{equation*} \partial_{r} \boldsymbol{X} \cdot\left(\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta+\frac{1}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi\right)=0 . \tag{225} \end{equation*}∂r​X⋅(p−∇θ+21​ψ∇ψ)=0.​(225)​

Here p,θ\boldsymbol{p}, \thetap,θ and ψ\psiψ are viewed as functions of X\boldsymbol{X}X, renamed r\boldsymbol{r}r, with respect to which acts the gradient ∇\boldsymbol{\nabla}∇. Also we rename p\boldsymbol{p}p as v\boldsymbol{v}v, which according to (225) is

v=∇θ−12ψ∇ψ\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{v}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta-\frac{1}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi \tag{226} \end{equation*}v=∇θ−21​ψ∇ψ​(226)​

As in Section 4.3, from the chain rule and the implicit function theorem it follows that

∂τ=∂t+∂τX⋅∇\begin{equation*} \partial_{\tau}=\partial_{t}+\partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \tag{227} \end{equation*}∂τ​=∂t​+∂τ​X⋅∇​(227)​

and according to (222a) (at Π=−1,ur=0\Pi=-1, u^{r}=0Π=−1,ur=0 ) ∂τX=p=v\partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X}=\boldsymbol{p}=\boldsymbol{v}∂τ​X=p=v. Finally, the measure transforms according to d2φ→ d2r19\mathrm{d}^{2} \varphi \rightarrow \mathrm{~d}^{2} r \frac{1}{\sqrt{9}}d2φ→ d2r9​1​. Thus the Lagrangian for (223) becomes, after setting uru^{r}ur to zero and Π\PiΠ to -1 ,

LM=∫d2rg(v2−θ˙−v⋅∇θ+12ψ(ψ˙+v⋅∇ψ)−12(v2+g)−12εrsψαi∂jψ∂sxj∂rxi)\begin{align*} L_{M}=\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} r}{\sqrt{g}}\left(v^{2}-\dot{\theta}-\boldsymbol{v} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta+\right. & \frac{1}{2} \psi(\dot{\psi}+\boldsymbol{v} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi)-\frac{1}{2}\left(v^{2}+g\right) \\ & \left.-\frac{1}{2} \varepsilon^{r s} \psi \alpha^{i} \partial_{j} \psi \partial_{s} x^{j} \partial_{r} x^{i}\right) \tag{228a} \end{align*}LM​=∫g​d2r​(v2−θ˙−v⋅∇θ+​21​ψ(ψ˙​+v⋅∇ψ)−21​(v2+g)−21​εrsψαi∂j​ψ∂s​xj∂r​xi)​(228a)​

But εrs∂sxj∂rxi=εijdet⁡∂rxi=εijg\varepsilon^{r s} \partial_{s} x^{j} \partial_{r} x^{i}=\varepsilon^{i j} \operatorname{det} \partial_{r} x^{i}=\varepsilon^{i j} \sqrt{g}εrs∂s​xj∂r​xi=εijdet∂r​xi=εijg​. After g\sqrt{g}g​ is renamed 2λ/ρ\sqrt{2 \lambda} / \rho2λ​/ρ, (228a) finally reads

LM=12λ∫ d2r(−ρ(θ˙−12ψψ˙)−12ρ(∇θ−12ψ∇ψ)2−λρ−2λ2ψα×∇ψ).\begin{equation*} L_{M}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \lambda}} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} r\left(-\rho\left(\dot{\theta}-\frac{1}{2} \psi \dot{\psi}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \rho\left(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta-\frac{1}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi\right)^{2}-\frac{\lambda}{\rho}-\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \times \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi\right) . \tag{228b} \end{equation*}LM​=2λ​1​∫ d2r(−ρ(θ˙−21​ψψ˙​)−21​ρ(∇θ−21​ψ∇ψ)2−ρλ​−22λ​​ψα×∇ψ).​(228b)​

Upon replacing ψ\psiψ by 12(1−ε)ψ\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1-\varepsilon) \psi2​1​(1−ε)ψ, this is seen to reproduce the Lagrange density (176), apart from an overall factor.

5.5 Light-cone parameterization

For our second derivation, we return to (219)-(221) and use the remaining reparameterization freedom to equate the two XiX^{i}Xi variables with the two φr\varphi^{r}φr variables, renaming both as rir^{i}ri. Also τ\tauτ is renamed as ttt. This parallels the method in Section 4.1. Now in (219)-(221) grs=δrsg_{r s}=\delta_{r s}grs​=δrs​, and ∂τX=0\partial_{\tau} \boldsymbol{X}=0∂τ​X=0, so that (221) becomes simply

G=Γ=2θ˙−ψψ˙+u2u=∇θ−12ψ∇ψ\begin{align*} G=\Gamma & =2 \dot{\theta}-\psi \dot{\psi}+u^{2} \tag{229}\\ \boldsymbol{u} & =\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta-\frac{1}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi \tag{230} \end{align*}G=Γu​=2θ˙−ψψ˙​+u2=∇θ−21​ψ∇ψ​(229)(230)​

Therefore the supermembrane Lagrangian (219) reads

LM=−∫d2r{2θ˙−ψψ˙+(∇θ−12ψ∇ψ)2+12ψα×∇ψ}.\begin{equation*} L_{M}=-\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r\left\{\sqrt{2 \dot{\theta}-\psi \dot{\psi}+\left(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta-\frac{1}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi\right)^{2}}+\frac{1}{2} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \times \boldsymbol{\nabla} \psi\right\} . \tag{231} \end{equation*}LM​=−∫d2r⎩⎨⎧​2θ˙−ψψ˙​+(∇θ−21​ψ∇ψ)2​+21​ψα×∇ψ⎭⎬⎫​.​(231)​

Again a replacement of ψ\psiψ by 12(1−ε)ψ\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(1-\varepsilon) \psi2​1​(1−ε)ψ demonstrates that the integrand coincides with the Lagrange density in (201) (apart from a normalization factor).

5.6 Further consequences of the supermembrane connection

Supermembrane dynamics is Poincaré invariant in (3+1)-dimensional space-time. This invariance is hidden by the choice of light-cone parameterization: only the light-cone subgroup of the Poincaré group is left as a manifest invariance. This is just the (2+1)(2+1)(2+1) Galileo group generated by H,P,M,BH, \boldsymbol{P}, M, \boldsymbol{B}H,P,M,B, and NNN. (The light-cone subgroup of the Poincaré group is isomorphic to the Galileo group in one lower dimension [33].) The Poincaré generators not included in the above list correspond to Lorentz transformations in the "-" direction. We expect therefore that these generators are "dynamical", that is, hidden and unexpected conserved quantities of our supersymmetric Chaplygin gas, similar to the situation with the purely bosonic model.

One verifies that the following quantities

D=tH−∫d2rρθG=∫d2r(rH−θPI−18ψαα⋅PIψ)=∫d2r(rH−θP−14ψαα⋅Pψ)\begin{align*} D & =t H-\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r \rho \theta \tag{232}\\ \boldsymbol{G} & =\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r\left(\boldsymbol{r} \mathcal{H}-\theta \boldsymbol{\mathcal { P }}_{I}-\frac{1}{8} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \mathcal{P}_{I} \psi\right) \\ & =\int \mathrm{d}^{2} r\left(\boldsymbol{r} \mathcal{H}-\theta \boldsymbol{\mathcal { P }}-\frac{1}{4} \psi \boldsymbol{\alpha} \boldsymbol{\alpha} \cdot \boldsymbol{\mathcal { P }} \psi\right) \tag{233} \end{align*}DG​=tH−∫d2rρθ=∫d2r(rH−θPI​−81​ψαα⋅PI​ψ)=∫d2r(rH−θP−41​ψαα⋅Pψ)​(232)(233)​

are time-independent by virtue of the equations of motion (183)-(186), and they supplement the Galileo generators to form the full (3+1)(3+1)(3+1) Poincare algebra, which becomes the superPoincaré algebra once the supersymmetry is taken into account. Evidently (232), (233) are the supersymmetric generalizations of (105), 106).

We see that fluid dynamics can be extended to include Grassmann variables, which also enter in a supersymmetry-preserving interaction. Since our construction is based on a supermembrane in (3+1)(3+1)(3+1)-dimensional space-time, the fluid model is necessarily a planar Chaplygin gas. It remains for the future to show how this construction could be generalized to arbitrary dimensions and to different interactions. Note that Grassmann Gauss potentials ψ\psiψ can be used even in the absence of supersymmetry. For example, our theory (176), with the last term omitted, posseses a conventional, bosonic Hamiltonian without supersymmetry, while the Grassmann variables are hidden in v\boldsymbol{v}v and occur only in the canonical 1-form.

6 One-dimensional Case

In this section, I shall discuss the nonrelativistic/relativistic models in one spatial dimension. Complete integrability has been established for both the Chaplygin gas 34 and the Born-Infeld theory [35]. We can now understand this to be a consequence of the complete integrability of the Nambu-Goto 1-brane (string) moving on 2-space (plane), which is the antecedent of both models. [Therefore, it suffices to discuss only the Chaplygin gas since solutions of the Born-Infeld model can then be obtained by the mapping (172)-(173).]

As remarked previously, in one dimension there is no vorticity, and the nonrelativistic velocity vvv can be presented as a derivative with respect to the single spatial variable of a potential θ\thetaθ. Similarly, the relativistic momentum p=v/1−v2/c2p=v / \sqrt{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}p=v/1−v2/c2​ is a derivative of a potential θ\thetaθ. In both cases the potential is canonically conjugate to the density ρ\rhoρ governed by the canonical 1-form ∫dxθρ˙\int \mathrm{d} x \theta \dot{\rho}∫dxθρ˙​. Moreover, it is evident that at the expense of a spatial nonlocality, one may replace θ\thetaθ by its antiderivative, which is ppp both nonrelativistically and relativistically (nonrelativistically p=vp=vp=v ), so that in both cases the Lagrangian reads

L=−12∫ dx dyρ(x)ε(x−y)p˙(y)−H\begin{equation*} L=-\frac{1}{2} \int \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} y \rho(x) \varepsilon(x-y) \dot{p}(y)-H \tag{234} \end{equation*}L=−21​∫ dx dyρ(x)ε(x−y)p˙​(y)−H​(234)​

For the Chaplygin gas and the Born-Infeld models, HHH is given respectively by

HChaplygin =∫dx(12ρp2+λρ)HBorn-Infeld =∫dx(ρ2c2+a2c2+p2)\begin{align*} H^{\text {Chaplygin }} & =\int \mathrm{d} x\left(\frac{1}{2} \rho p^{2}+\frac{\lambda}{\rho}\right) \tag{235}\\ H^{\text {Born-Infeld }} & =\int \mathrm{d} x\left(\sqrt{\rho^{2} c^{2}+a^{2}} \sqrt{c^{2}+p^{2}}\right) \tag{236} \end{align*}HChaplygin HBorn-Infeld ​=∫dx(21​ρp2+ρλ​)=∫dx(ρ2c2+a2​c2+p2​)​(235)(236)​

The equations of motion are, respectively

 Chaplygin gas: ρ˙+∂∂x(pρ)=0 or ∂∂tp˙+∂∂x(p22−λρ2)θ˙+p22+∂∂xpθ˙+p22=0 Born-Infeld model: ρ˙+∂∂x(pρ2c2+a2c2+p2)=0p˙+∂∂x(ρc2c2+p2ρ2c2+a2)=0 or ∂c2∂t(θ˙c2−1c2θ˙2+p2)−∂∂x(pc2−1c2θ˙2+p2)=0\begin{align*} & \text { Chaplygin gas: } \tag{237}\\ & \qquad \begin{aligned} & \dot{\rho}+\frac{\partial}{\partial x}(p \rho)=0 \\ & \text { or } \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \frac{\dot{p}+\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\frac{p^{2}}{2}-\frac{\lambda}{\rho^{2}}\right)}{\sqrt{\dot{\theta}+\frac{p^{2}}{2}}}+\frac{\partial}{\partial x} \frac{p}{\sqrt{\dot{\theta}+\frac{p^{2}}{2}}}=0 \\ & \text { Born-Infeld model: } \\ & \dot{\rho}+\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(p \sqrt{\frac{\rho^{2} c^{2}+a^{2}}{c^{2}+p^{2}}}\right)=0 \\ & \dot{p}+\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\rho c^{2} \sqrt{\frac{c^{2}+p^{2}}{\rho^{2} c^{2}+a^{2}}}\right)=0 \\ & \text { or } \frac{\partial}{c^{2} \partial t}\left(\frac{\dot{\theta}}{\sqrt{c^{2}-\frac{1}{c^{2}} \dot{\theta}^{2}+p^{2}}}\right)-\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\frac{p}{\sqrt{c^{2}-\frac{1}{c^{2}} \dot{\theta}^{2}+p^{2}}}\right)=0 \end{aligned} \tag{238} \end{align*}​ Chaplygin gas: ​ρ˙​+∂x∂​(pρ)=0 or ∂t∂​θ˙+2p2​​p˙​+∂x∂​(2p2​−ρ2λ​)​+∂x∂​θ˙+2p2​​p​=0 Born-Infeld model: ρ˙​+∂x∂​(pc2+p2ρ2c2+a2​​)=0p˙​+∂x∂​(ρc2ρ2c2+a2c2+p2​​)=0 or c2∂t∂​​c2−c21​θ˙2+p2​θ˙​​−∂x∂​​c2−c21​θ˙2+p2​p​​=0​​(237)(238)​

In the above, eqs. (239) and (242) result by determining ρ\rhoρ in terms of θ(p=∂∂xθ)\theta\left(p=\frac{\partial}{\partial x} \theta\right)θ(p=∂x∂​θ) from (238) and (241), and using that expression for ρ\rhoρ in (237) and (240).

6.1 Specific solutions for the Chaplygin gas on a line

Classes of solutions for a Chaplygin gas in one dimension can be given in closed form. For example, to obtain general, time-rescaling-invariant solutions, we make the Ansatz that θ∝\theta \proptoθ∝ 1/t1 / t1/t. Then (109) or (239) leads to a second-order nonlinear differential equation for the xxx dependence of θ\thetaθ. Therefore solutions involve two arbitrary constants, one of which fixes the origin of xxx (we suppress it); the other we call kkk, and take it to be real. The solutions then read

θ(t,x)=−12k2tcosh⁡2kx.\begin{equation*} \theta(t, x)=-\frac{1}{2 k^{2} t} \cosh ^{2} k x . \tag{243} \end{equation*}θ(t,x)=−2k2t1​cosh2kx.​(243)​

[Other solutions can be obtained by relaxing the reality condition on kkk and/or shifting the argument kxk xkx by a complex number. In this way one finds that θ\thetaθ can also be 12k2tsinh⁡2kx\frac{1}{2 k^{2} t} \sinh ^{2} k x2k2t1​sinh2kx, 12k2tsin⁡2kx,12k2tcos⁡2kx\frac{1}{2 k^{2} t} \sin ^{2} k x, \frac{1}{2 k^{2} t} \cos ^{2} k x2k2t1​sin2kx,2k2t1​cos2kx; but these lead to singular or unphysical forms for ρ\rhoρ.] The density corresponding to (243) is found from (96) or (238) to be

ρ(t,x)=2λk∣t∣cosh⁡2kx.\begin{equation*} \rho(t, x)=\sqrt{2 \lambda} \frac{k|t|}{\cosh ^{2} k x} . \tag{244} \end{equation*}ρ(t,x)=2λ​cosh2kxk∣t∣​.​(244)​

The velocity/momentum v=p=∂∂xθv=p=\frac{\partial}{\partial x} \thetav=p=∂x∂​θ is

v(t,x)=p(t,x)=−1ktsinh⁡kxcosh⁡kx\begin{equation*} v(t, x)=p(t, x)=-\frac{1}{k t} \sinh k x \cosh k x \tag{245} \end{equation*}v(t,x)=p(t,x)=−kt1​sinhkxcoshkx​(245)​

while the sound speed

s(t,x)=cosh⁡2kxk∣t∣\begin{equation*} s(t, x)=\frac{\cosh ^{2} k x}{k|t|} \tag{246} \end{equation*}s(t,x)=k∣t∣cosh2kx​​(246)​

is always larger than ∣v∣|v|∣v∣. Finally, the current j=ρ∂θ∂xj=\rho \frac{\partial \theta}{\partial x}j=ρ∂x∂θ​ exhibits a kink profile,

j(t,x)=−ε(t)2λtanh⁡kx\begin{equation*} j(t, x)=-\varepsilon(t) \sqrt{2 \lambda} \tanh k x \tag{247} \end{equation*}j(t,x)=−ε(t)2λ​tanhkx​(247)​

which is suggestive of complete integrability. Another particular solution is the Galileo boost of the static profiles (115), (116):

p(t,x)=p(x−ut)ρ(t,x)=2λ∣p−u∣.\begin{align*} & p(t, x)=p(x-u t) \tag{248}\\ & \rho(t, x)=\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{|p-u|} . \tag{249} \end{align*}​p(t,x)=p(x−ut)ρ(t,x)=∣p−u∣2λ​​.​(248)(249)​

Here uuu is the boosting velocity and p(x−ut)p(x-u t)p(x−ut) is an arbitrary function of its argument (provided p≠up \neq up=u ). Clearly this is a constant profile solution, in linear motion with velocity uuu.

Further evidence for complete integrability is found by identifying an infinite number of constants of motion. One verifies that the following quantities

In±=∫dxρ(p±2λρ)n,n=0,±1,…\begin{equation*} I_{n}^{ \pm}=\int \mathrm{d} x \rho\left(p \pm \frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\rho}\right)^{n}, \quad n=0, \pm 1, \ldots \tag{250} \end{equation*}In±​=∫dxρ(p±ρ2λ​​)n,n=0,±1,…​(250)​

are conserved.

The combinations p±2λρp \pm \frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\rho}p±ρ2λ​​ are just the velocity (±)( \pm)(±) the sound speed, and they are known as Riemann coordinates.

R±=p±2λρ\begin{equation*} R_{ \pm}=p \pm \frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\rho} \tag{251} \end{equation*}R±​=p±ρ2λ​​​(251)​

The equations of motion for this system [continuity (237) and Euler (238)] can be succinctly presented in terms of R±R_{ \pm}R±​:

R˙±=−R∓∂∂xR±\begin{equation*} \dot{R}_{ \pm}=-R_{\mp} \frac{\partial}{\partial x} R_{ \pm} \tag{252} \end{equation*}R˙±​=−R∓​∂x∂​R±​​(252)​

6.2 Aside on the integrability of the cubic potential in one dimension

Although it does not belong to the models that we have discussed, the cubic potential for 1-dimensional motion, V(ρ)=ℓρ3/3V(\rho)=\ell \rho^{3} / 3V(ρ)=ℓρ3/3, is especially interesting because it is secretly free - a fact that is exposed when Riemann coordinates are employed. For this problem these read R±=p±2ℓρR_{ \pm}=p \pm \sqrt{2 \ell} \rhoR±​=p±2ℓ​ρ and again they are just the velocity ( ±\pm± ) the sound speed. In contrast to (252) the Euler and continuity equations for this system decouple: R˙±=−R±∂∂xR±\dot{R}_{ \pm}=-R_{ \pm} \frac{\partial}{\partial x} R_{ \pm}R˙±​=−R±​∂x∂​R±​. Indeed, it is seen that R±R_{ \pm}R±​satisfy essentially the free Euler equation [compare with (42) and identify R±R_{ \pm}R±​ with vvv ]. Consequently, the solution (44)-(46) works here as well.

Recall the previous remark in Section 3.1 on the Schrödinger group [Galileo ⊕SO(2,1)\oplus \mathrm{SO}(2,1)⊕SO(2,1) ]: in one dimension the cubic potential is invariant against this group of transformations, and in all dimensions the free theory is invariant [17], 18]. Therefore a natural speculation is that the secretly noninteracting nature of the cubic potential in one dimension is a consequence of Schrödinger group invariance.

Another interesting fact about a one-dimensional nonrelativistic fluid with cubic potential is that it also arises in a collective, semiclassical description of nonrelativistic free fermions in one dimension, where the cubic potential reproduces fermion repulsion [36]. In spite of the nonlinearity of the fluid model's equations of motion, there is no interaction in the underlying fermion dynamics. Thus, the presence of the Schrödinger group and the equivalence to free equations for this fluid system is an understandable consequence.

6.3 General solution for the Chaplygin gas on a line

The general solution to the Chaplygin gas can be found by linearizing the governing equations (continuity and Euler) with the help of a Legendre transform, which also effects a hodographic transformation that exchanges the independent variables (t,x)(t, x)(t,x) with the dependent ones (ρ,θ)(\rho, \theta)(ρ,θ); actually instead of ρ\rhoρ we use the sound speed s=2λ/ρs=\sqrt{2 \lambda} / \rhos=2λ​/ρ and instead of θ\thetaθ we use the momentum p=∂∂xθp=\frac{\partial}{\partial x} \thetap=∂x∂​θ.

Define

ψ(p,s)=θ(t,x)−tθ˙(t,x)−x∂∂xθ(t,x).\begin{equation*} \psi(p, s)=\theta(t, x)-t \dot{\theta}(t, x)-x \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \theta(t, x) . \tag{253} \end{equation*}ψ(p,s)=θ(t,x)−tθ˙(t,x)−x∂x∂​θ(t,x).​(253)​

From the Bernoulli equation we know that

θ˙=−12p2+12s2.\begin{equation*} \dot{\theta}=-\frac{1}{2} p^{2}+\frac{1}{2} s^{2} . \tag{254} \end{equation*}θ˙=−21​p2+21​s2.​(254)​

Thus

ψ(p,s)=θ(t,x)+t2(p2−s2)−xp\begin{equation*} \psi(p, s)=\theta(t, x)+\frac{t}{2}\left(p^{2}-s^{2}\right)-x p \tag{255} \end{equation*}ψ(p,s)=θ(t,x)+2t​(p2−s2)−xp​(255)​

and the usual Legendre transform rules govern the derivatives.

∂ψ∂p=tp−x∂ψ∂s=−ts\begin{align*} & \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial p}=t p-x \tag{256a}\\ & \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial s}=-t s \tag{256b} \end{align*}​∂p∂ψ​=tp−x∂s∂ψ​=−ts​(256a)(256b)​

It remains to incorporate the continuity equation (237) whose content must be recast by the hodographic transformation. This is achieved by rewriting equation (237) in terms of s=2λ/ρ:s=\sqrt{2 \lambda} / \rho:s=2λ​/ρ:

∂s∂t+p∂s∂x−s∂p∂x=0\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial s}{\partial t}+p \frac{\partial s}{\partial x}-s \frac{\partial p}{\partial x}=0 \tag{257} \end{equation*}∂t∂s​+p∂x∂s​−s∂x∂p​=0​(257)​

Next (257) is presented as a relation between Jacobians:

∂(s,x)∂(t,x)+p∂(t,s)∂(t,x)−s∂(t,p)∂(t,x)=0\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial(s, x)}{\partial(t, x)}+p \frac{\partial(t, s)}{\partial(t, x)}-s \frac{\partial(t, p)}{\partial(t, x)}=0 \tag{258a} \end{equation*}∂(t,x)∂(s,x)​+p∂(t,x)∂(t,s)​−s∂(t,x)∂(t,p)​=0​(258a)​

which is true because here ∂x/∂t=∂t/∂x=0\partial x / \partial t=\partial t / \partial x=0∂x/∂t=∂t/∂x=0. Eq. (258a) implies, after multiplication by ∂(t,x)/∂(s,p)\partial(t, x) / \partial(s, p)∂(t,x)/∂(s,p)

0=∂(s,x)∂(s,p)+p∂(t,s)∂(s,p)−s∂(t,p)∂(s,p)=∂x∂p−p∂t∂p−s∂t∂s\begin{align*} 0 & =\frac{\partial(s, x)}{\partial(s, p)}+p \frac{\partial(t, s)}{\partial(s, p)}-s \frac{\partial(t, p)}{\partial(s, p)} \\ & =\frac{\partial x}{\partial p}-p \frac{\partial t}{\partial p}-s \frac{\partial t}{\partial s} \tag{258b} \end{align*}0​=∂(s,p)∂(s,x)​+p∂(s,p)∂(t,s)​−s∂(s,p)∂(t,p)​=∂p∂x​−p∂p∂t​−s∂s∂t​​(258b)​

The second equality holds because now we take ∂s/∂p=∂p/∂s=0\partial s / \partial p=\partial p / \partial s=0∂s/∂p=∂p/∂s=0. Finally, from (255), (256) it follows that (258b) is equivalent to

∂2ψ∂p2−∂2ψ∂s2+2s∂ψ∂s=0\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial^{2} \psi}{\partial p^{2}}-\frac{\partial^{2} \psi}{\partial s^{2}}+\frac{2}{s} \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial s}=0 \tag{258c} \end{equation*}∂p2∂2ψ​−∂s2∂2ψ​+s2​∂s∂ψ​=0​(258c)​

This linear equation is solved by two arbitrary functions of p±sp \pm sp±s ( p±sp \pm sp±s being just the Riemann coordinates)

ψ(p,s)=F(p+s)−sF′(p+s)+G(p−s)+sG′(p−s).\begin{equation*} \psi(p, s)=F(p+s)-s F^{\prime}(p+s)+G(p-s)+s G^{\prime}(p-s) . \tag{259} \end{equation*}ψ(p,s)=F(p+s)−sF′(p+s)+G(p−s)+sG′(p−s).​(259)​

In summary, to solve the Chaplygin gas equations, we choose two functions FFF and GGG, construct ψ\psiψ as in (259), and regain s(=2λ/ρ),p(=∂∂xθ)s(=\sqrt{2 \lambda} / \rho), p\left(=\frac{\partial}{\partial x} \theta\right)s(=2λ​/ρ),p(=∂x∂​θ), and θ\thetaθ from (255), (256). In particular, the solution (243), (244) corresponds to

F(z)=G(−z)=±z2kln⁡z\begin{equation*} F(z)=G(-z)= \pm \frac{z}{2 k} \ln z \tag{260} \end{equation*}F(z)=G(−z)=±2kz​lnz​(260)​

where the sign is correlated with the sign of ttt.

6.4 Born-Infeld model on a line

Since the Born-Infeld system is related to Chaplygin gas by the transformation described in Section 4.4, there is no need to discuss separately Born-Infeld solutions. Nevertheless, the formulation in terms of Riemann coordinates is especially succinct and gives another view on the Chaplygin/Born-Infeld relation.

The Riemann coordinates R±R_{ \pm}R±​for the Born-Infeld model are contructed by first defining

1c∂∂xθ=p/c=tan⁡φpa/ρc=tan⁡φρ\begin{align*} \frac{1}{c} \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \theta=p / c & =\tan \varphi_{p} \\ a / \rho c & =\tan \varphi_{\rho} \tag{261} \end{align*}c1​∂x∂​θ=p/ca/ρc​=tanφp​=tanφρ​​(261)​

and

R±=φp±φρ\begin{equation*} R_{ \pm}=\varphi_{p} \pm \varphi_{\rho} \tag{262} \end{equation*}R±​=φp​±φρ​​(262)​

The 1-dimensional version of the equations of motion (130), (131), that is, (240), (241) can be presented as

R˙±=−c(sin⁡R∓)∂∂xR±\begin{equation*} \dot{R}_{ \pm}=-c\left(\sin R_{\mp}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial x} R_{ \pm} \tag{263} \end{equation*}R˙±​=−c(sinR∓​)∂x∂​R±​​(263)​

The relation to the Riemann description of the Chaplygin gas can now be seen in two ways: a nonrelativistic limit and an exact transformation. For the former, we note that at large ccc, φp≈p/c,φρ≈a/ρc\varphi_{p} \approx p / c, \varphi_{\rho} \approx a / \rho cφp​≈p/c,φρ​≈a/ρc so that

R±Born-Infeld ≈1c(p±aρ)=1cR±Chaplygin ∣λ=a2/2.\begin{equation*} R_{ \pm}^{\text {Born-Infeld }} \approx \frac{1}{c}\left(p \pm \frac{a}{\rho}\right)=\left.\frac{1}{c} R_{ \pm}^{\text {Chaplygin }}\right|_{\lambda=a^{2} / 2} . \tag{264} \end{equation*}R±Born-Infeld ​≈c1​(p±ρa​)=c1​R±Chaplygin ​​λ=a2/2​.​(264)​

Moreover, the equation (263) becomes, in view of (264),

1cR˙±Chaplygin =−R∓Chaplygin 1c∂∂xR±Chaplygin \begin{equation*} \frac{1}{c} \dot{R}_{ \pm}^{\text {Chaplygin }}=-R_{\mp}^{\text {Chaplygin }} \frac{1}{c} \frac{\partial}{\partial x} R_{ \pm}^{\text {Chaplygin }} \tag{265} \end{equation*}c1​R˙±Chaplygin ​=−R∓Chaplygin ​c1​∂x∂​R±Chaplygin ​​(265)​

so that (252) is regained. On the other hand, for the exact transformation we define new Riemann coordinates in the relativistic, Born-Infeld case by

R±=csin⁡R±\begin{equation*} \mathcal{R}_{ \pm}=c \sin R_{ \pm} \tag{266} \end{equation*}R±​=csinR±​​(266)​

Evidently (263) implies that R±\mathcal{R}_{ \pm}R±​satisfies the nonrelativistic equations (252), (265) when R±R_{ \pm}R±​ solves the relativistic equation (263). Expressing R±\mathcal{R}_{ \pm}R±​and R±R_{ \pm}R±​in terms of the corresponding nonrelativistic and relativistic variables produces a mapping between the two sets. Calling pNR,ρNRp_{\mathrm{NR}}, \rho_{\mathrm{NR}}pNR​,ρNR​ and pR,ρRp_{\mathrm{R}}, \rho_{\mathrm{R}}pR​,ρR​ the momentum and density of the nonrelativistic and of the relativistic theory, respectively, the mapping implied by (266) is

pNR=c2ρRpR(pR2+c2)(ρR2c2+a2)ρNR=1c2(pR2+c2)(ρR2c2+a2)\begin{align*} & p_{\mathrm{NR}}=\frac{c^{2} \rho_{\mathrm{R}} p_{\mathrm{R}}}{\sqrt{\left(p_{\mathrm{R}}^{2}+c^{2}\right)\left(\rho_{\mathrm{R}}^{2} c^{2}+a^{2}\right)}} \\ & \rho_{\mathrm{NR}}=\frac{1}{c^{2}} \sqrt{\left(p_{\mathrm{R}}^{2}+c^{2}\right)\left(\rho_{\mathrm{R}}^{2} c^{2}+a^{2}\right)} \tag{267} \end{align*}​pNR​=(pR2​+c2)(ρR2​c2+a2)​c2ρR​pR​​ρNR​=c21​(pR2​+c2)(ρR2​c2+a2)​​(267)​

As can be checked, this maps the Chaplygin equations into the Born-Infeld equations. But the mapping is not canonical.

We record the infinite number of constants of motion, which put into evidence the (by now obvious) complete integrability of the Born-Infeld equations on a line. The following quantities are time-independent:

In±=acn−1∫ dx(φp±φρ)nsin⁡φρcos⁡φp,n=0,±1,…\begin{equation*} I_{n}^{ \pm}=a c^{n-1} \int \mathrm{~d} x \frac{\left(\varphi_{p} \pm \varphi_{\rho}\right)^{n}}{\sin \varphi_{\rho} \cos \varphi_{p}}, \quad n=0, \pm 1, \ldots \tag{268} \end{equation*}In±​=acn−1∫ dxsinφρ​cosφp​(φp​±φρ​)n​,n=0,±1,…​(268)​

The nonrelativistic limit takes the above into (250), while expressing In±I_{n}^{ \pm}In±​in terms of R±\mathcal{R}_{ \pm}R±​ according to (266) shows that the integrals in (268) are expressible as series in terms of the integrals in (250).

In the relativistic model ρ\rhoρ need not be constrained to be positive (negative ρ\rhoρ could be interpreted as antiparticle density). The transformation p→−p,ρ→−ρp \rightarrow-p, \rho \rightarrow-\rhop→−p,ρ→−ρ is a symmetry and can be interpreted as charge conjuguation. Further, ppp and ρ\rhoρ appear in an equivalent way. As a result, this theory enjoys a duality transformation:

ρ→±ac2pp→±c2aρ.\begin{equation*} \rho \rightarrow \pm \frac{a}{c^{2}} p \quad p \rightarrow \pm \frac{c^{2}}{a} \rho . \tag{269} \end{equation*}ρ→±c2a​pp→±ac2​ρ.​(269)​

Under the above, both the canonical structure and the Hamiltonian remain invariant. Solutions are mapped in general to new solutions. Note that the nonrelativistic limit is mapped to the ultra-relativistic one under the above duality. Self-dual solutions, with ρ=±ac2p\rho= \pm \frac{a}{c^{2}} pρ=±c2a​p, satisfy

ρ˙=∓c∂∂xρ\begin{equation*} \dot{\rho}=\mp c \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \rho \tag{270} \end{equation*}ρ˙​=∓c∂x∂​ρ​(270)​
