and are, therefore, the chiral relativistic solutions that were presented at the end of Section 3.2. In the self-dual case, when ppp is eliminated from the canonical 1-form and from the Hamiltonian with the help of (269), one arrives at an action for ρ\rhoρ, which coincides (apart from irrelevant constants) with the self-dual action, constructed some time ago [37]

{12∫ dt dx dyρ˙(x)ε(x−y)p(y)−∫dt dxρ2c2+a2c2+p2 dt}∣p=c2aρ=2c2a{14∫ dt dx dyρ˙(x)ε(x−y)ρ(y)−c2∫ dt dx(ρ2(x)+a2c2)}\begin{align*} & \left.\left\{\frac{1}{2} \int \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} y \dot{\rho}(x) \varepsilon(x-y) p(y)-\int \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d} x \sqrt{\rho^{2} c^{2}+a^{2}} \sqrt{c^{2}+p^{2}} \mathrm{~d} t\right\}\right|_{p=\frac{c^{2}}{a} \rho} \\ = & \frac{2 c^{2}}{a}\left\{\frac{1}{4} \int \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} y \dot{\rho}(x) \varepsilon(x-y) \rho(y)-\frac{c}{2} \int \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} x\left(\rho^{2}(x)+\frac{a^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)\right\} \tag{271} \end{align*}=​{21​∫ dt dx dyρ˙​(x)ε(x−y)p(y)−∫dt dxρ2c2+a2​c2+p2​ dt}​p=ac2​ρ​a2c2​{41​∫ dt dx dyρ˙​(x)ε(x−y)ρ(y)−2c​∫ dt dx(ρ2(x)+c2a2​)}​(271)​

6.5 General solution of the Nambu-Goto theory for a ( d=1\mathrm{d}=1d=1 )brane (string) in two spatial dimensions (on a plane)

The complete integrability of the Chaplygin gas and of the Born-Infeld theory, as well as the relationships between the two, derives from the fact that the different models descend by fixing in different ways the parameterization invariance of the Nambu-Goto theory for string on a plane. At the same time, the equations governing the planar motion of a string can be solved completely. Therefore it is instructive to see how the string solution produces this Chaplygin solution [21].

We follow the development in Section 4.3. The Nambu-Goto action reads

ING=∫dφ0LNGLNG=∫dφ1LNGLNG=[−det⁡∂Xμ∂φα∂Xμ∂φβ]1/2\begin{align*} I_{\mathrm{NG}} & =\int \mathrm{d} \varphi^{0} L_{\mathrm{NG}} \tag{272a}\\ L_{\mathrm{NG}} & =\int \mathrm{d} \varphi^{1} \mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{NG}} \tag{272b}\\ \mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{NG}} & =\left[-\operatorname{det} \frac{\partial X^{\mu}}{\partial \varphi^{\alpha}} \frac{\partial X_{\mu}}{\partial \varphi^{\beta}}\right]^{1 / 2} \tag{272c} \end{align*}ING​LNG​LNG​​=∫dφ0LNG​=∫dφ1LNG​=[−det∂φα∂Xμ​∂φβ∂Xμ​​]1/2​(272a)(272b)(272c)​

Here Xμ,μ=0,1,2X^{\mu}, \mu=0,1,2Xμ,μ=0,1,2, are string variables and (φ0,φ1)\left(\varphi^{0}, \varphi^{1}\right)(φ0,φ1) are its parameters. As in Section 4.3, we define light-cone combinations X±=12(X0±X2)X^{ \pm}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(X^{0} \pm X^{2}\right)X±=2​1​(X0±X2), rename X−X^{-}X−as θ\thetaθ, and choose the parameterization X+=φ0≡τX^{+}=\varphi^{0} \equiv \tauX+=φ0≡τ. After suppressing the superscripts on φ0\varphi^{0}φ0 and X1X^{1}X1, we construct the Nambu-Goto Lagrange density as

LNG=det⁡1/2(2∂τθ−(∂τX)2uu−(∂φX)2)u=∂φθ−∂τX∂φX\begin{align*} \mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{NG}} & =\operatorname{det}^{1 / 2}\left(\begin{array}{cc} 2 \partial_{\tau} \theta-\left(\partial_{\tau} X\right)^{2} & u \\ u & -\left(\partial_{\varphi} X\right)^{2} \end{array}\right) \tag{273}\\ u & =\partial_{\varphi} \theta-\partial_{\tau} X \partial_{\varphi} X \tag{274} \end{align*}LNG​u​=det1/2(2∂τ​θ−(∂τ​X)2u​u−(∂φ​X)2​)=∂φ​θ−∂τ​X∂φ​X​(273)(274)​

Equations of motion are presented in Hamiltonian form:

p≡∂LNG∂∂τXΠ≡∂LNG∂∂τθ∂τX=−1Πp−u∂φX∂τθ=12Π2(p2+(∂φX)2)−u∂φθ∂τp=−∂φ(1Π∂φX)−∂φ(up)∂τΠ=−∂φ(uΠ)\begin{align*} p & \equiv \frac{\partial \mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{NG}}}{\partial \partial_{\tau} X} \quad \Pi \equiv \frac{\partial \mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{NG}}}{\partial \partial_{\tau} \theta} \tag{275}\\ \partial_{\tau} X & =-\frac{1}{\Pi} p-u \partial_{\varphi} X \tag{276a}\\ \partial_{\tau} \theta & =\frac{1}{2 \Pi^{2}}\left(p^{2}+\left(\partial_{\varphi} X\right)^{2}\right)-u \partial_{\varphi} \theta \tag{276b}\\ \partial_{\tau} p & =-\partial_{\varphi}\left(\frac{1}{\Pi} \partial_{\varphi} X\right)-\partial_{\varphi}(u p) \tag{276c}\\ \partial_{\tau} \Pi & =-\partial_{\varphi}(u \Pi) \tag{276d} \end{align*}p∂τ​X∂τ​θ∂τ​p∂τ​Π​≡∂∂τ​X∂LNG​​Π≡∂∂τ​θ∂LNG​​=−Π1​p−u∂φ​X=2Π21​(p2+(∂φ​X)2)−u∂φ​θ=−∂φ​(Π1​∂φ​X)−∂φ​(up)=−∂φ​(uΠ)​(275)(276a)(276b)(276c)(276d)​

and there is the constraint

p∂φX+Π∂φθ=0\begin{equation*} p \partial_{\varphi} X+\Pi \partial_{\varphi} \theta=0 \tag{277} \end{equation*}p∂φ​X+Π∂φ​θ=0​(277)​

There still remains the reparameterization freedom of replacing φ\varphiφ by an arbitrary function of τ\tauτ and φ\varphiφ; this freedom may be used to set u=0,Π=−1u=0, \Pi=-1u=0,Π=−1. Consequently, in the fully parameterized equations of motion Eq. (276d) disappears; instead of (276a) and (276d), we have ∂τX=p,∂τp=∂φ2X\partial_{\tau} X=p, \partial_{\tau} p=\partial_{\varphi}^{2} X∂τ​X=p,∂τ​p=∂φ2​X, which imply

(∂τ2−∂φ2)X=0\begin{equation*} \left(\partial_{\tau}^{2}-\partial_{\varphi}^{2}\right) X=0 \tag{278a} \end{equation*}(∂τ2​−∂φ2​)X=0​(278a)​

(276b) reduces to

∂τθ=12[(∂τX)2+(∂φX)2]\begin{equation*} \partial_{\tau} \theta=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\partial_{\tau} X\right)^{2}+\left(\partial_{\varphi} X\right)^{2}\right] \tag{278b} \end{equation*}∂τ​θ=21​[(∂τ​X)2+(∂φ​X)2]​(278b)​

and the constraint (277) requires

∂φθ=∂τX∂φX\begin{equation*} \partial_{\varphi} \theta=\partial_{\tau} X \partial_{\varphi} X \tag{278c} \end{equation*}∂φ​θ=∂τ​X∂φ​X​(278c)​

Solution to (278a) is immediate in terms of two functions F±F_{ \pm}F±​,

x(τ,φ)=F+(τ+φ)+F−(τ−φ)\begin{equation*} x(\tau, \varphi)=F_{+}(\tau+\varphi)+F_{-}(\tau-\varphi) \tag{279} \end{equation*}x(τ,φ)=F+​(τ+φ)+F−​(τ−φ)​(279)​

and then (278b), (278d) fix θ\thetaθ :

θ(τ,φ)=∫τ+φdz[F+′(z)]2+∫τ−φdz[F−′(z)]2\begin{equation*} \theta(\tau, \varphi)=\int^{\tau+\varphi} \mathrm{d} z\left[F_{+}^{\prime}(z)\right]^{2}+\int^{\tau-\varphi} \mathrm{d} z\left[F_{-}^{\prime}(z)\right]^{2} \tag{280} \end{equation*}θ(τ,φ)=∫τ+φdz[F+′​(z)]2+∫τ−φdz[F−′​(z)]2​(280)​

This completes the description of a string moving on a plane. But we need to convert this information into a solution of the Chaplygin gas, and we know from Section 4.3 that this can be accomplished by a hodographic transformation: instead of XXX and θ\thetaθ as a function of τ\tauτ and φ\varphiφ, we seek φ\varphiφ as a function of τ\tauτ and XXX, and this renders θ\thetaθ to be a function of τ\tauτ and XXX as well. The density ρ\rhoρ is determined by the Jacobian ∣∂X/∂φ∣|\partial X / \partial \varphi|∣∂X/∂φ∣.

Replace τ\tauτ by ttt and XXX by xxx and define φ\varphiφ to be f(t,x)f(t, x)f(t,x). Then from (279) it follows that

x=F+(t+f(t,x))+F−(t−f(t,x)).\begin{equation*} x=F_{+}(t+f(t, x))+F_{-}(t-f(t, x)) . \tag{281} \end{equation*}x=F+​(t+f(t,x))+F−​(t−f(t,x)).​(281)​

This equation may be differentiated with respect to ttt and xxx, whereupon one finds

∂f∂t=−F+′(t+f)+F−′(t−f)F+′(t+f)−F−′(t−f)∂f∂x=1F+′(t+f)−F−′(t−f)\begin{align*} & \frac{\partial f}{\partial t}=-\frac{F_{+}^{\prime}(t+f)+F_{-}^{\prime}(t-f)}{F_{+}^{\prime}(t+f)-F_{-}^{\prime}(t-f)} \tag{282a}\\ & \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}=\frac{1}{F_{+}^{\prime}(t+f)-F_{-}^{\prime}(t-f)} \tag{282b} \end{align*}​∂t∂f​=−F+′​(t+f)−F−′​(t−f)F+′​(t+f)+F−′​(t−f)​∂x∂f​=F+′​(t+f)−F−′​(t−f)1​​(282a)(282b)​

Thus the procedure for constructing a Chaplygin gas solution is to choose two functions F±F_{ \pm}F±​, solve the differential equations (282) for fff, and then the fluid variables are

θ(t,x)=∫t+f(t,x)[F+′(z)]2 dz+∫t−f(t,x)[F−′(z)]2 dz2λρ=∣F+′(t+φ)−F−′(t−φ)∣\begin{align*} \theta(t, x) & =\int^{t+f(t, x)}\left[F_{+}^{\prime}(z)\right]^{2} \mathrm{~d} z+\int^{t-f(t, x)}\left[F_{-}^{\prime}(z)\right]^{2} \mathrm{~d} z \tag{283}\\ \frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\rho} & =\left|F_{+}^{\prime}(t+\varphi)-F_{-}^{\prime}(t-\varphi)\right| \tag{284} \end{align*}θ(t,x)ρ2λ​​​=∫t+f(t,x)[F+′​(z)]2 dz+∫t−f(t,x)[F−′​(z)]2 dz=​F+′​(t+φ)−F−′​(t−φ)​​(283)(284)​

One may verify directly that (283) and (284) satisfy the required equations: Upon differentiating (283) with respect to ttt and xxx, we find

∂θ∂t=(F+′)2(1+∂f∂t)+(F−′)2(1−∂f∂t)=−2F+′F−′∂θ∂x=(F+′)2(∂f∂x)−(F−′)2(∂f∂x)=F+′+F−′\begin{align*} \frac{\partial \theta}{\partial t} & =\left(F_{+}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\left(1+\frac{\partial f}{\partial t}\right)+\left(F_{-}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\left(1-\frac{\partial f}{\partial t}\right) \\ & =-2 F_{+}^{\prime} F_{-}^{\prime} \tag{285a}\\ \frac{\partial \theta}{\partial x} & =\left(F_{+}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\right)-\left(F_{-}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\right) \\ & =F_{+}^{\prime}+F_{-}^{\prime} \tag{285b} \end{align*}∂t∂θ​∂x∂θ​​=(F+′​)2(1+∂t∂f​)+(F−′​)2(1−∂t∂f​)=−2F+′​F−′​=(F+′​)2(∂x∂f​)−(F−′​)2(∂x∂f​)=F+′​+F−′​​(285a)(285b)​

The second equalities follow with the help of (282). From (285) one sees that

∂θ∂t+12(∂θ∂x)2=12(F+′−F−′)2=λρ2\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial \theta}{\partial t}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial \theta}{\partial x}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(F_{+}^{\prime}-F_{-}^{\prime}\right)^{2}=\frac{\lambda}{\rho^{2}} \tag{286} \end{equation*}∂t∂θ​+21​(∂x∂θ​)2=21​(F+′​−F−′​)2=ρ2λ​​(286)​

the last equality being the definition (284). Thus the Bernoulli (Euler) equation holds. For the continuity equation, we first find from (284) and (285)

∂ρ∂t=±∂∂t2λF+′−F−′=∓2λ(F+′−F−′)2[F+′′(1+∂f∂t)−F−′′(1−∂f∂t)]=±22λ(F+′−F−′)3(F+′′F−′+F−′′F+′)∂∂x(ρ∂θ∂x)=∂∂x(±2λF+′+F−′F+′−F−′)=∓2λ(F+′−F−′)2(F+′′F−′+F−′′F+′)∂f∂x=∓22λ(F+′−F−′)3(F+′′F−′+F−′′F+′)\begin{align*} \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t} & = \pm \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{F_{+}^{\prime}-F_{-}^{\prime}} \\ & =\mp \frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\left(F_{+}^{\prime}-F_{-}^{\prime}\right)^{2}}\left[F_{+}^{\prime \prime}\left(1+\frac{\partial f}{\partial t}\right)-F_{-}^{\prime \prime}\left(1-\frac{\partial f}{\partial t}\right)\right] \\ & = \pm \frac{2 \sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\left(F_{+}^{\prime}-F_{-}^{\prime}\right)^{3}}\left(F_{+}^{\prime \prime} F_{-}^{\prime}+F_{-}^{\prime \prime} F_{+}^{\prime}\right) \tag{287a}\\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\rho \frac{\partial \theta}{\partial x}\right) & =\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left( \pm \sqrt{2 \lambda} \frac{F_{+}^{\prime}+F_{-}^{\prime}}{F_{+}^{\prime}-F_{-}^{\prime}}\right) \\ & =\mp \frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\left(F_{+}^{\prime}-F_{-}^{\prime}\right)^{2}}\left(F_{+}^{\prime \prime} F_{-}^{\prime}+F_{-}^{\prime \prime} F_{+}^{\prime}\right) \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} \\ & =\mp \frac{2 \sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\left(F_{+}^{\prime}-F_{-}^{\prime}\right)^{3}}\left(F_{+}^{\prime \prime} F_{-}^{\prime}+F_{-}^{\prime \prime} F_{+}^{\prime}\right) \tag{287b} \end{align*}∂t∂ρ​∂x∂​(ρ∂x∂θ​)​=±∂t∂​F+′​−F−′​2λ​​=∓(F+′​−F−′​)22λ​​[F+′′​(1+∂t∂f​)−F−′′​(1−∂t∂f​)]=±(F+′​−F−′​)322λ​​(F+′′​F−′​+F−′′​F+′​)=∂x∂​(±2λ​F+′​−F−′​F+′​+F−′​​)=∓(F+′​−F−′​)22λ​​(F+′′​F−′​+F−′′​F+′​)∂x∂f​=∓(F+′​−F−′​)322λ​​(F+′′​F−′​+F−′′​F+′​)​(287a)(287b)​

The last equalities follow from (282); since (287a) and (287b) sum to zero, the continuity equation holds.

We observe that the differentiated functions F±′F_{ \pm}^{\prime}F±′​ are just the Riemann coordinates: from (285b) and (284) [with the absolute value ignored] we have

p±2λρ≡R±=2F±′.\begin{equation*} p \pm \frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\rho} \equiv R_{ \pm}=2 F_{ \pm}^{\prime} . \tag{288} \end{equation*}p±ρ2λ​​≡R±​=2F±′​.​(288)​

Also it is seen with the help of (282) that the Riemann formulation (252) of the Chaplygin equations is satisfied by 2F±′2 F_{ \pm}^{\prime}2F±′​.

The constants of motion (250) become proportional to

In±∝∫dx1F+′−F−′[F±′]n=∫dx∂f∂x[F±′(t±f)]n∝∫ dz[F±′(z)]n.\begin{align*} I_{n}^{ \pm} & \propto \int \mathrm{d} x \frac{1}{F_{+}^{\prime}-F_{-}^{\prime}}\left[F_{ \pm}^{\prime}\right]^{n} \\ & =\int \mathrm{d} x \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\left[F_{ \pm}^{\prime}(t \pm f)\right]^{n} \\ & \propto \int \mathrm{~d} z\left[F_{ \pm}^{\prime}(z)\right]^{n} . \tag{289} \end{align*}In±​​∝∫dxF+′​−F−′​1​[F±′​]n=∫dx∂x∂f​[F±′​(t±f)]n∝∫ dz[F±′​(z)]n.​(289)​

Finally we remark that the solution (243), (244) corresponds to

F+(z)=−F−(z)=±ln⁡z2k\begin{equation*} F_{+}(z)=-F_{-}(z)= \pm \frac{\ln z}{2 k} \tag{290} \end{equation*}F+​(z)=−F−​(z)=±2klnz​​(290)​

There exists a relation between the two functions FFF and GGG in (259), which encode the Chaplygin gas solution in the linearization approach of Section 6.3, and the above two functions F±F_{ \pm}F±​, which do the same job in the Nambu-Goto approach. The relation is that 2F+′2 F_{+}^{\prime}2F+′​ is inverse to 2F′′2 F^{\prime \prime}2F′′ and 2F−′2 F_{-}^{\prime}2F−′​ is inverse to 2G′′2 G^{\prime \prime}2G′′, that is,

2F′′[2F+′(z)]=z2G′′[2F−′(z)]=z\begin{align*} & 2 F^{\prime \prime}\left[2 F_{+}^{\prime}(z)\right]=z \\ & 2 G^{\prime \prime}\left[2 F_{-}^{\prime}(z)\right]=z \tag{291} \end{align*}​2F′′[2F+′​(z)]=z2G′′[2F−′​(z)]=z​(291)​

Problem 7 Derive (291). Verify this relation with (260) and (290).

7 Towards a Non-Abelian Fluid Mechanics

Fluid mechanics and fluid magnetohydrodynamics may very well describe the long-wavelength degrees of freedom in a quark-gluon plasma. Moreover it is plausible that the group (color) degrees of freedom remain distinct in that regime, so that one should incorporate them in the fluid approximation. In this way one is led to think about constructing non-Abelian fluid mechanics and (color) magnetohydrodynamics. In this section we describe an approach to this task [38]. In the course of development, we encounter and solve an interesting mathematical problem: how to parameterize a non-Abelian vector potential so that the non-Abelian ChernSimons density becomes a total derivative, and the volume-integrated Chern-Simons term is given by a surface integral. Obviously this is the non-Abelian generalization of the similar Abelian problem, which is solved by presenting the Abelian vector potential in Clebsch form. So we shall determine the non-Abelian version of the Clebsch parameterization.

7.1 Proposal for non-Abelian fluid mechanics

We review our Lagrange density for relativistic Abelian fluid mechanics (144):

L=−jμaμ−f(jμjμ).\begin{equation*} \mathcal{L}=-j^{\mu} a_{\mu}-f\left(\sqrt{j^{\mu} j_{\mu}}\right) . \tag{292} \end{equation*}L=−jμaμ​−f(jμjμ​​).​(292)​

The equation of state is encoded in the function fff. For free fluid motion f(jμjμ)=cjμjμf\left(\sqrt{j^{\mu} j_{\mu}}\right)=c \sqrt{j^{\mu} j_{\mu}}f(jμjμ​​)=cjμjμ​​. Here jμj^{\mu}jμ is the matter current and aμa_{\mu}aμ​ is an auxilliary 4 -vector, which is presented in the form

aμ=∂μθ+α∂μβ.\begin{equation*} a_{\mu}=\partial_{\mu} \theta+\alpha \partial_{\mu} \beta . \tag{293} \end{equation*}aμ​=∂μ​θ+α∂μ​β.​(293)​

The time component a0a_{0}a0​, involving time derivatives, determines the canonical 1-form; the spatial components a\boldsymbol{a}a are in the Clebsch parameterization, as is needed for overcoming the obstacle created by a Casimir invariant of the fluid in the algebra (14), (16). Another way of characterizing the parameterization of the vector a\boldsymbol{a}a is that it casts the Chern-Simons density of a\boldsymbol{a}a, namely, a⋅∇×a\boldsymbol{a} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{a}a⋅∇×a into total derivative form: ∇θ⋅(∇α×∇β)=∇⋅(θ∇×a)\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta \cdot(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \alpha \times \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta)=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\theta \boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{a})∇θ⋅(∇α×∇β)=∇⋅(θ∇×a).

For a non-Abelian generalization, it is plausible to suppose that the current 4 -vector acquires an internal symmetry index: JaμJ_{a}^{\mu}Jaμ​; correspondingly, the auxiliary 4 -vector must also acquire an internal symmetry index: AμaA_{\mu}^{a}Aμa​. It remains to give a rule for parameterizing AμaA_{\mu}^{a}Aμa​, which generalizes the Abelian rule (293).

Our proposal - and it is a speculative one, since at this stage we have no derivation from microscopic considerations - is that AμaA_{\mu}^{a}Aμa​ should be written in a form so that its nonAbelian Chern-Simons density, CS⁡(A)=Aa dAa+13fabcAaAbAc\operatorname{CS}(A)=A^{a} \mathrm{~d} A^{a}+\frac{1}{3} f^{a b c} A^{a} A^{b} A^{c}CS(A)=Aa dAa+31​fabcAaAbAc, is a total derivative ( fabcf^{a b c}fabc are the structure constants of the group). This leads us to the purely mathematical problem of constructing a parameterization for a non-Abelian vector that ensures this property.

7.2 Non-Abelian Clebsch parameterization

(or, casting the non-Abelian Chern-Simons density into total derivative form)

We enquire whether it is possible to parameterize the non-Abelian 1-form, AaA^{a}Aa, such that the Chern-Simons 3 -form is a total derivative (is exact):

CS⁡(A)=Aa dAa+13fabcAaAbAc=dΩ\begin{equation*} \operatorname{CS}(A)=A^{a} \mathrm{~d} A^{a}+\frac{1}{3} f^{a b c} A^{a} A^{b} A^{c}=\mathrm{d} \Omega \tag{294} \end{equation*}CS(A)=Aa dAa+31​fabcAaAbAc=dΩ​(294)​

That this should be possible follows from the observation that the left side of (294) is a 3 -form on 3 -space; hence it is closed, because a 4 -form does not exist in 3 -space. [Of course on a 4 dimensional space the exterior derivative of (294) is proportional to the non-Abelian anomaly (Chern-Pontryagin density) [13].] But a closed form is also exact, at least locally; this justifies the right side of (294).

How this works in the Abelian case has already been explored in Sections 2.4 and 2.5; the Clebsch parameterization (58), (60) for AAA leads to the desired result. But the generalization of (58), (50) for a non-Abelian 1-form is not evident. However, at the end of Section 2.5, an alternative approach is presented, wherein the Abelian 1-form is projected from a non-Abelian pure gauge 1-form. This construction can be generalized to the non-Abelian case and yields the sought-for parameterization.

The mathematical problem can therefore be formulated in the following way: For a given group HHH, how can one construct a potential Aμa=(A0a,Aia)A_{\mu}^{a}=\left(A_{0}^{a}, A_{i}^{a}\right)Aμa​=(A0a​,Aia​) such that the non-Abelian ChernSimons integrand CS(A)C S(A)CS(A) is a total derivative? Here we shall only sketch the solution to the problem, referring those interested to Ref. [38] for a detailed discussion.

In the solution that we present, the "total derivative" form for the Chern-Simons density of AaA^{a}Aa is achieved in two steps. The parameterization, which we find, directly leads to an Abelian form of the Chern-Simons density:

Aa dAa+13fabcAaAbAc=γdγ\begin{equation*} A^{a} \mathrm{~d} A^{a}+\frac{1}{3} f^{a b c} A^{a} A^{b} A^{c}=\gamma \mathrm{d} \gamma \tag{295} \end{equation*}Aa dAa+31​fabcAaAbAc=γdγ​(295)​

for some γ\gammaγ. Then Darboux's theorem [10] (or usual fluid dynamical theory [11]) ensures that γ\gammaγ can be presented in Clebsch form, so that γdγ\gamma \mathrm{d} \gammaγdγ is explicitly a total derivative.

We begin with a pure gauge g−1 dgg^{-1} \mathrm{~d} gg−1 dg in some non-Abelian group GGG (called the Ur-group) whose Chern-Simons integral coincides with the winding number of ggg.

W(g)=116π2∫ d3rCS(g−1 dg)=124π2∫tr⁡(g−1 dg)3\begin{equation*} W(g)=\frac{1}{16 \pi^{2}} \int \mathrm{~d}^{3} r \mathrm{CS}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)=\frac{1}{24 \pi^{2}} \int \operatorname{tr}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)^{3} \tag{296} \end{equation*}W(g)=16π21​∫ d3rCS(g−1 dg)=24π21​∫tr(g−1 dg)3​(296)​

We consider a normal subgroup H⊂GH \subset GH⊂G, with generators IaI^{a}Ia, and construct a non-Abelian gauge potential for HHH by projection:

Aa∝tr⁡(Iag−1 dg)\begin{equation*} A^{a} \propto \operatorname{tr}\left(I^{a} g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right) \tag{297} \end{equation*}Aa∝tr(Iag−1 dg)​(297)​

Within HHH, this is not a pure gauge. We determine the group structure that ensures the Chern-Simons 3 -form of AaA^{a}Aa to be proportional to tr⁡(g−1 dg)3\operatorname{tr}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)^{3}tr(g−1 dg)3. Consequently, the constructed non-Abelian gauge fields, belonging to the group HHH, carry quantized Chern-Simons number. Moreover, we describe the properties of the Ur-group GGG that guarantee that the projected potential AaA^{a}Aa enjoys sufficient generality to represent an arbitrary potential in HHH.

Since tr⁡(g−1 dg)3\operatorname{tr}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)^{3}tr(g−1 dg)3 is a total derivative for an arbitrary group (although this fact cannot in general be expressed in finite terms [39]) our construction ensures that the form of AaA^{a}Aa, which is achieved through the projection (297), produces a "total derivative" expression (in the limited sense indicated above) for its Chern-Simons density.

Conditions on the Ur-group GGG, which we take to be compact and semi-simple, are the following. First of all GGG has to be so chosen that it has sufficient number of parameters to make tr⁡(Iag−1 dg)\operatorname{tr}\left(I^{a} g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)tr(Iag−1 dg) a generic potential for HHH. Since we are in three dimensions, an HHH-potential AiaA_{i}^{a}Aia​ has 3×dim⁡H3 \times \operatorname{dim} H3×dimH independent functions; so a minimal requirement will be

dim⁡G≥3dim⁡H.\begin{equation*} \operatorname{dim} G \geq 3 \operatorname{dim} H . \tag{298} \end{equation*}dimG≥3dimH.​(298)​

Secondly we require that the HHH-Chern-Simons form for AaA^{a}Aa should coincide with that of g−1 dgg^{-1} \mathrm{~d} gg−1 dg. As we shall show in a moment, this is achieved if G/HG / HG/H is a symmetric space. In this case, if we split the Lie algebra of GGG into the HHH-subalgebra spanned by Ia,a=1,…I^{a}, a=1, \ldotsIa,a=1,…, dim⁡H\operatorname{dim} HdimH, and the orthogonal complement spanned by SA,A=1,…,(dim⁡G−dim⁡H)S^{A}, A=1, \ldots,(\operatorname{dim} G-\operatorname{dim} H)SA,A=1,…,(dimG−dimH), the commutation rules are of the form

[Ia,Ib]=fabcIc[Ia,SA]=haABSB[SA,SB]=NhaABIa.\begin{align*} {\left[I^{a}, I^{b}\right] } & =f^{a b c} I^{c} \tag{299a}\\ {\left[I^{a}, S^{A}\right] } & =h^{a A B} S^{B} \tag{299b}\\ {\left[S^{A}, S^{B}\right] } & =N h^{a A B} I^{a} . \tag{299c} \end{align*}[Ia,Ib][Ia,SA][SA,SB]​=fabcIc=haABSB=NhaABIa.​(299a)(299b)(299c)​

(ha)AB\left(h^{a}\right)^{A B}(ha)AB form a (possibly reducible) representation of the HHH-generators IaI^{a}Ia. The constant NNN depends on normalizations. More explicitly, if the structure constants for the Ur-group GGG are named fˉabc,a,b,c=1,…,dim⁡G\bar{f}^{a b c}, a, b, c=1, \ldots, \operatorname{dim} Gfˉ​abc,a,b,c=1,…,dimG, then the conditions (299a c) require that fˉabc\bar{f}^{a b c}fˉ​abc vanishes whenever an odd number of indices belongs to the orthogonal complement labeled by A,B,…A, B, \ldotsA,B,… Moreover, fabcf^{a b c}fabc are taken to be the conventional structure constants for HHH and this may render them proportional to (rather than equal to) fˉabc\bar{f}^{a b c}fˉ​abc.

We define the traces of the generators by

tr⁡(IaIb)=−N1δab,tr⁡(SASB)=−N2δABtr⁡(IaSA)=0\begin{align*} \operatorname{tr}\left(I^{a} I^{b}\right) & =-N_{1} \delta^{a b}, \quad \operatorname{tr}\left(S^{A} S^{B}\right)=-N_{2} \delta^{A B} \\ \operatorname{tr}\left(I^{a} S^{A}\right) & =0 \tag{300} \end{align*}tr(IaIb)tr(IaSA)​=−N1​δab,tr(SASB)=−N2​δAB=0​(300)​

We can evaluate the quantity tr⁡[SA,SB]Ia=tr⁡SA[SB,Ia]\operatorname{tr}\left[S^{A}, S^{B}\right] I^{a}=\operatorname{tr} S^{A}\left[S^{B}, I^{a}\right]tr[SA,SB]Ia=trSA[SB,Ia] using the commutation rules. This immediately gives the relation N1N=N2N_{1} N=N_{2}N1​N=N2​.

Expanding g−1 dgg^{-1} \mathrm{~d} gg−1 dg in terms of generators, we write

g−1 dg=(IaAa+SAαA)\begin{equation*} g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g=\left(I^{a} A^{a}+S^{A} \alpha^{A}\right) \tag{301} \end{equation*}g−1 dg=(IaAa+SAαA)​(301)​

which defines the HHH-potential AaA^{a}Aa. Equivalently

Aa=−1N1tr⁡(Iag−1 dg)\begin{equation*} A^{a}=-\frac{1}{N_{1}} \operatorname{tr}\left(I^{a} g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right) \tag{302} \end{equation*}Aa=−N1​1​tr(Iag−1 dg)​(302)​

From d(g−1 dg)=−g−1 dgg−1 dg\mathrm{d}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)=-g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} gd(g−1 dg)=−g−1 dgg−1 dg, we get the Maurer-Cartan relations

Fα≡dAa+12fabcAbAc=−N2haABαAαB dαA+hαBAAaαB=0.\begin{align*} F^{\alpha} \equiv \mathrm{d} A^{a}+\frac{1}{2} f^{a b c} A^{b} A^{c} & =-\frac{N}{2} h^{a A B} \alpha^{A} \alpha^{B} \\ \mathrm{~d} \alpha^{A}+h^{\alpha B A} A^{a} \alpha^{B} & =0 . \tag{303} \end{align*}Fα≡dAa+21​fabcAbAc dαA+hαBAAaαB​=−2N​haABαAαB=0.​(303)​

Using these results, the following chain of equations shows that the Chern-Simons 3-form for the HHH-gauge group is proportional to tr⁡(g−1 dg)3\operatorname{tr}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)^{3}tr(g−1 dg)3 :

116π2(Aa dAa+13fabcAaAbAc)=148π2(Aa dAa+2AaFa)=148π2(Aa dAa−NhaABAaαAαB)=148π2(Aa dAa+N dαAαA)=−148π2[1N1tr⁡(A dA)+NN2tr⁡( dαα)]=−148π2N1tr⁡(A dA+αdα)=−148π2N1tr⁡g−1 dg d(g−1 dg)=148π2N1tr⁡(g−1 dg)3.\begin{align*} \frac{1}{16 \pi^{2}}\left(A^{a} \mathrm{~d} A^{a}+\frac{1}{3} f^{a b c} A^{a} A^{b} A^{c}\right) & =\frac{1}{48 \pi^{2}}\left(A^{a} \mathrm{~d} A^{a}+2 A^{a} F^{a}\right) \\ & =\frac{1}{48 \pi^{2}}\left(A^{a} \mathrm{~d} A^{a}-N h^{a A B} A^{a} \alpha^{A} \alpha^{B}\right) \\ & =\frac{1}{48 \pi^{2}}\left(A^{a} \mathrm{~d} A^{a}+N \mathrm{~d} \alpha^{A} \alpha^{A}\right) \\ & =-\frac{1}{48 \pi^{2}}\left[\frac{1}{N_{1}} \operatorname{tr}(A \mathrm{~d} A)+\frac{N}{N_{2}} \operatorname{tr}(\mathrm{~d} \alpha \alpha)\right] \\ & =-\frac{1}{48 \pi^{2} N_{1}} \operatorname{tr}(A \mathrm{~d} A+\alpha \mathrm{d} \alpha) \\ & =-\frac{1}{48 \pi^{2} N_{1}} \operatorname{tr} g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g \mathrm{~d}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right) \\ & =\frac{1}{48 \pi^{2} N_{1}} \operatorname{tr}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)^{3} . \tag{304} \end{align*}16π21​(Aa dAa+31​fabcAaAbAc)​=48π21​(Aa dAa+2AaFa)=48π21​(Aa dAa−NhaABAaαAαB)=48π21​(Aa dAa+N dαAαA)=−48π21​[N1​1​tr(A dA)+N2​N​tr( dαα)]=−48π2N1​1​tr(A dA+αdα)=−48π2N1​1​trg−1 dg d(g−1 dg)=48π2N1​1​tr(g−1 dg)3.​(304)​

In the above sequence of manipulations, we have used the Maurer-Cartan relations (303), which rely on the symmetric space structure of (299a c), and the trace relations (300), along with N1N=N2N_{1} N=N_{2}N1​N=N2​.

We thus see that ∫CS⁡(A)\int \operatorname{CS}(A)∫CS(A) is indeed the winding number of the configuration g∈Gg \in Gg∈G. Since tr⁡(g−1 dg)3\operatorname{tr}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)^{3}tr(g−1 dg)3 is a total derivative locally on GGG, the potential (302), with the symmetric space structure of (299a-c), does indeed fulfill the requirement of making CS⁡(A)\operatorname{CS}(A)CS(A) a total derivative. It is therefore appropriate to call our construction (302) a "non-Abelian Clebsch parameterization".

In explicit realizations, given a gauge group of interest HHH, we need to choose a group GGG such that the conditions (298), (299a c) hold. In general this is not possible. However, one can proceed recursively. Let us suppose that the desired result has been established for a group, which we call H2H_{2}H2​. Then we form H⊂GH \subset GH⊂G obeying (299a c) as H=H1×H2H=H_{1} \times H_{2}H=H1​×H2​, where H1H_{1}H1​ is the gauge group of interest, satisfying dim⁡G≥3dim⁡H1\operatorname{dim} G \geq 3 \operatorname{dim} H_{1}dimG≥3dimH1​. For this choice of HHH, the result (304) becomes

CS⁡(H1)+CS⁡(H2)=148π2N1tr⁡(g−1 dg)3\begin{equation*} \operatorname{CS}\left(H_{1}\right)+\operatorname{CS}\left(H_{2}\right)=\frac{1}{48 \pi^{2} N_{1}} \operatorname{tr}\left(g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)^{3} \tag{305} \end{equation*}CS(H1​)+CS(H2​)=48π2N1​1​tr(g−1 dg)3​(305)​

But since CS(H2)\mathrm{CS}\left(H_{2}\right)CS(H2​) is already known to be a total derivative, (305) shows the desired result: CS(H1)\mathrm{CS}\left(H_{1}\right)CS(H1​) is a total derivative.

To see explicitly how this works we work out the representation for a SU(2)≈O(3)\mathrm{SU}(2) \approx O(3)SU(2)≈O(3) potential AiaA_{i}^{a}Aia​, which possesses nine independent functions.

We take G=O(5),H=O(3)×O(2)G=O(5), H=O(3) \times O(2)G=O(5),H=O(3)×O(2). We consider the 4-dimensional spinorial representation of O(5)O(5)O(5). With the generators normalized by tr⁡(tatb)=−δab\operatorname{tr}\left(t^{a} t^{b}\right)=-\delta^{a b}tr(tatb)=−δab, the Lie algebra generators of O(5)O(5)O(5) are given by

Ia=12i(σa00σa)I0=12i(−1001)SA=1i2(00σA0)S~A=1i2(0σA00)\begin{align*} I^{a} & =\frac{1}{2 i}\left(\begin{array}{cc} \sigma^{a} & 0 \\ 0 & \sigma^{a} \end{array}\right) \\ I^{0} & =\frac{1}{2 i}\left(\begin{array}{cc} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{array}\right) \tag{306}\\ S^{A} & =\frac{1}{i \sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 0 \\ \sigma^{A} & 0 \end{array}\right) \quad \widetilde{S}^{A}=\frac{1}{i \sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}{cc} 0 & \sigma^{A} \\ 0 & 0 \end{array}\right) \end{align*}IaI0SA​=2i1​(σa0​0σa​)=2i1​(−10​01​)=i2​1​(0σA​00​)SA=i2​1​(00​σA0​)​(306)​

σ\sigmaσ 's are the 2×22 \times 22×2 Pauli matrices. IaI^{a}Ia generate O(3)O(3)O(3), with the conventional structure constants εabc\varepsilon^{a b c}εabc, and I0I^{0}I0 is the generator of O(2).S,S~O(2) . S, \widetilde{S}O(2).S,S are the coset generators.

A general group element in O(5)O(5)O(5) can be written in the form g=Mhkg=M h kg=Mhk where h∈O(3)h \in O(3)h∈O(3), k∈O(2)k \in O(2)k∈O(2), and

M=11+w‾⋅w−14(w×w‾)2(1−i2(w×w‾)⋅σ−w⋅σw‾⋅σ1+i2(w×w‾)⋅σ)(307)M=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\overline{\mathbf{w}} \cdot \mathbf{w}-\frac{1}{4}(\mathbf{w} \times \overline{\mathbf{w}})^{2}}}\left(\begin{array}{cc} 1-\frac{i}{2}(\mathbf{w} \times \overline{\mathbf{w}}) \cdot \sigma & -\mathbf{w} \cdot \sigma \tag{307}\\ \overline{\mathbf{w}} \cdot \sigma & 1+\frac{i}{2}(\mathbf{w} \times \overline{\mathbf{w}}) \cdot \sigma \end{array}\right)M=1+w⋅w−41​(w×w)2​1​(1−2i​(w×w)⋅σw⋅σ​−w⋅σ1+2i​(w×w)⋅σ​)(307)

waw^{a}wa is a complex 3 -dimensional vector, with the bar denoting complex conjugation. w⋅w‾=\mathbf{w} \cdot \overline{\mathbf{w}}=w⋅w= wawˉaw^{a} \bar{w}^{a}wawˉa and (w×w‾)a=εabcwbwˉc(\mathbf{w} \times \overline{\mathbf{w}})^{a}=\varepsilon^{a b c} w^{b} \bar{w}^{c}(w×w)a=εabcwbwˉc. The general O(5)O(5)O(5) group element contains ten independent real functions. These are collected as six from MMM (in the three complex functions waw^{a}wa ), three in hhh, and one in kkk.

The O(3)O(3)O(3) gauge potential given by −tr⁡(Iag−1 dg)-\operatorname{tr}\left(I^{a} g^{-1} \mathrm{~d} g\right)−tr(Iag−1 dg) reads

Aa=Rab(h)ab+(h−1 dh)aaa=11+w⋅w‾−14(w×w‾)2{wa dw‾⋅(w×w‾)+wˉa dw⋅(w‾×w)2+εabc( dwbwˉc−wb dwˉc)}\begin{align*} & A^{a}=R^{a b}(h) a^{b}+\left(h^{-1} \mathrm{~d} h\right)^{a} \\ & a^{a}=\frac{1}{1+\mathbf{w} \cdot \overline{\mathbf{w}}-\frac{1}{4}(\mathbf{w} \times \overline{\mathbf{w}})^{2}}\left\{\begin{aligned} & \frac{w^{a} \mathrm{~d} \overline{\mathbf{w}} \cdot(\mathbf{w} \times \overline{\mathbf{w}})+\bar{w}^{a} \mathrm{~d} \mathbf{w} \cdot(\overline{\mathbf{w}} \times \mathbf{w})}{2} \\ & \left.+\varepsilon^{a b c}\left(\mathrm{~d} w^{b} \bar{w}^{c}-w^{b} \mathrm{~d} \bar{w}^{c}\right)\right\} \end{aligned}\right. \tag{308} \end{align*}​Aa=Rab(h)ab+(h−1 dh)aaa=1+w⋅w−41​(w×w)21​⎩⎨⎧​​2wa dw⋅(w×w)+wˉa dw⋅(w×w)​+εabc( dwbwˉc−wb dwˉc)}​​(308)​

where Rab(h)R^{a b}(h)Rab(h) is defined by hIah−1=Rabhbh I^{a} h^{-1}=R^{a b} h^{b}hIah−1=Rabhb and kkk does not contribute. AaA^{a}Aa is the hhh-gauge transform of aaa^{a}aa, which depends on six real parameters (wa)\left(w^{a}\right)(wa). The three gauge parameters of h∈O(3)h \in O(3)h∈O(3), along with the six, give the nine functions needed to parameterize a general O(3)O(3)O(3) [or SU(2)S U(2)SU(2)-] potential in three dimensions. The Chern-Simons form is

CS⁡(A)=116π2(Aa dAa+13εabcAaAbAc)=116π2(aa daa+13εabcaaabac)−d[116π2( dhh−1)aaa)]+124π2tr⁡(h−1 dh)3\begin{align*} \operatorname{CS}(A)= & \frac{1}{16 \pi^{2}}\left(A^{a} \mathrm{~d} A^{a}+\frac{1}{3} \varepsilon^{a b c} A^{a} A^{b} A^{c}\right) \\ = & \left.\frac{1}{16 \pi^{2}}\left(a^{a} \mathrm{~d} a^{a}+\frac{1}{3} \varepsilon^{a b c} a^{a} a^{b} a^{c}\right)-\mathrm{d}\left[\frac{1}{16 \pi^{2}}\left(\mathrm{~d} h h^{-1}\right)^{a} a^{a}\right)\right] \\ & +\frac{1}{24 \pi^{2}} \operatorname{tr}\left(h^{-1} \mathrm{~d} h\right)^{3} \tag{309} \end{align*}CS(A)==​16π21​(Aa dAa+31​εabcAaAbAc)16π21​(aa daa+31​εabcaaabac)−d[16π21​( dhh−1)aaa)]+24π21​tr(h−1 dh)3​(309)​

The second equality reflects the usual response of the Chern-Simons density to gauge transformations. Using the explicit form of aaa^{a}aa as given in (308), we can further reduce this. Indeed we find that

aa daa+13εabcaaabac=(−2)(w‾×dw‾)⋅ρ+(w×dw)⋅ρˉ[1+w⋅w‾−14(w×w‾)2]2ρk=12εijk dwˉi dwˉj\begin{gather*} a^{a} \mathrm{~d} a^{a}+\frac{1}{3} \varepsilon^{a b c} a^{a} a^{b} a^{c}=(-2) \frac{(\overline{\mathbf{w}} \times \mathrm{d} \overline{\mathbf{w}}) \cdot \rho+(\mathbf{w} \times \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}) \cdot \bar{\rho}}{\left[1+\mathbf{w} \cdot \overline{\mathbf{w}}-\frac{1}{4}(\mathbf{w} \times \overline{\mathbf{w}})^{2}\right]^{2}} \tag{310}\\ \rho_{k}=\frac{1}{2} \varepsilon_{i j k} \mathrm{~d} \bar{w}^{i} \mathrm{~d} \bar{w}^{j} \end{gather*}aa daa+31​εabcaaabac=(−2)[1+w⋅w−41​(w×w)2]2(w×dw)⋅ρ+(w×dw)⋅ρˉ​​ρk​=21​εijk​ dwˉi dwˉj​(310)​

Defining an Abelian potential

a=w⋅dw‾−w‾⋅dw1+w⋅w‾−14(w×w‾)2\begin{equation*} a=\frac{\mathbf{w} \cdot \mathrm{d} \overline{\mathbf{w}}-\overline{\mathbf{w}} \cdot \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w}}{1+\mathbf{w} \cdot \overline{\mathbf{w}}-\frac{1}{4}(\mathbf{w} \times \overline{\mathbf{w}})^{2}} \tag{311} \end{equation*}a=1+w⋅w−41​(w×w)2w⋅dw−w⋅dw​​(311)​

we can easily check that a daa \mathrm{~d} aa da reproduces (310). In other words

CS⁡(A)=116π2a da+d[( dhh−1)aaa)16π2]+148π2tr⁡(h−1 dh)3\begin{equation*} \operatorname{CS}(A)=\frac{1}{16 \pi^{2}} a \mathrm{~d} a+\mathrm{d}\left[\frac{\left.\left(\mathrm{~d} h h^{-1}\right)^{a} a^{a}\right)}{16 \pi^{2}}\right]+\frac{1}{48 \pi^{2}} \operatorname{tr}\left(h^{-1} \mathrm{~d} h\right)^{3} \tag{312} \end{equation*}CS(A)=16π21​a da+d[16π2( dhh−1)aaa)​]+48π21​tr(h−1 dh)3​(312)​

If desired, the Abelian potential aaa can now be written in the Clebsch form making a daa \mathrm{~d} aa da into a total derivative, while the remaining two terms already are total derivatives, though in a "hidden" form for the last expression. This completes our construction.

7.3 Proposal for non-Abelian magnetohydrodynamics

We return to our construction of a Lagrange density for non-Abelian kinetic theory. As explained in Section 7.1, a plausible non-Abelian generalization for (292) is

L=−Jμa1N1tr⁡Iag−1∂μg−cJμaJaμ\begin{equation*} \mathcal{L}=-J^{\mu a} \frac{1}{N_{1}} \operatorname{tr} I^{a} g^{-1} \partial_{\mu} g-c \sqrt{J^{\mu a} J^{a}{ }_{\mu}} \tag{313} \end{equation*}L=−JμaN1​1​trIag−1∂μ​g−cJμaJaμ​​​(313)​

where for simplicity we have taken the "free" form for fff. When the desired group is SU(2),g\mathrm{SU}(2), gSU(2),g is an O(5)O(5)O(5) group element, as detailed in Section 7.2 .

Magnetohydrodynamics is achieved by introducing a further interaction with a dynamical gauge potential Aμa\mathcal{A}_{\mu}^{a}Aμa​. This is accomplished by promoting the derivative of ggg to a gauge-covariant derivative, gauged on the right

Lmagnetohydrodynamics =−1N1Jμatr⁡(Iag−1Dμg)−cJμaJμa−14FaμνFμνa\begin{equation*} \mathcal{L}_{\text {magnetohydrodynamics }}=-\frac{1}{N_{1}} J^{\mu a} \operatorname{tr}\left(I^{a} g^{-1} D_{\mu} g\right)-c \sqrt{J^{\mu a} J_{\mu}^{a}}-\frac{1}{4} \mathcal{F}^{a \mu \nu} \mathcal{F}_{\mu \nu}^{a} \tag{314} \end{equation*}Lmagnetohydrodynamics ​=−N1​1​Jμatr(Iag−1Dμ​g)−cJμaJμa​​−41​FaμνFμνa​​(314)​

with

Dμg=∂μg+egAμ\begin{equation*} D_{\mu} g=\partial_{\mu} g+e g \mathcal{A}_{\mu} \tag{315} \end{equation*}Dμ​g=∂μ​g+egAμ​​(315)​

Aμ=AμaIa\mathcal{A}_{\mu}=\mathcal{A}_{\mu}^{a} I^{a}Aμ​=Aμa​Ia are independent, dynamical gauge potentials (not given by ggg ) leading to the field strengths Fμνa\mathcal{F}_{\mu \nu}^{a}Fμνa​. The gauge transformation properties by the gauge function hhh are

g′=ghA′=h−1Ah+1eh−1 dhJμ′aIa=h−1JμaIah\begin{align*} g^{\prime}=g h \quad \mathcal{A}^{\prime} & =h^{-1} \mathcal{A} h+\frac{1}{e} h^{-1} \mathrm{~d} h \\ J_{\mu}^{\prime a} I^{a} & =h^{-1} J_{\mu}^{a} I^{a} h \tag{316} \end{align*}g′=ghA′Jμ′a​Ia​=h−1Ah+e1​h−1 dh=h−1Jμa​Iah​(316)​

We expect that the Lagrangian (314) will describe non-Abelian magnetohydrodynamics, namely the dynamics of a fluid with non-Abelian charge coupled to non-Abelian fields. [The Abelian version of (314) does indeed describe ordinary magnetohydrodynamics.] This gluon hydrodynamics can be useful for non-Abelian plasmas such as the quark-gluon plasma. Details of (314) and possible applications are under further study.

Solutions to Problems

Problem [1 The imaginary part of the Schrödinger equation gives the continuity equation in the form ρ˙+∇⋅(ρ∇θ)=0\dot{\rho}+\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\rho \boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)=0ρ˙​+∇⋅(ρ∇θ)=0. This identifies the velocity v\boldsymbol{v}v as ∇θ\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta∇θ, that is, v\boldsymbol{v}v is irrotational and there is no vorticity. The real part becomes the Bernoulli equation θ˙+\dot{\theta}+θ˙+ 12(∇θ)2=ℏ22ρ−1/2∇2ρ1/2\frac{1}{2}(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \theta)^{2}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2} \rho^{-1 / 2} \nabla^{2} \rho^{1 / 2}21​(∇θ)2=2ℏ2​ρ−1/2∇2ρ1/2, whose gradient gives the Euler equation and identifies the force f\boldsymbol{f}f as ∇(ℏ22ρ−1/2∇2ρ1/2)\boldsymbol{\nabla}\left(\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2} \rho^{-1 / 2} \nabla^{2} \rho^{1 / 2}\right)∇(2ℏ2​ρ−1/2∇2ρ1/2).

Problem 2 j=ρv\boldsymbol{j}=\rho \boldsymbol{v}j=ρv with v=∇θ\boldsymbol{v}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \thetav=∇θ. Problem 3LSchro¨dinger =θρ˙−12ρ(∇θ)2−ℏ28∇ρ⋅∇ρρ3 \mathcal{L}_{\text {Schrödinger }}=\theta \dot{\rho}-\frac{1}{2} \rho(\nabla \theta)^{2}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{8} \frac{\nabla \rho \cdot \nabla \rho}{\rho}3LSchro¨dinger ​=θρ˙​−21​ρ(∇θ)2−8ℏ2​ρ∇ρ⋅∇ρ​ where the time derivative of iℏρ2−ρθi \frac{\hbar \rho}{2}-\rho \thetai2ℏρ​−ρθ has been dropped.

The results in the solutions to Problems 1 and 3 are called the Mädelung formulation of quantum mechanics (40).

Problem 4CS(A)=εijk∂iΦ∂jcos⁡Θ∂kh(r)4 \mathrm{CS}(A)=\varepsilon^{i j k} \partial_{i} \Phi \partial_{j} \cos \Theta \partial_{k} h(r)4CS(A)=εijk∂i​Φ∂j​cosΘ∂k​h(r) (a) Extracting the first derivative leaves CS⁡(A)=∂iVai,Vai=εijkΦ∂jcos⁡Θ∂kh(r)\operatorname{CS}(A)=\partial_{i} V_{a}^{i}, V_{a}^{i}=\varepsilon^{i j k} \Phi \partial_{j} \cos \Theta \partial_{k} h(r)CS(A)=∂i​Vai​,Vai​=εijkΦ∂j​cosΘ∂k​h(r). (This is true because εijk∂i∂jcos⁡Θ=0=εijk∂i∂kh(r)\varepsilon^{i j k} \partial_{i} \partial_{j} \cos \Theta=0=\varepsilon^{i j k} \partial_{i} \partial_{k} h(r)εijk∂i​∂j​cosΘ=0=εijk∂i​∂k​h(r), since cos⁡Θ\cos \ThetacosΘ and h(r)h(r)h(r) are nonsingular.) Note that Vai=εiΘrΦ(−sin⁡Θr)h′(r)=δiΦΦ(1rsin⁡Θ)h(r)V_{a}^{i}=\varepsilon^{i \Theta r} \Phi\left(-\frac{\sin \Theta}{r}\right) h^{\prime}(r)=\delta^{i \Phi} \Phi\left(\frac{1}{r} \sin \Theta\right) h(r)Vai​=εiΘrΦ(−rsinΘ​)h′(r)=δiΦΦ(r1​sinΘ)h(r). Since Var=0V_{a}^{r}=0Var​=0, the surface integral does not contribute. However, since Φ\PhiΦ is multivalued, there is a contribution from the Φ\PhiΦ integral: ∫d3rCS(A)=∫0Rr2 dr∫0πsin⁡ΘdΘ∫02π dΦ(1rsin⁡Θ∂∂ΦΦ)×(1rsin⁡Θ)h′(r)=\int \mathrm{d}^{3} r \mathrm{CS}(A)=\int_{0}^{R} r^{2} \mathrm{~d} r \int_{0}^{\pi} \sin \Theta \mathrm{d} \Theta \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \mathrm{~d} \Phi\left(\frac{1}{r \sin \Theta} \frac{\partial}{\partial \Phi} \Phi\right) \times\left(\frac{1}{r} \sin \Theta\right) h^{\prime}(r)=∫d3rCS(A)=∫0R​r2 dr∫0π​sinΘdΘ∫02π​ dΦ(rsinΘ1​∂Φ∂​Φ)×(r1​sinΘ)h′(r)= 4π[h(R)−h(0)]4 \pi[h(R)-h(0)]4π[h(R)−h(0)]. (b) Extracting the second derivative leaves CS⁡(A)=∂jVbj−εijk(∂j∂iΦ)cos⁡Θ∂kh(r)\operatorname{CS}(A)=\partial_{j} V_{b}^{j}-\varepsilon^{i j k}\left(\partial_{j} \partial_{i} \Phi\right) \cos \Theta \partial_{k} h(r)CS(A)=∂j​Vbj​−εijk(∂j​∂i​Φ)cosΘ∂k​h(r). The last term is present, owing to the singularity of Φ\PhiΦ at the origin, which gives rise to εkij∂i∂jΦ=δk32πδ(x)δ(y)\varepsilon^{k i j} \partial_{i} \partial_{j} \Phi=\delta^{k 3} 2 \pi \delta(x) \delta(y)εkij∂i​∂j​Φ=δk32πδ(x)δ(y). (See 41].) Also we have Vbi=εijk∂iΦcos⁡Θ∂kh(r)=V_{b}^{i}=\varepsilon^{i j k} \partial_{i} \Phi \cos \Theta \partial_{k} h(r)=Vbi​=εijk∂i​ΦcosΘ∂k​h(r)= εΦjr(1rsin⁡θ)cos⁡Θh′(r)=−1rδjθcot⁡Θh′(r)\varepsilon^{\Phi j r}\left(\frac{1}{r \sin \theta}\right) \cos \Theta h^{\prime}(r)=-\frac{1}{r} \delta^{j \theta} \cot \Theta h^{\prime}(r)εΦjr(rsinθ1​)cosΘh′(r)=−r1​δjθcotΘh′(r). Again there is no rrr-component to contribute to the surface integral, but the second, singular term leaves

∫d3rCS⁡(A)=∫d3r(2π)δ(x)δ(y)cos⁡Θ∂∂zh(r)=2π∫−RR dzz∣z∣∂∂zh(∣z∣)=4π∫0R dz∂∂zh(z)=4π[h(R)−h(0)].\begin{aligned} \int \mathrm{d}^{3} r \operatorname{CS}(A) & =\int \mathrm{d}^{3} r(2 \pi) \delta(x) \delta(y) \cos \Theta \frac{\partial}{\partial z} h(r) \\ & =2 \pi \int_{-R}^{R} \mathrm{~d} z \frac{z}{|z|} \frac{\partial}{\partial z} h(|z|) \\ & =4 \pi \int_{0}^{R} \mathrm{~d} z \frac{\partial}{\partial z} h(z)=4 \pi[h(R)-h(0)] . \end{aligned}∫d3rCS(A)​=∫d3r(2π)δ(x)δ(y)cosΘ∂z∂​h(r)=2π∫−RR​ dz∣z∣z​∂z∂​h(∣z∣)=4π∫0R​ dz∂z∂​h(z)=4π[h(R)−h(0)].​

(c) Extracting the last derivative leaves

CS⁡(A)=∂kVck−εijk(∂k∂iΦ)∂jcos⁡Θh(r),Vck=εijk∂iΦ∂jcos⁡Θh(r)=εΦθk(1rsin⁡Θ)(−1rsin⁡Θ)h(r)=δkrh(r)r2\begin{aligned} \operatorname{CS}(A) & =\partial_{k} V_{c}^{k}-\varepsilon^{i j k}\left(\partial_{k} \partial_{i} \Phi\right) \partial_{j} \cos \Theta h(r), \\ V_{c}^{k} & =\varepsilon^{i j k} \partial_{i} \Phi \partial_{j} \cos \Theta h(r) \\ & =\varepsilon^{\Phi \theta k}\left(\frac{1}{r \sin \Theta}\right)\left(-\frac{1}{r} \sin \Theta\right) h(r) \\ & =\delta^{k r} \frac{h(r)}{r^{2}} \end{aligned}CS(A)Vck​​=∂k​Vck​−εijk(∂k​∂i​Φ)∂j​cosΘh(r),=εijk∂i​Φ∂j​cosΘh(r)=εΦθk(rsinΘ1​)(−r1​sinΘ)h(r)=δkrr2h(r)​​

Here the surface integral contributes 4πh(R)4 \pi h(R)4πh(R). The singular term is

−δj3(2π)δ(x)δ(y)(∂jcos⁡Θ)h(r)=−(2π)δ(x)δ(y)(∂∂zz∣z∣)h(∣z∣)=−(4π)δ3(r)h(0).\begin{aligned} -\delta^{j 3}(2 \pi) \delta(x) \delta(y)\left(\partial_{j} \cos \Theta\right) h(r) & =-(2 \pi) \delta(x) \delta(y)\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z} \frac{z}{|z|}\right) h(|z|) \\ & =-(4 \pi) \delta^{3}(\boldsymbol{r}) h(0) . \end{aligned}−δj3(2π)δ(x)δ(y)(∂j​cosΘ)h(r)​=−(2π)δ(x)δ(y)(∂z∂​∣z∣z​)h(∣z∣)=−(4π)δ3(r)h(0).​

Hence this contribution to the spatial integral is −4πh(0)-4 \pi h(0)−4πh(0), for a total of 4π[h(R)−h(0)]4 \pi[h(R)-h(0)]4π[h(R)−h(0)]. Problem 5 In the Clebsch parameterization, B=∇α×∇β\boldsymbol{B}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \alpha \times \boldsymbol{\nabla} \betaB=∇α×∇β, and δA=∇δγ+δα∇β+\delta \boldsymbol{A}=\boldsymbol{\nabla} \delta \gamma+\delta \alpha \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta+δA=∇δγ+δα∇β+ α∇δβ\alpha \boldsymbol{\nabla} \delta \betaα∇δβ. Therefore

B⋅δA=B⋅∇δγ+B⋅α∇δβ+(B⋅∇β)δα=∇⋅(Bδγ)+∇⋅(Bαδβ)−(B⋅∇α)δβ+(B⋅∇β)δα.\begin{aligned} \boldsymbol{B} \cdot \delta \boldsymbol{A} & =\boldsymbol{B} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \delta \gamma+\boldsymbol{B} \cdot \alpha \boldsymbol{\nabla} \delta \beta+(\boldsymbol{B} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta) \delta \alpha \\ & =\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\boldsymbol{B} \delta \gamma)+\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot(\boldsymbol{B} \alpha \delta \beta)-(\boldsymbol{B} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \alpha) \delta \beta+(\boldsymbol{B} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \beta) \delta \alpha . \end{aligned}B⋅δA​=B⋅∇δγ+B⋅α∇δβ+(B⋅∇β)δα=∇⋅(Bδγ)+∇⋅(Bαδβ)−(B⋅∇α)δβ+(B⋅∇β)δα.​

The last two terms vanish, so ∫d3rA⋅B\int \mathrm{d}^{3} r \boldsymbol{A} \cdot \boldsymbol{B}∫d3rA⋅B is the surface term ∫dS⋅B(δγ+αδβ)\int \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{S} \cdot \boldsymbol{B}(\delta \gamma+\alpha \delta \beta)∫dS⋅B(δγ+αδβ) with no contribution from the bulk (finite r\boldsymbol{r}r space). This of course is consistent with the ChernSimons integral being a surface term, since δ12∫ d3rA⋅B=∫d3rB⋅δA\delta \frac{1}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{3} r \boldsymbol{A} \cdot \boldsymbol{B}=\int \mathrm{d}^{3} r \boldsymbol{B} \cdot \delta \boldsymbol{A}δ21​∫ d3rA⋅B=∫d3rB⋅δA. When demanding the variation of 12∫ d3rB2\frac{1}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{3} r B^{2}21​∫ d3rB2 to vanish, we first find ∫d3r(∇×B)⋅δA=0\int \mathrm{d}^{3} r(\boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{B}) \cdot \delta \boldsymbol{A}=0∫d3r(∇×B)⋅δA=0. When δA\delta \boldsymbol{A}δA is arbitrary, this condition implies the vanishing of ∇×B\boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{B}∇×B. However, in the Clebsch parameterization, all we can conclude is that ∇×B\boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{B}∇×B is proportional to B\boldsymbol{B}B, with a position-dependent proportionality factor ∇×B=μB\boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{B}=\mu \boldsymbol{B}∇×B=μB. Taking the divergence shows that B⋅∇μ=0\boldsymbol{B} \cdot \boldsymbol{\nabla} \mu=0B⋅∇μ=0, that is, μ\muμ can be a function of the magnetic surfaces; see (64), (69).

Problem 6 θ(t,r)=r2/2t\theta(t, \boldsymbol{r})=r^{2} / 2 tθ(t,r)=r2/2t. Time rescaling: θω(t,r)=eωθ(T,r),T=eωt;eωθ(T,r)=\theta_{\omega}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=e^{\omega} \theta(T, \boldsymbol{r}), T=e^{\omega} t ; e^{\omega} \theta(T, \boldsymbol{r})=θω​(t,r)=eωθ(T,r),T=eωt;eωθ(T,r)= eωr2/2eωt=r2/2t=θ(t,r)e^{\omega} r^{2} / 2 e^{\omega} t=r^{2} / 2 t=\theta(t, \boldsymbol{r})eωr2/2eωt=r2/2t=θ(t,r).

Space-time mixing: θω(t,r)=θ(T,R),T=t+ω⋅r+12ω2θ(T,R)=t+ω⋅r+ω2R2/4T\theta_{\boldsymbol{\omega}}(t, \boldsymbol{r})=\theta(T, \boldsymbol{R}), T=t+\boldsymbol{\omega} \cdot \boldsymbol{r}+\frac{1}{2} \omega^{2} \theta(T, \boldsymbol{R})=t+\boldsymbol{\omega} \cdot \boldsymbol{r}+\omega^{2} R^{2} / 4 Tθω​(t,r)=θ(T,R),T=t+ω⋅r+21​ω2θ(T,R)=t+ω⋅r+ω2R2/4T, R=r+ωθ(T,R)=r+ωR2/2T\boldsymbol{R}=\boldsymbol{r}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \theta(T, \boldsymbol{R})=\boldsymbol{r}+\boldsymbol{\omega} R^{2} / 2 TR=r+ωθ(T,R)=r+ωR2/2T. Squaring the second equation gives R2=r2+ω⋅rR2/T+R^{2}=r^{2}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \cdot \boldsymbol{r} R^{2} / T+R2=r2+ω⋅rR2/T+ ω2R4/4T2\omega^{2} R^{4} / 4 T^{2}ω2R4/4T2. Multiplying the first equation by R2/TR^{2} / TR2/T gives R2=tR2/T+ω⋅rR2/T+ω2R4/4T2R^{2}=t R^{2} / T+\boldsymbol{\omega} \cdot \boldsymbol{r} R^{2} / T+\omega^{2} R^{4} / 4 T^{2}R2=tR2/T+ω⋅rR2/T+ω2R4/4T2. Comparing the two shows that R2/T=r2/tR^{2} / T=r^{2} / tR2/T=r2/t or θ(T,R)=θ(t,r)\theta(T, \boldsymbol{R})=\theta(t, \boldsymbol{r})θ(T,R)=θ(t,r).

Problem 7 From (256) and (259) we learn that t=F′′+G′′,x=(p+s)F′′−F′+t=F^{\prime \prime}+G^{\prime \prime}, x=(p+s) F^{\prime \prime}-F^{\prime}+t=F′′+G′′,x=(p+s)F′′−F′+ (p−s)G′′−G′(p-s) G^{\prime \prime}-G^{\prime}(p−s)G′′−G′, where FFF is a function of p+s=R+p+s=R_{+}p+s=R+​and GGG is a function of p−s=R−p-s=R_{-}p−s=R−​. Differentiating these equations with respect to ttt and xxx, it follows that 1=F′′′R˙++G′′′R˙−1=F^{\prime \prime \prime} \dot{R}_{+}+G^{\prime \prime \prime} \dot{R}_{-}1=F′′′R˙+​+G′′′R˙−​, 0=F′′′∂R+∂x+G′′′∂R−∂x,0=R+F′′′R˙++R−G′′′R˙−,1=R+F′′′∂R+∂x+R−G′′′∂R−∂x0=F^{\prime \prime \prime} \frac{\partial R_{+}}{\partial x}+G^{\prime \prime \prime} \frac{\partial R_{-}}{\partial x}, 0=R_{+} F^{\prime \prime \prime} \dot{R}_{+}+R_{-} G^{\prime \prime \prime} \dot{R}_{-}, 1=R_{+} F^{\prime \prime \prime} \frac{\partial R_{+}}{\partial x}+R_{-} G^{\prime \prime \prime} \frac{\partial R_{-}}{\partial x}0=F′′′∂x∂R+​​+G′′′∂x∂R−​​,0=R+​F′′′R˙+​+R−​G′′′R˙−​,1=R+​F′′′∂x∂R+​​+R−​G′′′∂x∂R−​​, which in turn imply ∂R+∂x=1/(R+−R−)F′′′,∂R−∂x=−1/(R+−R−)G′′′\frac{\partial R_{+}}{\partial x}=1 /\left(R_{+}-R_{-}\right) F^{\prime \prime \prime}, \frac{\partial R_{-}}{\partial x}=-1 /\left(R_{+}-R_{-}\right) G^{\prime \prime \prime}∂x∂R+​​=1/(R+​−R−​)F′′′,∂x∂R−​​=−1/(R+​−R−​)G′′′, and R˙±=−R∓∂R±∂x\dot{R}_{ \pm}=-R_{\mp} \frac{\partial R_{ \pm}}{\partial x}R˙±​=−R∓​∂x∂R±​​ [the Riemann equation (252) again].

On the other hand, the functions F±(t±f)F_{ \pm}(t \pm f)F±​(t±f) describing the Chaplygin gas solution from the Nambu-Goto equation are related to R±R_{ \pm}R±​by (288): R±=2F±′R_{ \pm}=2 F_{ \pm}^{\prime}R±​=2F±′​. Hence ∂R±∂x=±2F±′′∂f∂x=\frac{\partial R_{ \pm}}{\partial x}= \pm 2 F_{ \pm}^{\prime \prime} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}=∂x∂R±​​=±2F±′′​∂x∂f​= ±2F±′′/(F+′−F−′)=±4F±′′/(R+−R−)\pm 2 F_{ \pm}^{\prime \prime} /\left(F_{+}^{\prime}-F_{-}^{\prime}\right)= \pm 4 F_{ \pm}^{\prime \prime} /\left(R_{+}-R_{-}\right)±2F±′′​/(F+′​−F−′​)=±4F±′′​/(R+​−R−​), where (282b) is used. It follows that 4F+′′(z)F′′′(2F+′(z))=4 F_{+}^{\prime \prime}(z) F^{\prime \prime \prime}\left(2 F_{+}^{\prime}(z)\right)=4F+′′​(z)F′′′(2F+′​(z))= ddz(2F′′(2F+′(z)))=1\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} z}\left(2 F^{\prime \prime}\left(2 F_{+}^{\prime}(z)\right)\right)=1dzd​(2F′′(2F+′​(z)))=1 and 4F−′′(z)G′′′(2F−′(z))=ddz(2G′′(2F−′(z)))=14 F_{-}^{\prime \prime}(z) G^{\prime \prime \prime}\left(2 F_{-}^{\prime}(z)\right)=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} z}\left(2 G^{\prime \prime}\left(2 F_{-}^{\prime}(z)\right)\right)=14F−′′​(z)G′′′(2F−′​(z))=dzd​(2G′′(2F−′​(z)))=1, or 2F′′(F+′(z))=z2 F^{\prime \prime}\left(F_{+}^{\prime}(z)\right)=z2F′′(F+′​(z))=z and 2G′′(2F−′(z))=z2 G^{\prime \prime}\left(2 F_{-}^{\prime}(z)\right)=z2G′′(2F−′​(z))=z. When F+(z)=ln⁡z/2k,2F+′(z)=1/zkF_{+}(z)=\ln z / 2 k, 2 F_{+}^{\prime}(z)=1 / z kF+​(z)=lnz/2k,2F+′​(z)=1/zk; with F(z)=z2kln⁡zF(z)=\frac{z}{2 k} \ln zF(z)=2kz​lnz, 2F′′(z)=1/kz2 F^{\prime \prime}(z)=1 / k z2F′′(z)=1/kz and 2F′′(2F+′(z))=z2 F^{\prime \prime}\left(2 F_{+}^{\prime}(z)\right)=z2F′′(2F+′​(z))=z; similarly for F−(z)F_{-}(z)F−​(z) and G(z)G(z)G(z).

[3] The Lagrangian description of a fluid and its relation to an Eulerian description is explained, for example, in R. Salmon, Ann. Rev. Fluid Mech. 20, 225 (1988). [4] In the fluid mechanical context, these brackets were put forward by P.J. Morrison and J.M. Greene, Phys. Rev. Lett. 45, 790 (1980); (E) 48, 569 (1982). [5] L. Faddeev and R. Jackiw, Phys. Rev. Lett. 60, 1692 (1988). For a detailed exposition, see R. Jackiw in Constraint Theory and Quantization Methods, F. Colomo, L. Lusanna, and G. Marmo, eds. (World Scientific, Singapore 1994), reprinted in R. Jackiw, Diverse Topics in Theoretical and Mathematical Physics (World Scientific, Singapore 1995). [6] C. Eckart, Phys. Rev. 54, 920 (1938). [7] For an introduction to the properties of the Abelian and non-Abelian Chern-Simons terms, see S. Deser, R. Jackiw, and S. Templeton, Ann. Phys. (NY) 140, 372 (1982), (E) 185, 406 (1985). In fluid mechanics or in magnetohydrodynamics the Abelian Chern-Simons term is known as the fluid or magnetic helicity, and was introduced by L. Woltier, Proc. Nat. Acad. Sci. 44, 489 (1958), and further studied in M. Berger and G. Field, J. Fluid Mech. 147, 133 (1984); H. Moffatt and A. Tsinober, Ann. Rev. Fluid Mech. 24, 281 (1992). [8] C.C. Lin, International School of Physics E. Fermi (XXI), G. Careri, ed. (Academic Press, New York NY 1963). [9] A. Clebsch, J. Reine Angew. Math. 56, 1 (1859). [10] A constructive discussion of the Darboux theorem can be found it the second work of Ref. 卧. [11] H. Lamb, Hydrodynamics (Cambridge University Press, Cambridge UK 1932), p. 248. [12] R. Although accused by Stalinist authorities of succumbing excessively to foreign influences, unaccountably both managed to escape the fatal consequences of their alleged actions; see N. O'Raifeartaigh and V. Sreedhar, htp-th/0007199. [18] R. Jackiw, Physics Today 25(1), 23 (1972); U. Niederer, Helv. Phys. Acta 45, 802 (1972); C.R. Hagen, Phys. Rev. D 5, 377 (1972). D 59, 085007 (1999). [22] Analytic details of the implementation of the space-time mixing transformation on (112) are presented by Bazeia and Jackiw 197. [23] N. Ogawa, Phys. Rev. D 62, 085023 (2000), who also presents other solutions, as does Bazeia, Ref. 21]. [24] R. Jackiw and A.P. Polychronakos, Comm. Math. Phys. 207, 107 (1999). [29] That the theory of a membrane [(d=2)[(d=2)[(d=2)-brane ]]] in three spatial dimensions is equivalent to planar fluid mechanics was known to J. Goldstone (unpublished) and worked out by his student Hoppe (sometimes in collaboration with Bordemann). The method described in Secs. 4.1 and 4.2 was presented for d=2d=2d=2 in J. Hoppe, Phys. Lett. B329, 10 (1994), while a version of the argument in Sec. 4.3 specialized to d=2d=2d=2 is found in Bordemann and Hoppe, Ref. [20]. Generalization to arbitrary ddd is given in R. Jackiw and A.P.
